sentence: A local modification rule is a pair (A,T), where A is a finite set, and T: 2^A ⊎ [2]2→{0,1} is a map from graphs on A ∪ [2] to {0,1}, where [2] := {1,2}, which is symmetric with respect to interchange of the 1 and 2 labels.  Given any vertex set V, we define a modification map T^(V): 2^A ⊎ V2→ 2^V2 by declaring an edge (v_1,v_2) in V to lie in T^(V)(G) for some G ∈ 2^A ⊎ V2 if and only if T( {0,1}_2^(𝕀_A ⊕ϕ)(G) ) = 1, where 𝕀_A ⊕ϕ: A ⊎ [2] → A ⊎{v_1,v_2} is the map which is the identity on A and maps 1,2 to v_1,v_2 respectively.

sentence:
[Testability]<cit.>  Let K be a finite palette of some order k ≥ 0, and let  be a hereditary K-property.  We say that  is testable with one-sided error if, for every > 0, there exists an integer N ≥ 1 and a real number δ > 0 with the following property: if G ∈ K^(V) is a K-coloured hypergraph with N ≤ |V| < ∞ which
locally almost obeys  in the sense that

    1/|VN| |{ W ∈VN: G⇂_W ∈^(W)}| ≥ 1-δ,

then there exists G' ∈^(V) which is close to G in the sense that

    1/|Vk| |{ W ∈Vk: G⇂_W ≠ G'⇂_W }| ≤.

sentence:
[Continuous hypergraphs]  Let K be a finite palette. A K-coloured continuous hypergraph is a quadruplet G = (V,,ν,(G_j)_j=0^∞), where (V,,ν) is a probability space, and G_j: V^j → K_j is a measurable map for each j ≥ 0. If W is an vertex set, we define the sampling map G^(W): V^W → K^(W) by the formula

    G^(W)( v )_j(ϕ) = G_j(v ∘ϕ)

for all j ≥ 0, all ϕ∈([j],W), and all v ∈ V^W, where we view v as a function from W to V (and identify V^j with V^[j]).  If  is a K-property, we say that G obeys  if G^(W)(v) ∈^(W) for all vertex sets W and all v ∈ V^W.

sentence:
(Nakamura)
A monomial x^m y^n (resp. x^m z^n) for m,n≥ 0 is called a
y-valley (resp. z-valley ) for Γ, if

    x^m y^n,x^m+1 y^n,x^m y^n+1∈Γ     x^m+1 y^n+1∉Γ


    (resp.  x^m z^n,x^m+1 z^n,x^m z^n+1∈Γ  but  x^m+1
    z^n+1∉Γ).
 We call a y-valley or z-valley a valley
for brevity.

sentence:
Let M N be an oriented matroid perspective on a linearly ordered set E.

We define the activity class of M N as the set of 
its reorientations -_AM -_AN 
where 
A is any union of 
cyclic or acyclic parts of its active partition. 







Observe that we forbid reorienting the hybrid part
[This is done in order to distinguish reorientations from their complementaries when the hybrid part is non-empty. This yields tighter classes, closer to Tutte polynomial properties, and meaningful notably in the proof of Theorem <ref>.]
.


By Proposition <ref> and 
extending this definition to all reorientations of  M N,
we define activity classes of reorientations of M N , that partition the set of reorientations of M N, and can be seen as classes of the equivalence relation defined by reorienting parts of the active partition.

sentence:
Given two k-uniform hypergraphs on the vertex set [n] E_1 and E_2,

(i) E_1 dominates E_2 if the matrix C_E_1,E_2(X), whose rows and columns correspond
to sets in E_2 and E_1 respectively,
has rank |E_2|.

(ii) E_1 and E_2 are weakly isomorphic if each dominates the other.

sentence:
The interlacement graph of a 4-regular graph F with respect to
an Euler system C is the simple graph ℐ(F,C) with
V(ℐ(F,C))=V(F) and E(ℐ(F,C))={vw


|

v and w are interlaced with respect to C}. The interlacement
matrix of F with respect to C is the adjacency matrix of this graph; when
no confusion can arise, we use ℐ(C) to denote both the graph and
the matrix.

sentence: Let T∈_k(λ).  The promotion (T) of T  is given by the following construction.  If T has no 1's then let (T) be the result of decrementing all the values of T by 1.  Otherwise, do the following.  First, delete all the boxes in T that contain a 1 and rectify the resulting skew tableau.  Next, decrement all the values by 1 and then place a k in all the empty boxes resulting from sliding (so that (T) has the same shape as T).

sentence:
If T ∈_γ(λ,μ)
for some partitions λ, μ and γ, then
let S_1 < S_2 < … < S_d be the multisets
of the unbarred entries that appear in T
(ignoring the barred entries), then we say that T is
a lattice tableau if the word

    read(T|_-) read(T|_S_1) read(T|_S_2)
    ⋯ read(T|_S_d)

is lattice.

sentence:
Let T be a tetrahedron with vertices p_1, p_2, p_3, and p_4. Consider the points q_i= 1/2 (p_1+p_2+p_3+p_4) - p_i, i∈ [4], and let

    C(T)=(p_i,q_i: i∈[4]).
 
C(T) is a parallelepiped with facets (p_i, p_j, q_k, q_l) for all choices of {i,j,k,l}=[4]. We call it the parallelepiped circumscribed to T.

For each i ∈ [4], let T_i=(q_i, p_j, p_k, p_l), with {i,j,k,l}=[4]; we call these T_i the corner tetrahedra of C(T). Together with T they triangulate C(T).

sentence:
The fundamental polytope of a metric space (X,ρ) is the convex polytope
 R_X,ρ obtained as the convex hull of all vectors e_x,y, where (x,y)
 run through all pairs of distinct points of X.
 The combinatorial type of R_X,ρ, i.e., the isomorphism class of the
 corresponding poset of faces,
 is called the combinatorial structure of the finite metric space (X,ρ).
 Two finite metric spaces with the same combinatorial structures called similar metric spaces .

sentence:
Let t∈(2^[k]∖{∅})^K_n and let ϕ∈K_nK_m. The subtemplate of t induced by ϕ is the template t_|ϕ∈(2^[k]∖{∅})^K_m defined by t_|ϕ(ij)=t(ϕ(i)ϕ(j)).
 
 
 
 Given m≤ n and  k-colouring templates t, t' for K_m, K_n respectively, we say that t is a subtemplate of t', which we denote by t≤ t', if there exists ϕ∈K_nK_m such that t(e)⊆ t'_ϕ(e) for every e∈ E(K_m).

sentence:
[Multicolour monotonicity]
An order-hereditary property 𝒫 of k-colourings is monotone with respect to colour i∈[k], or i-monotone , if whenever c is a k-colouring of K_n which lies in 𝒫 and e is any edge of K_n, the colouring c̃ obtained from c by changing the colour of e to i also lies in 𝒫.

either finite or cofinite, then we say that (A,B,C) is a trio .

sentence:
A threshold graph G is a graph that can be constructed recursively starting from one vertex and no edges by repeatedly carrying out one of the following two steps:
		
			
  * add a dominating vertex: a vertex that is connected to every other existing vertex; 
			
  * add an isolated vertex: a vertex that is not connected to any other existing vertex. 
		
		We say that a threshold graph G is labeled by reverse degree sequence if its vertices are labeled by 0, …, n in such a way that d_i ≥  d_j for each pair of vertices i < j, where d_i is the degree of vertex i.

sentence:
A combinatorial (p_q, n_k)-configuration is an incidence structure 
𝒞 = (P,B,I), where 
I ⊆P× B, P ∩ B = ∅, |P| = p and |B| = n. 
The elements of P are called points , the elements of B are called blocks , 
and the relation I is called the incidence relation. Furthermore, each line is incident 
with k points, each point is incident with q blocks, and two distinct points are incident with 
at most one common line, i.e.,


    { (p_1, b_1), (p_2, b_1), (p_1, b_2), (p_2, b_2) }⊆ I, p_1 ≠ p_2  b_1 = b_2.

sentence:
Vertex-transitive Lauri J. et al. <cit.> 


“We say that a graph G is vertex-transitive if any two vertices of G are similar, that is, if, for any u, v ∈ V(G), there is an automorphism α of G such that α(u) = v.”
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Arc-transitive Lauri J. et al. <cit.>

“If G has the property that, for any two edges {a, b},{c, d}, there is an automorphism α such that α(a) = c and α(b) = d and also an automorphism β such that β(a) = d and β(b) = c, then G is said to be arc-transitive .”

A function f:{h(H)⊆ G :  h∈ G^H}→ [0,1] is a fractional hom_H-tiling in G of size κ∈ℝ^+ if it satisfies the following two properties:


  * For any vertex v∈ V(G), we have ∑ f(h(H))· |h^-1(v)|≤ 1, where the sum runs over all homomorphisms h∈ G^H.

  * We have that ∑ f(h(H))=κ, where the sum runs through all homomorphisms h∈ G^H.

sentence: A hyperweb ^rW_l^a-1 is a r-uniform hypergraph on l vertices placed in a cycle in increasing order, say 1 through l. The r-edges present are such that every a consecutive vertices form an a-clique, i.e., for any given vertex, any edge starting with it and spanning at most the next a-1 vertices will be present. We only consider hyperwebs for which l≥ 2a, so that we do not have a complete hypergraph. A hyperweb is thus for us a hyperwheel with the central vertex removed. For example, Figure <ref> represents the edges present in ^3W_7^3.

coflow which has exactly one or two nonzero-entries.

sentence:
Let 𝒟_1 (resp. 𝒟_2) be the set of horizontal (resp. vertical) edges of a maximal Dyck path 𝒟=𝒟^a_1× a_2. We label 𝒟 with the corner-first index in the following sense:




  * edges in 𝒟_1 are indexed as u_1,…,u_a_1 such that u_i is the horizontal edge of the i-th corner for i∈ [1,c] and u_c+i is the i-th of the remaining horizontal ones for i∈ [1, a_1-c],

  * edges in 𝒟_2 are indexed as v_1,…, v_a_2 such that v_i is the vertical edge of the i-th corner for i∈ [1,c] and v_c+i is the i-th  of the remaining vertical ones for i∈ [1, a_2-c].

(Here we count corners from bottom left to top right, count vertical edges from bottom to top, and count horizontal edges from left to right.)

sentence:
[Rains and Vazirani <cit.>]
A quasiparabolic W-set is a scaled W-set (X,) satisfying the following two properties:

    
  ∙ (QP1) For all r∈ R(W), x∈ X, if (rx)=(x), then rx = x.
    
  ∙ (QP2) For all r∈ R(W), x∈ X, s∈ S, if (rx) > (x) and (srx) < (sx), then rx = sx.

sentence:

Then we call s_1s_2⋯ s_kx_0 a reduced expression for x if x=s_1s_2⋯ s_kx_0, s_i∈ S. By abuse of notation, we also call wx_0 reduced where w =s_1s_2⋯ s_k is the corresponding reduced expression.

sentence:
A square matrix in which each row (after the first) has the elements of the previous
row shifted cyclically one place right is called a circulant matrix. So, a circulant matrix has the form




    𝐌= circ(m_0, m_1,… , m_n-1) =
    [
        [   m_0   m_1     … m_n-1; m_n-1   m_0     … m_n-2;     ⋮     ⋮     ⋱     ⋮;   m_1   m_2     …   m_0;       ]],

sentence:
Let L be a Latin cube that is isomorphic to a Boolean Latin cube.


A row block of L is a set of n rows R_i,k such that for every pair 
of rows R_i_1,k_1={(i_1,j,k_1): j ∈ [n]} and 
R_i_2,k_2 = {(i_2,j,k_2): j ∈ [n]} in this set, B(i_1,x,k_1)=B(i_2,x,k_2) for every x ∈{1,…,n}. It is obvious that there are n row blocks in total.
Column blocks and  file blocks are defined similarly.

sentence:
[ Noncommutative Schur functions ]

Let λ=(λ_1,λ_2,…) be an integer partition.
Let λ' be the conjugate partition,
and let  t=λ_1 be the  number of parts of λ'.
The noncommutative Schur function
𝔍_λ(𝐮) ∈ is given by the following
noncommutative version of the classical Kostka-Naegelsbach determinantal formula  s_λ = (e_λ'_i+j-i) :

    𝔍_λ(𝐮) = ∑_π∈_t(π)   e_λ'_1+π(1)-1(𝐮) 
    e_λ'_2+π(2)-2(𝐮) ⋯
    e_λ'_t+π(t)-t(𝐮).

sentence:
For 
α=(α_1,…,α_l)∈_≥ 0^l
and 
𝐧=(n_1,…,n_l) ∈{0,1,…, N}^l,
we define the noncommutative column-flagged Schur function
J_α(𝐧)=J_α(𝐧)(𝐮) by

    J_α(𝐧)
    =∑_π∈_l(π)   e_α_1+π(1)-1(𝐮_[n_1])
     e_α_2+π(2)-2(𝐮_[n_2])⋯
    e_α_l+π(l)-l(𝐮_[n_l]).

These specialize to the noncommutative Schur functions 𝔍_λ(𝐮)

via
𝔍_λ(𝐮) = J_λ'(N,…,N).

    (P_1,…,P_n)     :=    1/n!∑_j = 1^n (-1)^n - j∑_1 ≤ i_1 < ⋯ < i_j ≤ n(P_i_1+⋯ +P_i_j).

sentence:
Let :={f_1,… f_n}⊆[𝐳^± 1] be a generic collection of Laurent polynomials. Let K be a connected component of  (). Let 0≤ k≤ n-1.
  
   
  (a) A non-empty and connected subset F⊊ K is called a k-face of K, if there exist unique  E_α(1)(f_j_1),…,E_α(n-k)(f_j_n-k) such that  𝐱∈⋂_s = 1^n-k∂E_α(s)(f_j_s) for all 𝐱∈ F.
   
  (b) An (n-1)-dimensional face of K is called a facet of K.

sentence:
Let S be a totally ordered idempotent semifield,
	and let w ∈ S^Ed be a tropical Plücker vector.
	Then the tropical linear space associated to w
	is the intersection of the tropical hyperplanes defined by 
	
    ∑_i ∈ J w_J-ix_i

	over all J ∈Ed+1.
	The tropical linear space associated to w is denoted L_w.

	The tropical image of L_w under A, denoted AL_w, is the projection 
	
    π_F(L_g(w,a))

	of the tropical graph of A on L_w onto the codomain of A.

sentence:
Let φ be an acyclic morphism.
We say that φ is marked if


(φ_L) and (φ_R) are injective


and that φ is well-marked if


it is marked and if (φ_L)=(φ_R)


where φ_L (resp. φ_R) is the leftmost (resp. rightmost)
conjugate of φ.

sentence:
Suppose ℜ= (R, ≤) is a preorder with approximations. Assume X is a subset of R. We say that X is Ramsey iff for every n
∈ω and a⃗∈ R, there exists b⃗∈ [n,a⃗] such that [n,b⃗] is either contained in or disjoint from X. Assuming
the Axiom of Choice, ℜ is a Ramsey space iff  every subset of ℜ (endowed with the natural topology) having the
property of Baire is Ramsey.

sentence: A set system  shatters a given set S ⊆[n] if 2^S = {F ∩ S  :   F ∈ℱ}. The family of subsets of [n] shattered by ℱ is denoted by Sh(ℱ).

sentence:
Given p,p'∈𝒫^∘∙_2,nb and sectors S in p and S' in p', we number the points in (S) and (S') with respect to the cyclic order. We say that (p,S) and (p',S') are equivalent if the following four conditions are met:
	
		
  * The sectors S and S' are of equal size.
		
  * The same normalized colors occur in the same order in S and S'.
		
  * For all i, the point at position i in S belongs to a block crossing ∂ S in p if and only if the block of i-th point in S' crosses ∂ S' in p'. 
		
  * For all i,j, the points at positions i,j in S form a block in p if and only if the i-th and j-th points of S' constitute one of the blocks of p'.
                
                In other words: p restricted to S coincides with p' restricted to S' (up to rotation).

sentence:
We denote by () the set of all triples (a,b,U), where (a,b)∈, U⊆a,b, and a≠ b implies that a∉ U and b∈ U. We set U^=a,b∖ U, and
 
    abU=(x,y)a x y b ,
      x∉ U , and y∈ U ,   if a≠ b ,
    
     (a∪ U^)×
     (a∪ U) ,   if a=b ,

for each (a,b,U)∈(). Hence 
abU=∩(a∪ U^)×(b∪ U) in each case.


Observe that abU is bipartite iff a≠ b. If a=b,
we shall say that abU is a clepsydra .
[After “clessidra”, which is the Italian for “hourglass”,
  the latter describing the pattern of the associated transitive
  relation: the elements of U^ below; a in the middle; the
  elements of U above.]

Two point sets A, B⊂ℝ^2 are called separated if (A)∩(B)=∅. Two separated m-element sets, A and B, are said to form an -avoiding pair for some ≥0 if  
    ι(A,<_B)+ι(B,<_A)≤ m^2.
 For simplicity, a 0-avoiding pair is called avoiding . See Figure <ref> (left).

sentence:
Let G be a graph, let c be a coloring of G, and let r≥ 2 and d≥ 1. 
	A coloring c' is a (d,r)-excellent refinement of c if for every vertex set X⊆ V(G) 
	there exists an r-shortest path closure X' of X such that if X receives p colors in c', then X' receives at most d· p colors in c.

sentence:
Given a weak composition a, a quasi-key tableau of shape a is a filling of D(a) with positive integers satisfying


  * entries weakly decrease along rows, and no entry of row i exceeds i

  * entries in any column are distinct, and entries increase up the first column

  * if an entry i is above an entry k in the same column with i<k, then there is a label j immediately right of k, with i<j

  * Given two rows with the higher row strictly longer, then if entry i is in column c of the lower row and entry j in column c+1 of the higher row, then  i<j.

Denote the set of quasi-key tableaux of shape a by (a); for example, see Figure <ref>. Moreover, let ^(1)(a) be all quasi-key tableaux of shape a whose first column entries are equal to their row index.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[<cit.>]
  A quasi-key tableau is quasi-Yamanouchi if the leftmost occurrence of each entry i is either
  
  
  * in row i, or
  
  * weakly left of some entry i+1.
  
  Denote the set of quasi-Yamanouchi quasi-key tableaux of shape a by (a).

		Let H be obtained from G by contracting both e_1 and e_2 and deleting all resulting parallel edges.
		We say that H is obtained from G by bicontraction or bicontracting the vertex v_0 .

sentence:
For T a Young tableau with columns C^1, C^2 … , C^m where C^i = c^i_1, c^i_2, …, c^i_k with c^i_j being the (j,i)th entry of T, we define the column reading word of T to be the word τ(T) = C^m C^m-1… C^1. 
Note if T is row and column strict then P(τ(T)) = T and each column of Q(τ(T)) has consecutive entries.
For w a reduced word, we define τ(w) to be  τ(P(w)). 
By the previous observation, w and τ(w) are Coxeter-Knuth equivalent.

sentence: <cit.> A subset M of the  edge set of G, is called a matching in G if no two of the edges in M are adjacent. In other words, if for any two edges e and f in M, both the end vertices of e are different from the end vertices of f.

sentence: <cit.> An n-sun or a trampoline , denoted by S_n, is a chordal graph on 2n vertices, where n ≥ 3, whose vertex set can be partitioned into two sets U = {u_1, u_2, u_3, . . . , u_n} and W = {w_1, w_2, w_3, . . . , w_n} such that U is an independent set of G and u_i is adjacent to w_j if and only if j = i or j = i + 1 (n). A complete sun is a sun G where the induced subgraph  ⟨ U⟩ is complete.

sentence:
Call a graph treeish if it can be constructed recursively via the following rules.  


  * An edge or a triangle is treeish. 

  * If G is treeish and v is a vertex of G, adding a new vertex w and a new edge {v, w} results in a treeish graph. 

  * If G is treeish, and {v, w} is an edge of G, then the graph obtained from G by adding a new vertex z and the edges {v, z} and {w, z} is treeish.

sentence:
For any P-diagram , define J() as the join of all spaces in the diagram realized by embedding them in skew affine subspaces.  The points of J() can be parametrized as 
    {∑_p ∈ P t_p x_p   | .  x_p ∈ D(p),  0 ≤ t_p ≤ 1  for all  p ∈ P,  and ∑_p ∈ P t_p = 1 }.
  Then the geometric realization of _P consists of the following set of points: 
    {t_0x_0 + ... + t_mx_m ∈ J()  |  x_i ∈ D(p_i),  p_0 ≤ ... ≤ p_m,  d_p_i+1 p_i(x_i+1) = x_i}.

sentence:
Let _1/2^± denote the set of all positive/negative half integers, respectively.

The vacuum ⊂_1/2 is the set _1/2^-.

A state S is a set S⊂+1/2 so that the symmetric
difference 

    S =(S∩_1/2^+)∪ (S^c∩_1/2^-)

 is finite.  States should be interpreted as a finite collection of electrons – 
the elements of S∩^+_1/2, which we will denote by S^+, and a finite collections of positrons – the elements of S^c∩^-_1/2, which we will denote by S^-.

The charge c(S) of a state S is the number of positrons minus the number of electrons:

    c(S)=| S^-| -| S^+|


The energy e(S) of a state S is the sum of all the energies of the positrons and the electrons:

    e(S)=∑_k∈ S^+  k +∑_k∈ S^-  -k
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:

    Λ_R={𝐳=(z_1,… z_a)|𝐳∈^a+ℤ(1/a,1/a,…, 1/a), ∑_i=1^a z_i=0}

sentence: We say that two disjoint subsets (_1,_2) of vertices of G are α-linked for 0<α≤ 1, iff for every pair '_1⊆_1 and _2'⊆_2 of equal-sized vertex subsets, there is a flow F:_1'_1/α_2' in G. We say that they are node-linked , iff for every pair '_1⊆_1 and _2'⊆_2 of equal-sized vertex subsets, there is a collection of |'_1| node-disjoint paths connecting the vertices of '_1 to the vertices of _2'.

sentence:
Let G = (V, E) be a simple connected graph and d_G(u, v) be the length of the shortest
path between the vertices u and v in G. For an ordered set S ={u_1,⋯, u_t} of vertices in V and a vertex v, we call r(v|S) = (d_G(v, u_1), ⋯, d_G(v, u_t)) the metric representation of v with respect to S.

Let G = (V, E) be a simple connected graph and d_G(u, v) be the length of the shortest

if every option is even in form and G  0.  G is even (odd) in value
if it equals a short game that is even (odd) in form.

every option is an i-game, and if G is even-tempered, then (G) ≥(G).

sentence:
a) A word W is n-divisible in ordinary sense if there exist
u_1, u_2,…,u_n such that W=v· u_1⋯
u_n and u_1≻…≻ u_n.

b) In our proof we will call a word W n-divisible in tail sense if there exist tails
u_1,…,u_n such that u_1≻ u_2≻…≻ u_n and for any
i=1, 2,…, n - 1 the beginning of u_i is to the left from the beginning of
u_i+1. If the contrary is not specified, an n-divisible word means n-divisible
in tail sense.

c) A word W is n-cancellable if either it is
n-divisible in ordinary sense or there exists a word of the form u^d⊆ W..

sentence: The arboricity of a graph G, denoted by 𝒜(G), is the minimum number of spanning forests whose union  covers all the edges of G. The star arboricity of a graph G, denoted by 𝒮(G), is the minimum number of spanning star forests whose union covers all the edges of G.

sentence:
[Interval dimension]

A open interval on the real line, denoted as (a,b), where a,b ∈ and a < b, is the set {x ∈ℝ : a <  x < b}. For a collection C of open intervals on the real line the partial order (C, ) defined by the relation (a,b)  (c,d) if b ≤ c in  is called the interval order corresponding to C. The poset dimension of this interval order (C,) is called the interval dimension of C and is denoted by (C).
word_labels: O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O

sentence:
A limit permutation is a Lebesgue measurable function Z:[0,1]^2 →[0,1] satisfying the following conditions:


  (a) for every x∈[0,1], the function Z(x,·) is a cdf, continuous at the point 0, for which Z(x,1)=1;


  (b) for every y∈[0,1], the function Z(·,y) is such that

    ∫_0^1 Z(x,y) dx = y.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Weighted permutation]
Given an integer k, a weighted permutation is a matrix Q:[k]^2 → [0,1] with the following two properties:



  (a) for every i ∈ [k] and j ≤ j' ∈ [k], we have Q(i,j) ≤ Q(i,j');


  (b) for every j ∈ [k], we have

    j-1 ≤∑_i=1^k Q(i,j) ≤ j.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Subpermutation density in a weighted permutation]

Given a weighted permutation Q:[k]^2→[0,1]
and a permutation τ:[m]→[m], m<k, the subpermutation density of τ in Q is given by

    t(τ,Q)=km^-1∑_X∈[k]^m_<∑_A∈[k+1]^m_<∏_i=1^m(Q(x_i,a_τ(i))-Q(x_i,a_τ(i)-1)),

where we use the notation X=(x_1,…,x_m) and A=(a_1,…,a_m).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Rectangular distance between limit permutations]
Given functions Z_1,Z_2:[0,1]^2→[0,1] such that Z(x,·) is a cdf for every x∈[0,1], the rectangular distance between Z_1 and Z_2 is defined by

    d_□(Z_1,Z_2) = sup_x_1<x_2∈ [0,1]
    α_1<α_2∈[0,1]|∫_x_1^x_2∫_α_1^α_2dZ_1(x,·)dx
      -∫_x_1^x_2∫_α_1^α_2dZ_2(x,·)dx|.

sentence:
Let N, N' be two networks with leaves labeled with X.
 Then an isomorphism between N and N' is a bijection ϕ: V(N) → V(N') such that 
 
  
  * two nodes u,v ∈ V(N) are adjacent in N if and only if ϕ(u) and ϕ(v) are adjacent in N';
  
  * for any leaf u ∈ L(N), ϕ(u) is the leaf in L(N') that has the same label as u.
 
We say N and N' are isomorphic if there exists an isomorphism between N and N'.

sentence:
A mycorrhizal forest[
 Mycorrhizal forests are so-called because of their similarity to real-life mycorrhizal networks, in which a number of trees may be connected together by an underground network of fungi.] with leaves X is a network M=(𝒯,R) defined by:


  * a set of t trees 𝒯 = (T_1,… ,T_t) with leaf sets X_1,… ,X_t respectively (the tree components ),

  * a network R (the root component ) with t leaves x_1,…,x_t, such that deleting all these leaves and the root makes R biconnected.

The mycorrhizal forest is the network where the root edge of T_i is identified with the edge leading to leaf x_i in R (see Figure <ref> for an example). A mycorrhizal forest with t=1 is called a mycorrhizal tree .

If M and M' are mycorrhizal forests with tree components T_1,… ,T_t and T'_1,… ,T'_t, respectively, both having leaf sets X_1,… ,X_t, then we denote d_treeSPR(M,M'):=∑_id_rSPR(T_i,T_i'), which is the distance induced by rSPR moves only within tree components (treeSPR moves).

sentence: Given a filling σ of the diagram of a partition λ, we say that σ is a sorted tableau if, for all positive integers h, when we read all columns of height h from left to right, the columns appear in weakly increasing order with respect to .  We write (λ) for the set of all sorted tableaux of shape λ.

sentence:
Given a rotationally symmetric n-Venn diagram, we label the curves as C_1, C_2, …, C_n according to the clockwise order in which
   they touch the unbounded outermost face.
 Assume that we have a cluster with the property that every curve intersects the cluster in a segment and that
   cluster S_k contains the crosscut for curve C_k.
 Let L_i,k be the list of curves that we encounter as we follow C_i in the cluster S_k in clockwise order, and
   let ℓ_i,k denote the length of L_i,k.
 A rotationally symmetric n-Venn diagram has crosscut symmetry if it can be partitioned into n such clusters
   S_1, S_2, … , S_n in such a way that for every cluster S_k, for any i  k,
   the list L_i,k is palindromic, that is, for 1 ≤ j ≤ℓ_i,k, we have L_i,k[j] = L_i,k[ℓ_i,k-j+1].

sentence: For any edge e ⊆ [n] and i ∈ e, we define the next vertex of e as follows. If there is some vertex j ∈ e such that j > i, then Next(i,e) is defined to be the smallest such j. Otherwise, if i is the largest element of e, then we define Next(i,e) to be the smallest element of e.

sentence:
Assume the quasiparabolic W-set (X,)  is bounded below and admits a bar operator. 
For each x ∈ X there are  unique elements M_x ∈(X,) and N_x ∈(X,) with 

    M_x = M_x∈ M_x + ∑_w<x v^-1[v^-1] · M_w
    N_x = N_x∈ N_x + ∑_w<x v^-1[v^-1] · N_w

 where both sums are over w ∈ X.
The elements {M_x}_x ∈ X and {N_x}_x∈ X form  -bases for (X,)  (X,), which we refer to as the canonical bases of these modules.

sentence:
Let  be a finite set of combinatorial objects, and let  be
  a descent set map on  such that (T) ⊆ [n-1] for
  all T ∈. A dual equivalence for (,) is a
  family of involutions {φ_i}_1<i<n on  satisfying the
  following conditions:

  
  
    -0.7
  
  * ( fixed points ) The fixed points of φ_i are
    given by
    
      ^φ_i  =  { T ∈ |  i-1 ∈(T)
        ⇔i ∈(T) }.
    
    

  
  * ( descent set ) For T∈∖^φ_i, we have
    
    {j}∩(T) ≠{j}∩(φ_i(T))     j = i-1  j = i, 
       {j}∩(T)   =  {j}∩(φ_i(T))     j<i-2  i+1<j.

    
    
  
  * ( equality ) For T∈∖^φ_i, we have
    
    {i-2}∩(T) ≠{i-2}∩(φ_i(T))
             ⇔   φ_i(T) = φ_i-1(T), 
    {i+1}∩(T) ≠{i+1}∩(φ_i(T))
             ⇔   φ_i(T) = φ_i+1(T).

    
    
  
  * ( commutativity ) For T ∈ and |i-j| ≥ 3, we
    have
    
      φ_j∘φ_i(T) = φ_i∘φ_j(T).
    
    

  
  * ( minimality ) For any 2 ≤ h ≤ i<n, if S =
    φ_i_ℓ∘⋯∘φ_i_1 (T) for indices
    h ≤ i_1,…,i_ℓ≤ i, then there exist indices h
    ≤ j_1,…,j_m ≤ i with at most one j_k = i such that
    S = φ_j_m∘⋯∘φ_j_1 (T).

Define a q-analog of Littlewood-Richardson coefficients by

    G_μ,ν(x;q) ∑_ν⊢ nLR_μ^(0),⋯,μ^(n-1)^ν(q) s_ν(x)   ,

where s_ν(x) is the Schur function corresponding to the partition ν.

sentence:
A set of edges
((i_1,j_1),(i_2,j_2),…,(i_ℓ,j_ℓ)) is a
L zig-zag path if i_1=1, the indices satisfy the pattern of
inequalities

    j_2b   > j_2b-1,
       
    i_2b   > n-j_2b-1+1
    ,
       
    i_2b   > i_2b+1,
       
    n-j_2b+1+1 >i_2b,

and either i_ℓ=n or j_ℓ=1.  The analogous structure
starting with j_1=n is called

R zig-zag path .

sentence:
[Square constructor]
Let τ be a permutation matrix of size k, and let 0 ≤ i,j
≤ k, with i+j>0. The pair i,j describes a way to decompose
τ into four (possibly empty) rectangular blocks,
τ=( [ A B; C D ]),

so that A and B have i rows, and A and C have j
columns. For h,ℓ∈{1,…,n}, and
 a permutation of size n with ℓ=(h)),
the square constructors C_τ,i,j^ col-h and
C_τ,i,j^ row-ℓ, acting on , produce the same
configuration ', of size n+k+1, 



as described in Figure <ref>.

sentence: A matching in a graph G is a set of edges such that no two of them  have a vertex in common. The number of edges in a matching is called the size of that matching . The collection of all matchings of size k in a graph G is denoted by ℳ_k(G). We define m_k(G)=|ℳ_k(G)| with the convention that m_0(G)=1.  A matching is called maximal if it is not contained in any other matching. The largest possible cardinality among all matchings is called the matching number of G.

sentence:
Given a hypergraph G∈ HG[n],
  the hypergraphic polytope P_G associated to G is the polytope in ℝ^n
  defined by the Minkowski sum
      
    P_G=∑_U∈ GΔ_U,

      where Δ_U is the simplex given by the convex hull of the points {e_i | i∈ U}.

sentence:
A template Γ is a directed graph (possibly with multiple
edges) on vertices
{0, …, l}, where l≥ 1, with edge
weights w(e) ∈_>0, satisfying:


  * If i → j is an edge, then i <j.

  * Every edge i e→ i+1 has weight w(e) ≥
  2. (No “short edges.”)

  * For each vertex j, 1 ≤ j ≤ l-1, there is an edge
  “covering” it, i.e., there exists an edge i → k with i <j <k.

sentence:
Let G=(V,E_G) be an arbitrary graph.


  * The bipartite graph S_G=(V,E_G, E_B) with E_B={ve| v∈ V, e∈ E_G, v∈ e} is the subdivision , also the vertex-edge incidence bipartite graph , of G.

  * Let C(G) denote the set of all maximal cliques of G. The bipartite graph B_G=(V, C(G),E_B) with E_B={vQ| v∈ V, Q∈ C(G), v∈ Q} is the vertex-clique incidence bipartite graph of G.

sentence:
Let 𝒜 be a (possibly infinite) set of linear hyperplanes in V:=ℝ^r and let T be an open convex cone in V. We say that 𝒜 is locally finite in T if for every x ∈ T  there exists a neighbourhood U_x ⊂ T of x, such that { H ∈𝒜| H ∩ U_x ≠∅} is finite. A hyperplane arrangement (of rank r) is a pair (𝒜,T), where T is a convex open cone in V, and 𝒜 is a set of linear hyperplanes such that the following holds: 

  * H ∩ T ≠∅ for all H ∈𝒜,

  * 𝒜 is locally finite in T.

Denote by T the topological closure of T with respect to the standard topology of V. If X ⊂T then the localization at X (in 𝒜) is defined as 
    𝒜_X:= { H ∈𝒜  |   X ⊂ H }.
 
In the case X= { x } we write 𝒜_x instead of A_{ x } and call (𝒜_x, T) the parabolic subarrangement at x.  The connected components of T ∖⋃_H ∈𝒜 H are called chambers or cells . If K is a chamber then its walls are given by the hyperplanes contained in the set 
    W^K:= { H ≤ V   |  dim(H)= r-1, ⟨ H ∩K⟩_ℝ=H, H ∩ K = ∅}.

The arrangement (𝒜, T) is called thin if W^K ⊂𝒜 for each chamber K. A simplicial hyperplane arrangement (of rank r) is an arrangement (𝒜, T) such that each chamber K is an open simplicial cone. T is called the Tits cone of the arrangement. Finally, a simplicial arrangement is called a Tits arrangement if it is also thin.

sentence: Let the pair (𝒜, T) be a Tits arrangement in V:=ℝ^r and denote by ∂ T the boundary of T. If there is a linear form 0 ≠α∈ V^* such that ∂ T=ker(α), then we say that (𝒜, T) is an affine Tits arrangement .

sentence:
Let M be an S-module and φ:V→ M a linear map.  The tropical kernel of φ is
  the submodule (φ)⊂ V consisting of all those elements
  ∑_i=1^n v_i e_i ∈ V such that
  
    φ(∑_i v_i e_i) = φ(∑_i≠ j v_i e_i )

for each j ∈ [n].  Thus 
    (φ) = (V^∨/(φ))^∨.

sentence:
[Orthogonal Matrix, Hadamard Matrices, Cretan Matrix]  
An orthogonal matrix , S= (s_ij) of order n, is square and has the modulus of all its entries ≤ 1, and satisfies SS^⊤ = ω I_n for n = 1, 2, 4t.

An Hadamard matrix of order has entries ± 1  and satisfies
HH^⊤ = nI_n for n = 1, 2, 4t, t > 0 an integer. Any Hadamard matrix can be put into normalized form , that is having the first row and column all plus 1s using Hadamard equivalence operations: that is it can be written with a core.

A Cretan matrix , S,  of order v has entries with modulus ≤ 1 and at least one element in  each row and column  must be 1, and which satisfies SS^⊤ = ω I_v. A Cretan(n; τ; ω ) matrix, or CM(n; τ ; ω) has τ levels or values for its entries.

sentence: A set  of projective k-subspaces is a generator set with respect to co-k-subspaces (briefly, a k-generator set of k-subspaces), if the set ⋃ of all points of the subspaces contained by  is a generator set with respect to co-k-subspaces. The elements of a k-generator set of k-subspaces is said to be in higgledy-piggledy arrangement and a k-generator set of k-subspaces is said to be a set of higgledy-piggledy k-subspaces .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
[k-generator set]
A set 𝒢 of points in the projective space (d,) is a generator set with respect to co-k-subspaces (or briefly, a k-generator set ), if each subspace Π⊂(d,) of co-dimension k meets 𝒢 in a `generator system' of Π, that is, 𝒢∩Π spans Π, in other words this intersection is not contained in any hyperplane of Π. (Hyperplanes of co-k-subspaces are subspaces in (d,) of co-dimension k+1.)

sentence:
We say that a vector ∈ R^ is a score equivalent objective
(abbreviated below as an SE objective) if it satisfies

    ∀  G,H∈   G∼ H  ⇒ ⟨ ,_G⟩ = ⟨ ,_H⟩ .

Clearly, the set of SE objectives is a linear subspace of R^.

sentence:
A monoid M generated by a finite subset S is called strongly
δ-hyperbolic (with respect to the generating set S) if its right
Cayley graph with respect to S is strongly δ-hyperbolic.
A monoid M is called strongly hyperbolic if it is strongly δ-hyperbolic
for some δ with respect to some finite generating set.

sentence:
Let α=(α_1 ≥α_2 ≥⋯≥α_d ≥ 0) be a partition with n ≥α_1.


  * The Schubert variety corresponding to α is the subvariety

    𝕊(α) := {V  |(V ∩ F_α_d+1-i+i) ≥ i  for  i=1,…,d}⊆Gr_d(E) .


  * The Schubert cell corresponding to α is the open subset of 𝕊(α)

    𝕊(α)^∘ := {V |(V ∩ F_α_d+1-i+i) = i,  (V ∩ F_α_d+1-i+i-1) = i-1  for  i=1,…,d}.

sentence:
Let σ⊂ be a cone corresponding to a 1/r(1,c-1) singularity. Let ℓ be the local index and let k be the width of the cone. Write k=dℓ+r, where d,r∈_≥ 0, 0≤ r<ℓ. The residue of σ is

    σ=1/rℓ(1,rc/k-1),    if r≠ 0;
    ∅,    otherwise.

The singularity content of σ is the pair (d,σ). The singularity content is local qG-deformation-theoretic data about σ.

sentence: Let X be an orbifold del Pezzo surface. A maximal invisible subcollection of the basket  of X is called an invisible basket for X. Notice that such a maximal subcollection is not unique, since singularities can appear in many different cancelling tuples. Given a choice of invisible basket ⊂, the complement =∖ is called the reduced basket for X corresponding to the choice of .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O

sentence: To a checkerboard-colored link diagram D, we construct the associated Tait graph G as follows. First, we associate a vertex to each black region of D. Next, we join a pair of distinct vertices by an edge if the two corresponding regions share a crossing of D and we join a vertex to itself if the corresponding region meets a crossing of D twice. Finally, we label the edges with either + or - according to the convention displayed in the center of Figure <ref>. What results is an edge-signed planar graph G called the Tait graph associated to D. See Figure <ref> for an example of the construction of a Tait graph. Note that the white regions of D correspond to the faces (complementary regions) of G. Also note that changing the crossing type of a single crossing of D corresponds to changing the sign of the corresponding edge of G and forming the mirror reflection D of D corresponds to changing all of the edge signs of G.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: For any tree T^* ∈, define the log map at T^* to be the map from  to the tangent cone at T^* given by log(T;T^*) = d(T^*,T)v(T), where T is any tree in , d(T^*,T) is the BHV distance between T^* and T and v(T) is the unit vector in the direction that the geodesic from T^* to T leaves T^*.

    σ(s,) = ∑_T ∈ |s|_T -  ∑_x ∈ E() ∩ X(s)  ∑_T ∈ |x|_T.

sentence:
To  a graded vector space
 
    M = (M_0,M_1, … ,M_n, …) ,
 we associate
  its Schur functor M : → defined by

    M(V) := ⊕_n≥ 0 M_n ⊗_ V ^⊗
    n .

The Schur functor admits a tensor product and a composition
defined by M⊗ N=M⊗N and M∘ N =M∘N. The tensor product and the composition of Schur
functors can be seen as a Schur functor on  graded vector spaces
denoted by M⊗ N and defined as :

    (M⊗ N)_n := ⊕_i+j=n M(i) ⊗ N(j) ,

and their composite denoted by M∘ N is defined as :

    (M∘ N)_n :=⊕_i_1+⋯+i_k=n M_k ⊗(N_i_1⊗⋯⊗ N_i_k)  .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let 𝒞 denote a (labelled or unlabelled) class that can be
entirely specified, in a possibly recursive way, with the
constructions of Section <ref>, and let 0<x<ρ
be any positive real lying inside the convergence domain for the
generating function of 𝒞. Then, assuming an oracle that
provides values of the relevant generating functions at real values,
the algorithm Γ𝒞 compiled from the specification by
the patterns of Section <ref> terminates with
probability 1 and in finite expected time, outputs a random
𝒞-structure under the Boltzmann distribution with
parameter x, and uses a number of real arithmetic operations that
is linear in the size of the output.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O

sentence:
Let P be a smooth  n-dimensional lattice polytope and
s≥ 1 an integer.  Let m be a vertex of P. Reorder the hyperplanes so
that {m}=∩_i=1^n  H_ρ_i, -a_i. We say that P is  s-spanned at
m if  the lattice point m(s), defined by {m(s)}=∩_i=1^n  H_ρ_i, -a_i+s, lies in
P^(s). We say that P is s-spanned if P is  s-spanned at every
vertex.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O

sentence:
Assume that there is a constant number t of possible player types represented by pairs (A̅^i,B̅^i), i=1,…,t, of fixed matrices A̅^i and B̅^i, i=1,…,t. For i=1,…,N, select one of these pairs (A̅^i,B̅^i), i=1,…,t, as the  type (A^i,B^i) of player i. Finally, let M be a bound for c_j(∑_i=1^N x^i_j) for all j and for all feasible selections of strategies for all players.

  
  (a) Problem (<ref>) can be solved in time polynomial in N, in ⟨ M,^0,^1,…,^N,^1,…,^N⟩, and in the number of calls of evaluation oracles.
  
  (b) Assume that each c_j has the form c_j(y)=λ_j f_j(y) for some fixed convex function f_j:_+→_+ given by evaluation oracles and some λ_j∈_+ that can be adjusted. Then the inverse integer optimization problem corresponding to Problem (<ref>) is solvable in time polynomial in N, in ⟨ M,^*,^0,^1,…,^N,^1,…,^N⟩, and in the number of calls of evaluation oracles.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Twisted prism]
Let P ⊆^d be a polytope and Q {1}× P its
embedding in ^d+1. The twisted prism of P is
(P) (Q ∪ -Q).

sentence:
A line ℓ determined by two points of S is
balanced if the two halfplanes it defines have weight
δ. Observe that this implies that the two points of S
spanning ℓ have different 
colors.

sentence: A graph is a digraph G in which the edge relation E(G) is symmetric.

sentence: [Centred set] A centred set in G is a multiplicative set (A,G) that contains the group identity 1 (thus in particular A^k ⊂ A^k' for k ≤ k') and is also symmetric (thus A^-1 := {a^-1: a ∈ A } is equal to A).

sentence:
[Generalised arithmetic progression]  A (symmetric) generalised arithmetic progression (or progression for short) in an abelian group G = (G,+) is any set P of the form

    P = { n_1 v_1 + … + n_r v_r: n_i ∈, |n_i| ≤ N_i  for all  1 ≤ i ≤ r }

for some v_1,…,v_r ∈ and N_1,…,N_r ≥ 1.  We refer to r as the rank of the progression.  If t ≥ 1, we say that the progression P is t-proper if the sums

    n_1 v_1 + … + n_r v_r

for n_i ∈, |n_i| ≤ tN_i are all distinct.  We say that a progression is proper if it is 1-proper.

sentence:
[Vertices, edges, facets and rows of simplices]
Let A=(a_i)_i∈^n be an infinite array of dimension n of m. Let =(j,ε,s) be the n-simplex of size s of m with principal vertex at position j∈^n in A and with orientation ε∈{-1,1}^n. Let (e_1,e_2,…,e_n) denote the canonical basis of the vector space ^n and let e_0:=0_^n.
The n+1 vertices _0,…,_n of  are defined by _k() := a_j + (s-1)ε· e_k for all k∈[0,n], that are _0() := a_j (principal vertex) and

    _k() := a_j + ε· (s-1)e_k = a_j_1,…,j_k-1,j_k+ε_k(s-1),j_k+1,…,j_n,

for all k∈[1,n]. The n+12 edges _k,l of  are sequences of length s defined by

    _k,l() 
    [                                                           := { a_j + ε· ((s-1-x)e_k + xe_l) | x∈[0,s-1] }; = { a_j + ε· (s-1)e_k) , a_j + ε· ((s-2)e_k + e_l) , a_j + ε· ((s-3)e_k + 2e_l) , … , a_j + ε· (s-1)e_l}, ]

for all distinct integers k,l∈[0,n]. The n+1 facets _0,…,_n of  are the (n-1)-simplices of size s defined by

    _k() := { a_j+ε· l | l∈^n  such that l_k=0 and l_1+⋯+l_n ≤ s-1 },

for all l∈[1,n] and

    _0() := { a_j+ε· l | l∈^n such that l_1+⋯+l_n = s-1 }.

For every k∈[0,s-1], the kth row of  is the (n-1)-simplex of size s-k defined by

    _k() := { a_j+ε· l | l∈^n  such that l_n=k and l_1+⋯+l_n-1≤ s-k-1}.

Let G be a looped simple graph. A pendant-twin reduction of G is a
graph obtained from G in one of the following ways:

  * Delete a twin vertex (adjacent or nonadjacent).


  * Delete a vertex of degree 1.

sentence:
A learning sequence of a set system Ł⊆ P(T) is, by
definition, a possibly infinite sequence 
    ⟨⟨ t_0, A_1⟩, ⟨ t_1,
    A_2⟩ ,…(, ⟨ t_n,
    A_n+1⟩) ⟩
 such that for each i<n
{t_0,…,t_i}⊆ A_i+1∈Ł. In
particular, we call the sequence bad if A_i+1∌t_i+1
for each i. 


We say a set system Ł⊆ P(T) has infinite elasticity ,
provided that 
there are infinite bad learning sequences. Otherwise, we say Ł has an
fe, and call Ł an fess.

Let T be a well-founded tree. For each node σ of T, let the
ordinal number | σ | be the supremum of |σ'| + 1 such that
σ'∈ T is an immediate extension of σ. Then the
order type |T| of the well-founded tree T is defined by the
ordinal number || assigned to the root  of T.
For a tree T which is not well-founded, let |T| be ∞. 

The order type of Ł, denoted by Ł, is, by definition, the
 order type of the tree of bad learning sequences of Ł.

  A smooth Fano polytope P splits into Q and Q' if P is lattice equivalent to Q ⊕ Q'.

 such that:

    on input (≠,≠) iff it behaves like min (max, p_1, p_2) both on input (≺ ,≺ ) and on input (≺,≻ ). We also say that f is of type min (max, p_1, p_2) . If f is of type p_1 or p_2 then we also say that f is of type projection .

sentence:
A cube in ^d will refer to a set of the form

    C = ∏_i=1^d [a_i,a_i + ℓ),

where a = (a_1, a_2, …, a_d) ∈^d and ℓ > 0. The cube C is based at a and has side length C = ℓ. The cube C is centered if it is symmetric about the origin.

sentence:
For α in (0,1], a subset E of  is called
Furstenberg set of type α or F_α-set if
for each direction e in the unit circle there is a line segment
ℓ_e in the direction of e such that the Hausdorff
dimension of the set E∩ℓ_e is greater or equal than
α. We will also say that such set E belongs to the class
F_α.

sentence: A Motzkin path is a path starting at 0 and going rightwards for a number of steps; the steps are either diagonally upwards (+1), straight (0) or diagonally downwards (-1). A Motzkin bridge is a Motzkin path from 0 to 0. A Motzkin excursion is a Motzkin bridge which stays non-negative.

sentence:
Given two edges e,f∈ E(G) and a vertex x∈ V(G), we say that x
(incidently) resolves or distinguishes the pair e,f, if
either x∈ e or x∈ f (exactly one of these two edges is incident with
x). A set S of vertices of G is an incidence generator for G
if for any two different edges e,f∈ E(G) there exists a vertex x∈ S
such that x incidently resolves the pair e,f. An incidence generator
of minimum cardinality is called an incidence basis for G and its
cardinality, the incidence dimension of G, is denoted by dim_I(G).

sentence: Let Ψ =(ψ_1,...,ψ_t) be a system of affine-linear forms. If 1 ≤ i ≤ t and s ≥ 0, we say that Ψ has i-complexity at most s if one can cover the t-1 forms {ψ_j : j ∈ [t]∖{i}} by s+1 classes, such that ψ_i does not lie in the affine-linear span of any of these classes. The complexity of Ψ is defined to be the least s for which the system has i-complexity at most s for all 1 ≤ i ≤ t, or ∞ if no such s exists.

sentence:
Suppose M is a complete _-structure with domain V, N is an ℒ-structure such that dom(N)⊆ V, and χ∈ Ch(M).


  * N is a χ-subpattern of M, denoted N≤_χM, if for every A∈dom(N) r, χ(A)=Diag^N(A).  

  * N is a full χ-subpattern of M , denoted N_χ M, if N≤_χM and dom(N)=V.  

When N_χ M, we say χ chooses N .  We say N is a subpattern of M , denoted N≤_p M, if N≤_χM for some choice function χ for M.  We say N is a full subpattern of M , denoted N_p M, if N_χM for some choice function χ for M.  The subscript in ≤_p and _p is for “pattern.”

sentence:
Given a cluster pattern, we denote

    𝒳
    = ⋃_t ∈𝕋_N𝐱_t
    = { x_i;t :  t ∈𝕋_N , 1≤ i≤ N } ,

the union of clusters from all seeds in the pattern.
The elements x_i;t∈𝒳 are called cluster variables .
The
cluster algebra 𝒜 associated with a
given pattern is the ℙ-subalgebra of the ambient field ℱ
generated by all cluster variables: 𝒜 = ℙ[𝒳].
We denote 𝒜 = 𝒜(𝐱, 𝐲, B), where
(𝐱,𝐲,B)
is any seed in the underlying cluster pattern.

sentence:
Let P ∈(m,n). For 0 ≤ i < j ≤ m+n, we say that the pair (i,j) is a diagonal inversion if a_i(P) is the successor of a_j(P) in the alphabet ℕ. Then we define d_i(P) #{ i < j | (i,j)  is a diagonal inversion}. Finally, we define the statistic dinv on (m,n) as 
    (P) = ∑_i=0^m+n d_i(P).

sentence:

    ϵ_i=
    +  if  (i,i+1,i+2) ∈ζ(π), 
    
    -  if  (i+2,i+1,i) ∈ζ(π).

The cyclic descent class _w is defined to be the set of all cyclic permutations with cyclic descent pattern w.

sentence:
A Dellac configuration of size n is a tableau of width n and height 2n which contains 2n dots between the lines y=x and y=n+x, such that each row contains exactly one dot and each column contains exactly two dots. Let DC(n) be the set of Dellac configurations of size n. An inversion of C ∈ DC(n) is a pair (d_1,d_2) of dots whose Cartesian coordinates in C are respectively (j_1,i_1) and (j_2,i_2) such that j_1 < j_2 and i_1 > i_2. We denote by inv(C) the number of inversions of C. For example, the tableau depicted in Figure <ref> is a Dellac configuration C ∈ DC(3) with inv(C) = 2 inversions (represented by two segments).

 

    < g r a p h i c s >

Dellac configuration C ∈ DC(3) with inv(C) = 2 inversions.

The growth function  of G based at g_0 is the function β→ where β_n is the number of vertices of G at distance at most n from g_0. sentence:
[(n-bounded expansion)]
Let G be a 2-connected c-crossing-critical graph drawn in the plane
with the minimum number of crossings.
Let G' be the planarization of G and let Y denote the set of crossing vertices of G'.
Let c_0=⌈ 5c/2+16⌉.
Assume  is a k-edge-linked shelled (F_1,F_2)-band or proper
(F_1,u)-fan in G' whose support is disjoint from Y.
Let  be a c-typical subband or subfan of  which is reducible with
repetition of order at least 12c_0+2k.
Let the number of vertices of the support of  be at most n,
and let G_1 denote the reduction of G on .
In these circumstances, we say that 
G is an n-bounded expansion of G_1 .

Assume ' is a necklace in G' whose support is disjoint from Y, 
and let '=(v_1,v_2) be a 1-typical subband of ' of length 2.
Let G_2 be obtained from G by replacing the support S of ' by a
parallel edge of multiplicity equal to the maximum number
of pairwise edge-disjoint paths between v_1 and v_2 in S.  
Let the number of vertices of the support of ' be at most n.
In these circumstances, we also say that 
G is an n-bounded expansion of G_1 .

sentence:
[Cups and Caps]
Let m ≥ 3 be a natural number. We say that the points (x_1,y_1),(x_2,y_2),…,(x_m,y_m) form an m-cup if they satisfy the following properties:


  1. x_1 < x_2 < … < x_m;

  2. y_2-y_1/x_2-x_1 < y_3-y_2/x_3-x_2 < … < y_m-y_m-1/x_m-x_m-1.
 
In a similar way, they form an m-cap if we have


  1. x_1 < x_2 < … < x_m;

  2. y_2-y_1/x_2-x_1 > y_3-y_2/x_3-x_2 > … > y_m-y_m-1/x_m-x_m-1.

sentence:
[Convexification function h(m,l)] 
For the natural numbers m,l ≥ 3, define h(m,l) to be the maximum number such that there exists an (m,l)-free set of h(m,l) points in the plane with no (m,l)-convexifying points. The function h(m,l) is called the convexification function .

sentence:
[Canonical s-v labelling] Let w∈_ n be an affine permutation and let a = (a_1, a_2, …, a_k) be a nilHecke word in _n such that S(a) = w. Let w' = S(a') where a' = (a_1, a_2, …, a_k-1). Define a s-v injective labelling T_a:D(w)→ 2^{1,⋯,k} recursively as follows.


  * If a_k is a decent of w', then D(w) = D(w'). Add a label k to the sets T_a'(a_k + rn, w'(a_k + 1) + rn)), r∈.

  * If a_k is not a decent of w', then D(w) is obtained from D(w') by switching the pairs of rows (a_k + rn, a_k + 1 + rn), r∈ and adding a cell (a_k, w(a_k+1)). Label the newly appeared boxes (a_k + rn, w(a_k + 1) + rn), r∈, by a single element set {k}.

We call T_a the canonical s-v labelling of a.

sentence:
[q-sparse and q-dense pairs]
Let q be a positive integer. Let G be a bipartite graph with parts X, Y. Let x,y be two different vertices such that x,y∈ X or x,y∈ Y. 
Then we call {x,y} a q-dense pair of G if N(x,y)≥ q. We call {x,y} a q-sparse pair of G if N(x,y) < q but x,y are still contained in a copy of K_2,q in G. Note that it is possible that {x,y} is neither q-sparse nor q-dense.

sentence:
Let I be a set. For each i∈ I, let E_i be a
set. For each i∈ I, let ρ_i be a binary relation on the set E_i. We shall write the relation ρ_i in infix notation (i.e., we shall
write eρ_if instead of (  e,f)  ∈ρ_i when we want
to say that two elements e and f of E_i are related by ρ). We
define a binary relation ρ on the set _i∈ IE_i (again,
written in infix notation) by the rule

    (
    [             (  (  j,e)  ρ(  k,f)  )
     ⟺ (  j=k and eρ_jf); for any two elements (  j,e)   and
    (  k,f)   of _i∈ IE_i ])  .

This relation ρ will be denoted by ⊕_i∈ Iρ_i and
called the direct sum of the relations ρ_i.

sentence:
Let V = {v_1,…,v_n} be a finite set. A simplicial complex Δ on V is a collection of subsets of V such that F ∈Δ whenever F ⊂ G for some G ∈Δ, and such that {v_i}∈Δ for i=1,…,n.

The elements of Δ are called faces . The dimension of a face F , dimF, is the number F -1. The dimension of Δ is 
    dimΔ=max{dimF : F∈Δ}.
 The maximal faces under inclusion are called the facets of the simplicial complex. The set of facets is denoted by (Δ). A subcomplex Γ of Δ is called a subcomplex of maximal dimension ( SMD for short) if (Γ)⊂ (Δ).

sentence:
Let Δ be a simplicial complex. A face F ∈ (Δ) is called a leaf of Δ iff there exists G ∈ (Δ) such that (H∩ F) ⊂ (G ∩ F) for all H ∈ (Δ). A face G with the above property is called a  branch of F .

Furthermore Δ is called a quasi-forest if there exists a total order (Δ)={F_1,…,F_m} such that F_i is a leaf of Γ, where  Γ is the SMD  with (Γ)={F_1,…,F_i} for all i=1,…,m. This order is called a leaf order of the quasi-forest. A connected quasi-forest is called a quasi-tree .

sentence:
Given a graph G, a subset 𝒞 of V(G) is an identifying code of G if 
𝒞 is both:


  * a dominating set of G, i.e. for each vertex v∈ V(G), N[v]∩𝒞≠∅, and

  * a separating set of G, i.e. for each pair u, v ∈ V(G) (u≠ v), N[u]∩𝒞≠
N[v]∩𝒞.

sentence:
Suppose 𝐚 and 𝐛 are two atomic probability measures on
X as in (<ref>), (<ref>) and (<ref>).
A transport plan from 𝐚 to 𝐛 is an atomic
probability measure

    q=∑_i=1^k∑_j=1^ℓq_ijδ _( x_i,y_j)

on the product space X× X such that for each i and j, q_ij≥
0,

    ∑_i=1^kq_ij=n_j and ∑_j=1^ℓq_ij=m_i.

Denote Plan( 𝐚,𝐛) as the space of all
transport plans from 𝐚 to 𝐛.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For p,q,s,k≥ 1, with p,q,s of the same odd-even
parity, we define ^(s)_p,q,k to be the set of arrays of
cells, arranged in k columns and 2 rows, subject to the following conditions:


  * Each cell contains an ordered list of vertices, so that there is a total
of p vertices in the first row, and q vertices in the second row.  The vertices
are paired (in the language of graph theory, there is a perfect matching on the vertices),
so that s pairs join a vertex in the first row to a vertex in the second row (these
are the mixed pairs ). The number of mixed pairs containing a vertex in
column i of row 1 is equal to the number of mixed pairs containing a vertex in
column i of row 2, for all i=1, ,k (this is called the balance condition).

  * There is at least one marked (with a small box) cell in row 1, and we denote the
set of such columns by R. There
is at least one marked (with a small box) cell in row 2, and we denote the
set of such columns by R'.
There is at least one vertex in every column that is not
contained in R∪ R' (this is called the nonempty condition).

  * Denote the set of columns in which there is at least one vertex in
row 1 by D,
and the set of columns in which there is at least one vertex in 
row 2 by D'. Define the function ψ:D∖ R→ D as
follows: if the rightmost vertex in column i of row 1 is paired
with a vertex in column j, then ψ(i)=j. Similarly,
define  ψ':D'∖ R'→ D' as
follows: if the rightmost vertex in column i of row 2 is paired
with a vertex in column j, then ψ'(i)=j. The functional digraph
of ψ is a forest with |R| components (called the rightmost forest
for row 1); each component is
a tree in which all edges are directed towards an element of R (and this
is called the root of that tree).
The functional digraph
of ψ' is a forest with |R'| components (called the rightmost forest
for row 2); each component is
a tree in which all edges are directed towards an element of R' (and this
is called the root of that tree). Together, these specify 
the forest condition. 

The elements of ^(s)_p,q,k are called paired arrays .
A paired array is defined to be canonical if |R|=|R'|=1.
Define ^(s)_p,q,k to be the set of canonical
paired arrays in ^(s)_p,q,k, and c^(s)_p,q,k=|^(s)_p,q,k|.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let  be a field and n∈. The graded lexicographic order (abbreviated grlex ) with y_1>…>y_n is defined as follows. We have y^α>y^β if


  * |α|>|β|, or

sentence:
[c.f. <cit.>]


Fix coprime s,t≥1. Let H_s,t be the subgroup of G_s,t consisting of f∈ G_s,t such that f(-1-m) = -1-f(m) for all m∈ (based on the involution m↦ -1-m).

It is easy to check that H_s,t has a group structure, and that it acts in the obvious way on the set of symmetric s-sets S_s(λ), or equivalently suitable beta-sets. This induces an action on D_s, via Corollary <ref>.

sentence: Let T=(G,S,L) be a canvas. Let P=p_1p_2p_3 be a neighboring 2-path of S such that for each i∈{1,2,3}, p_i has a unique neighbor u_i in S. Let H=G∪ P ∪{p_1u_1,p_2u_2,p_3u_3}. We say T/H is obtained from T by relaxing P and that T/H is a relaxation of T. We define T to be a 0-relaxation of itself. For k≥ 1, we say a supercanvas T' of T is a k-relaxation of T if T' is a relaxation of a (k-1)-relaxation of T.

sentence:
[Kantorovich duality]
Let G = (V,E) be a locally finite graph. Let μ_1,μ_2 be two probability measures on V. Then

    W_1(μ_1,μ_2)=sup_ϕ:V→ℝ
    ϕ∈1– Lip∑_x∈ Vϕ(x)(μ_1(x)-μ_2(x)).





If ϕ∈1–Lip attains the supremum we call it an optimal Kantorovich potential transporting μ_1 to μ_2.

sentence:
An oblivious tester for a property ={_n}_n is a (possibly 2-sided error) non-adaptive, probabilistic algorithm, which, given a distance parameter ϵ,
and oracle access to an input function f:^n_2 →{0,1}, performs the following steps:


  * Computes an integer d = d().  If d() > n, let H = _2^n.  Otherwise, let H
  ≤_2^n be a subspace of dimension  d() chosen uniformly at random.


  * Queries f on all elements x ∈ H.

  * Accepts or rejects based only on the outcomes of the received answers, the value of ,
  and its internal randomness.

We will say that a polytope B in ^d is generic if
there exists a sequence of faces F_1 ⊆ F_3 ⊆…⊆ F_d-1 of B such that F_j is a face of dimension j,

sentence:
[ Floor diagram of a plane tropical curve ]
A floor of a plane tropical curve h:C→^2 
is a connected component (in C) 
of the union of all edges which are not elevators. 
The floor diagram of h is an oriented weighted
graph (h) obtained from C by removing 
(the interiors of) all unbounded edges, 
collapsing each floor to a single vertex,
orienting all remaining edges 
(which correspond to bounded elevators) downwards,
and keeping their weights. 
Thus, the vertices of (h) correspond to the floors, and
the edges to the bounded elevators (directed downwards).

sentence:
[ A bijection between labeled floor diagrams and
   labeled trees ]

Suppose we have already defined such bijections for labeled floor
diagrams of genus 0 and any degree <d.
Now, for a diagram  of degree d, do the following.
Decompose  into the root vertex d and
subdiagrams _1,…,_k on vertex sets S_1,…,S_k, as
described in the proof of Theorem <ref> above.
Let T_1,…,T_k denote the trees on vertex sets S_1,…,S_k
that correspond to _1,…,_k, respectively,
under the appropriate bijections.
The tree T associated to  under the bijection in question is
constructed by connecting each tree T_i to the root vertex d by a single
edge e' that is going to be determined by the unique weighted edge
ve⟶d
connecting _i to d in .
It remains to describe the rule that determines e' from e.
We have already checked (see (<ref>)) that the total number
of choices for e is equal to |S_i|.
Let us record those choices in an ordered list as the vertex v moves left
to right within _i; for a given v, we record the choices
starting with the largest possible weight value w(e)=1-_i(v) and
decreasing it until we reach the smallest possible weight value
w(e)=1.
We similarly list the |S_i| choices available for the
edge v'e'⟶d connecting S_i to d ;
the ordering is determined by the (left-to-right) ordering of the
vertices v'∈ S_i.
We finally match the choices on both lists in the order they are
listed.

sentence:
Fix σ⊂ [n] and a
binomial ideal I ⊂[^n]. Set
I_σ=(I:(∏_i∈σx_i)^∞).


  * A weak monomial I-witness for
_σ^c is a monomial x^w ∈[^σ^c], x^w
∉ I, such that there exists
x^m ∈[^σ] with the property that for each i ∉σ, there are
a monomial x^q_i and a scalar λ_i ∈^* such
that x_i (x^m x^w - λ_i x^q_i) ∈ I_σ but x^mx^w
-λ_i x^q_i∉ I_σ.  

  * A weak monomial I-witness x^w for _σ^c is
essential if there is a
polynomial p ∈[^n],
p∉ I_σ, and a
monomial x^v ∈[^σ] such that x^vx^w is a monomial in
p, and
x_j p ∈ I_σ for
all j ∉σ.

        (actually, Jacob E. Goodman) as a Monthly
        problem <cit.> (and was also studied by Gates <cit.>).

sentence:
Let S=S_I denote the polynomial ring [Y_w : w∈(I)], with a variable Y_w for each generator w of I.  The toric map is the map ϕ: S → R given by 

    ϕ(Y_w)=w,

and extended algebraically.  (Here and throughout, we allow for a free re-indexing of the w_i to avoid unwieldy double subscripts.) The toric ideal of I, which we write T(I), is the kernel of ϕ.  The toric ring of I, denoted [I], is the quotient S_I/T(I) (naturally isomorphic to the image of ϕ, which is a subring of R).

sentence:
The Rees algebra of I is the R-subalgebra
  
    ℛ_I=R⊕ It ⊕ I^2t^2⊕…⊂ R[t].


  More carefully, let ℛ denote the polynomial ring [x_1,…, x_n][Y_w : w∈(I)], with a new variable Y_w for each generator w of I.  The Rees map is the R-algebra map ρ: ℛ→ R[t] given by 

    ρ(Y_w)=wt,

and extended algebraically.  (As with the toric ideal, we allow for a free re-indexing of the w_i to avoid unwieldy double subscripts.) The Rees ideal of I, which we write ℛ(I), is the kernel of ρ.  The Rees algebra of I, denoted ℛ_I, is the quotient ℛ_I=ℛ/ℛ(I) (naturally isomorphic to the image of ρ, which is a subring of R[t]).

such that ϕ maps edges to edges and non-edges to non-edges. A graph is vertex transitive if for every x,y ∈ V(G) there exists an automorphism of G mapping x to y.

sentence: A circular ladder graph is a graph isomorphic to the Cayley graph (_n×_2,{(0,1),(1,0),(-1,0)}) for some n≥ 3. A Möbius ladder graph is a graph  isomorphic to the Cayley graph (_2n,{1,-1,n}) for some n≥ 2 (note that we consider the complete graph on 4 vertices to be a Möbius ladder).

lattice directions.

for all f ∈ℱ: P_D(f) · c = 0, where ·
denotes the vector inner product.

Let G be a graph.  We say two disjoint edges uv and xy form a gap in G if G does not have an edge with one 
endpoint in {u,v} and the other in {x,y}.
A graph without gaps is called gap-free .  Equivalently, G is gap-free if and only if G^c contains no induced C_4.

w_5} and set of edges {w_1w_3,w_2w_3,w_3w_4,w_3w_5,w_4w_5} is called a cricket.

Let 𝒜  be an alphabet and G be the set of all involutory antimorphisms on ^*. Let Δ = δ_1 δ_2 … and Θ = ϑ_1 ϑ_2 …, where δ_i ∈ and ϑ_i ∈ G for all i ∈. The infinite generalized pseudostandard word  is the word whose prefixes w_n are obtained from the recurrence relation
		
    w_n+1   = (w_n δ_n+1)^ϑ_n+1,
    
    			w_0    = ε.

		The sequence  is called the directive bi-sequence of the word .

sentence:
A decreasing hook word is a colored word  v such that v^ is decreasing, i.e. v = x_1 x_2 ⋯ x_k x_k+1⋯x_n  and x_1 > x_2 > ⋯ > x_k and x_k+1≤…≤x_n.  A decreasing hook subword of a colored word  w is a subword of  w that is a decreasing hook word.
For a colored word  w, let τ(w) be the maximum possible length of a decreasing hook subword of w.

Given a colored word w, set t := τ(w) and let η be smallest letter of w (for  <) such that _≤η(w) has a decreasing hook subword of length  t (see Proposition <ref>, below, for a way to compute these values).
We say that a  decreasing hook subword of  w is a special subword if it has length  t and uses letters ≤η.  See Example <ref>.

       = _A(π,)∪{j-1: j∈((π,)^-1)∖{1}}  .

    Let C,L ∈n,d with C weakly above L and mark east steps

sentence:
Given G=(V,E), a set A_0⊆ V is called contagious if ⟨ A_0 ⟩=V. In words, activating A_0 results with the entire graph being activated.
The minimal cardinality of a contagious set is denoted by m(G,r). For a contagious set A_0, the number of generations is the minimal integer t with ⋃_i ≤ tA_i=V.

sentence:
A commutator form of weight n on the letters x_1,…,x_r will be a function from {x_1,…,x_r}^n to the set of formal commutators in the x_i, defined recursively as follows. The identity function ι given by ι(x_i):=x_i is the unique commutator form of weight 1. The commutator forms of weight n will consist of all functions γ for which there exist commutator forms γ_1,γ_2 with respective weights m_1,m_2 summing to n, and a permutation σ∈ S_n, such that

    γ(x_i_1,…,x_i_n)=[γ_1(x_i_σ(1),…,x_i_σ(m_1)),γ_2(x_i_σ(m_1+1),…,x_i_σ(n))]

for all i_j∈[1,r]. We will denote by |χ(γ)| the weight of a commutator form γ.

  * S is left amenable if the space of bounded, real-valued functions on S with the supremum norm admits a left translation invariant mean , that is, a positive linear functional λ of norm 1 which is left translation invariant: for all bounded f: S →ℝ and all s ∈ S, λ( x ↦ f(s x) ) = λ ( f ). When regarding means as finitely additive measures, we abuse notation slightly by writing λ(A) instead of λ(_A), where _A is the indicator function of A, for subsets A ⊆ S.

  *  The upper Banach density of A ⊆ S is

    d^*(A) = sup{λ(A)  |  λ a left translation invariant mean on }.


We denote by  the class of subsets of  of positive upper Banach density. (With the convention that the supremum of the empty set is -∞, the class  is non-empty if and only if  is left amenable.)

sentence: Fix δ≥ 1.  A graph G with minimum degree δ is edge-critical if for any edge e in G, the minimum degree of G - e is δ - 1. It is vertex-critical if for any vertex v in G, the minimum degree of G - v is strictly smaller than δ. If it is both edge- and vertex-critical, we say that G is critical.

Let d be max{c',4√(c_+/π),1/4√(c_-/π),1}, (where c_+ and c_- are the constants from Lemma <ref>, and c' is the constant given by Proposition <ref>).

Given four points, a, b, x_l and x_r in S_n, we define ρ=‖ ab‖ and, writing D^l_x(y) and D^r_x(y) for the left and right half-disks of radius y centred on x, we define the regions:


  * C=(D^l_x_l(ρ)∪ D^r_x_r(ρ))∩ S_n,

  * A=(D_a(ρ)∖(D_b(ρ)∪ C))∩ S_n, and

  * B=(D_b(ρ)∖(D_a(ρ)∪ C))∩ S_n.

See Figure <ref> for an illustration of these regions.

We say that a, b, x_l and x_r form a component set-up if:


  * The points b, x_l and x_r are all within d√(log n) of a,

  * #C=0,

  * and at least one of #A≥ k and #B≥ k holds.

sentence:
Let G be a SCCG . 


  * The connection set, 𝒲, of G is the set of vertices that belong to at least two simplicial cliques of G.

  * For an independent set I_m ⊂𝒲, S(I_m) is the set of all simplicial cliques that are not contained in the closed neighborhood of I_m and s_m:=|S(I_m)|.

  * S(I_m) is the complement of S(I_m) in 𝒞(G).

  *  For eachC_i∈𝒞(G),W_i:=C_i∩𝒲.

sentence:
Let G_1 and G_2 be sugraphs of a graph 𝒢 such that 𝒞(G_1) and 𝒞(G_2) are non-empty. We say that 𝒢 is the simplicial clique sum ( SCS ) of G_1 and G_2 if


  * V(G_1) ∪ V(G_2)=V(𝒢),

  * E(G_1) ∪ E(G_2)=E(𝒢), and

  * V(G_1) ∩ V(G_2) is a simplicial clique of G_1, G_2 and 𝒢.

sentence:
Let G = (V,E) be a graph.


  * A walk in G is an alternating sequence of vertices and edges

    u_1, e_1, u_2, e_2, …, e_m-1, u_m,

in which e_i = {u_i, u_i+1}. In a simple graph, specifying an edge is the same as specifying its vertices. Thus, we shall omit the edges in u_1, e_1, …, e_m-1, u_m and use u_1, …, u_m to denote such a walk.

  * A path is a simple walk; that is, a walk in which each vertex appears exactly once (except possibly the first and the last vertices).

  * A circuit is a closed walk, i.e., a walk u_1, …, u_m, where u_1 ≡ u_m.

  * A cycle is a closed path. A cycle consisting of n distinct vertices is called an n-cycle. When listing the vertices of a cycle, the last vertex (which is the same as the first one) is often omitted from the sequence.

  * A Hamiltonian path of G is a path that goes through each vertex of G exactly once.

  * A Hamiltonian cycle of G is a cycle that contains all the vertices of G (each appears exactly once). A graph containing a Hamiltonian cycle is called a Hamiltonian graph .

sentence: A hypergraph , H, is an ordered pair, (V,E), where V is a set of vertices and E is a set of subsets of V.  A hyperedge of H is an element of E.  A hypergraph is said to be uniform of rank k , or k-uniform , if all of its hyperedges have size k.  A k-uniform hypergraph is complete if every subset of size k of V is a hyperedge of H.

sentence: For a set F of cycles, we define the underlying graph of H by |H|:=⋃ H⊆ G. A set F of cycles is closed if for each edge e of |F| there are exactly two induced cycles C_1,C_2∈ F that use the edge e. If G=(V,E) is a graph, then a set of cycles F is closed in C(G) if F⊆ C(G) and it is closed. A subgraph S of G=(V,E) is called a closed surface in G if S=|F| for some closed subset F of C(G). In that case, we call F a face set of S .

sentence:
[Rank and analytic rank]  Let s ≥ 0 be an integer, and let P ∈_≤ s+1(V →).


  * The rank (P)= _s(P) of P is the least number m of polynomials Q_1,…,Q_m ∈_≤ s(V →) of degree ≤ s such that P is a function of Q_1,…,Q_m, i.e. there exists a function F: ^m → such that P = F(Q_1,…,Q_m).  (We adopt the convention that _0(P) is infinite if the linear polynomial P is non-constant.)  

  * The analytic rank (P) = _s(P) of P is defined to be the quantity (P) := -log_p e(P)_U^s+1(V)^1/2^s+1.

We define the rank and analytic rank of polynomials P ∈_≤ s+1(V →) by using the homomorphism ι_*, thus for instance (P) := (ι_* P).  (In particular, when defining the rank of a classical polynomial P, we allow for P to be represented by non-classical polynomials Q_1,…,Q_m of the required degree.)
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O

sentence:
[Regular factor]  Let V be a limit finite-dimensional vector space.  A factor is a bounded family P = (P_i,j)_1 ≤ i ≤ m; 0 ≤ j ≤ J_i of polynomials P_i,j∈_≤ D_i+j(p-1)(V →), where m ≥ 0 and J_1,…,J_m ≥ 0 and D_1,…,D_m ≥ 2 are standard natural numbers, obeying the relations

    p P_i,j = P_i,j-1

for all 1 ≤ i ≤ m and 0 ≤ j ≤ J_i (with the convention P_i,-1 = 0).  In particular, each P_i,j takes values in the (p^j+1)^þ roots of unity 1/p^j+1 /.  We refer to m as the dimension of the factor, D_1,…,D_m as the initial degrees , and J_1,…,J_m as the depths .  The degree of the factor is the quantity sup_1 ≤ i ≤ m D_i + J_i(p-1).

A depth extension of P is a factor of the form P' = (P_i,j)_1 ≤ i ≤ m; 0 ≤ j ≤ J'_i, where J'_i ≥ J_i for each 1 ≤ i ≤ m, and the polynomials P_i,j in P' agree with their counterparts in P for j ≤ J_i.
If P' is a depth extension of P, we call P a depth retraction of P'.  If d is a standard integer, we define the degree ≤ d depth retraction P_≤ d of P to be the retraction formed by deleting all P_i,j with D_i + J_i(p-1) > d.

If, for every standard integer k ≥ 2, the polynomials P_i,j with D_i + j(p-1) = k are linearly independent in _≤ k(V →) modulo _≤ k,(V →), we say that the factor P is regular .

A function Q: V → is said to be measurable with respect to the factor P if one has Q = F( P_1,J_1,…,P_m,J_m ) for some function F: ^m →.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
(Smoothing) Let γ, γ_1 and γ_2 be generalized  
arcs or closed loops such that we have
one of the following two cases:


 
  * γ_1 crosses γ_2 at a point x,
  
  * γ has a self-crossing at a point x.


Then we let C be the multicurve {γ_1,γ_2} or {γ} depending on which of the two cases we are in.  We define the smoothing of C at the point x to be the pair of multicurves C_+ = {α_1,α_2} (resp. {α}) and C_- = {β_1,β_2} (resp. {β}).

Here, the multicurve C_+ (resp. C_-) is the same as C except for the local change that replaces the crossing × with the pair of segments _∩^∪
(resp. ⊃⊂).

sentence:
A triple of type A is an arrangement of boxes, a, b, c,
located such that a is immediately to the left of b, and c is somewhere below b,
and the row containing a and b is at least as long as the row containing c.

Similarly, a triple of type B is an arrangement of boxes, a, b, c,
located such that a is immediately to the left of b, and c is somewhere above a,
and the row containing a and b is strictly longer than the row containing c.


A type A triple is an inversion triple if the entries ordered increasingly,
form a counter-clockwise orientation. Similarly, a type B triple is an inversion triple
if the entries ordered increasingly form a clockwise orientation.
If two entries are equal, the one with largest subscript in <ref>
is considered largest.

    Type A:  centertableaux,boxsize=1.2em
     a_3     b_1 
       [⋮] 
        c_2 
        Type B:  centertableaux,boxsize=1.2em
    c_2    
    [⋮]     
    
    a_3     b_1

sentence:
Let S be a numerical semigroup of genus g.  The effective generators of S are the elements of its minimal generating set that are larger than F(S).  The number of effective generators of S is called the efficacy of S, denoted h(S).

The children of a numerical semigroup S of genus g are the numerical semigroups of genus g+1 that come from removing an effective generator from S.  The number of children of S is h(S).

sentence:
A map with n vertices M is a graph M embedded on a
  (usually oriented) surface  so that every connected component of
  ∖ M is a topological disk. The connected components of
  ∖ M are called the faces of M. If 
  is the oriented sphere, then the map M is planar . As each face must
  be a disk, maps' underlying graphs are necessarily connected.

  A map M is 4-regular , 4-valent , or quartic if every
  vertex in the underlying graph M has degree 4.

sentence:
For an odd r and r':=(r+1)/2, let P={p_1,…,p_r'} and
Q={q_0,…,q_r'} consist of elements of [n] such that
q_0<p_1<q_1<p_2< …<p_r'<q_r', and let X⊆[n]-(P∪ Q).
Define the set of neighbors (or “witnesses”) of P,Q to be
   

    =(P,Q):={S⊂ P∪ Q   S P,Q,  r'≤ |S|≤ r'+1}.

  
Suppose that a weakly r-separated collection ⊂ 2^[n] contains
a set U∈{X∪ P, X∪ Q}. If, in addition,  contains the sets
of the form X∪ S for all S∈, then the collection obtained from
 by replacing U by the other member U' of {X∪ P,  X∪ Q}
is weakly r-separated as well.

sentence:
Choose M≥ N positive integers.
Let  be an ambient field
of rational functions
in N independent
variables
over
(x_N+1,…,x_M).
A labeled seed in  is
a pair (, Q), where
= (x_1, …, x_M) forms a free generating
set for
,
and
Q is a quiver on vertices
1, 2, …,N, N+1, …, M,
whose vertices 1,2, …, N are
mutable , and whose vertices N+1,…, M are frozen .

We refer to  as the (labeled)
extended cluster of a labeled seed (, Q).
The variables {x_1,…,x_N} are called cluster
variables , and the variables c={x_N+1,…,x_M} are called
frozen or coefficient variables .
We often view the labeled seed as a quiver Q where each vertex i is labeled by 
the corresponding variable x_i.

sentence:
Let X-Y be an alphabet defined as the difference of two positive alphabets.

 


A signed tableau T of shape λ is a filling of the diagram of λ with entries in X-Y such that the entries
are weakly increasing in the rows and columns, and 


  * Positive letters are strictly increasing on the columns.

  * Negative letters are strictly increasing on the rows.
 


The weight of a letter depends on its sign. 
Let a be  a positive letter, then a has  weight   x_a, and  the corresponding negative letter -a has weight  -y_a. The weight 
of a signed tableaux is defined as usual.

We denote by T_+ be the subtableau of T  positive letters, and by T_- the subtableau of the negative ones.

    X_G( x,t) = ∑_κ∈κ(G) t^(κ) x_κ.

The cluster algebra (B̃) = (B̃,𝐱) is the -subalgebra of  generated by the cluster variables. Its ring of coefficients is . We say that the cluster algebra (B̃) has principal coefficients at the vertex t_0 if the complementary part of B̃_t_0 (the bottom n× n submatrix) is the n× n identity matrix.

* The genericisation of a sentence involving
the terms t_i(A) for various sets A and integers i,
along an element b∈ E, is the sentence obtained
by replacing any term t_i(Ab) whose set contains b with the term t_i+1(A).

is the sentence obtained
by replacing any term t_i(Ab) whose set contains b with the term t_i(A).

sentence:
* A vector p = (p_A) of elements of ± R∪{∞}
indexed by all subsets A⊆ E
is a tropical flag Plücker vector if,
for all sets A,B⊆[n] with |A|≥|B|+2,

    min_a∈ A∖ Bp_A∖ a+p_B∪ a,

and moreover, for each 0≤ r≤ n, there is at least one
set A of cardinality r such that p_A≠∞.


  * If p is indexed only by the subsets of E of cardinality r,
satisfies these relations when |A|-1=|B|+1=r,
and not all entries of p are ∞,
we call it a tropical Plücker vector (of rank r) .

Every tropical Plücker vector is a projection p_r
of some tropical flag Plücker vector p to the coordinates indexed by size-r sets.
