of Theorem <ref> holds and
let k, ℓ>0 be integers.


  (i)
There exists
a function β=β(k,ℓ) with -14≤β≤ 2^7, for which

    C(k,k+ℓ)
    =2^-4 3^1/2 g      k^k+3ℓ/2-1/2(γ^2e^3/2/3^3/2)^ℓ ℓ^-3ℓ/2-3
       ×exp(β√(ℓ ^3/k)
    +O(ℓ^2/k)+O(1/ℓ)).



  (ii) The number C^conn(k,k+ℓ)
of labeled connected complex planar graphs
with k vertices and k+ℓ edges is given by  a similar
formula, with g replaced by g_c.


  (iii) A graph chosen uniformly at random among all complex planar
 graphs with k vertices and k+ℓ edges has deficiency
 Θ(√(ℓ^3/k)) and the core of size
(1+O(√(ℓ/k))+O(1/√(ℓ)))√(3kℓ).
In particular, if ℓ=o(k^1/3),
then such a random graph is clean.


  (iv) If ℓ=O(k^1/3), then  a graph chosen uniformly at
 random among all complex planar graphs with k vertices and k+ℓ
 edges has O(1) components, among which there is a
 giant component of size  k-O(k/ℓ). Furthermore, each  small component has Θ(k/ℓ) vertices and
the probability that such a graph contains exactly h such components
is bounded away from both 0 and 1 for every h=0,1,….

sentence:
Let Π be a finite set of points in ^2, 
and let Γ be a finite multiset of curves in ^2, which can coincide or overlap.
We say that the system (Π,Γ) has (λ,μ)-bounded multiplicity 
if [In both (a) and (b) the curves should be counted with their multiplicity.]
 
(a) for any curve γ∈Γ,
there are at most λ other curves γ'∈Γ such that 
|γ∩γ'|>μ; and

(b) for any point p∈Π, 
there are at most λ other points p'∈Π such that there are more than μ curves that contain both p and p'.

    |π(A)-ν(A)|≤ 1.

A graph G is inertia-balanced
 if there is an inertia-balanced A∈(G) with A=(G).
A graph G is Hermitian inertia-balanced
 if there is an inertia-balanced A∈(G) with A=(G).

sentence:
Subdivision vertex-edge neighbourhood edge-corona (short
for SVEE-corona) of G_1 with G_2 and G_3, denoted by
G_1^S(G_2^V∪ G_3^E), is the graph consisting of
S(G_1), |V(G_1)| copies of G_2 and |I(G_1)| copies of G_3,
all vertex-disjoint, joining the neighbours of the i-th
vertex of I(G_1) to every vertex in the i-th copy of
G_2 and i-th vertex of V(G_1) to each vertex in the
i-th copy of G_3.

sentence:
A set S of weighted trees is relevant if there is an efficient
algorithm that computes, for each weighted tree (T, w), a weighted tree
(T',w')∈ S so that whenever (T_1, w_1) and (T_2, w_2) are weighted
trees, (T_1, w_1) is isomorphic to (T_2, w_2) if and only if (T'_1,
w'_1) is isomorphic to (T'_2,w'_2).
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Weak separation rule]
Subsets I and J are weakly separated if at least one of the following holds:

  
  * |I| ≥ |J| and J-I can be partitioned into a disjoint union J-I = J' ⊔ J” so that J' ≺ I-J ≺ J”,
  
  * |I| ≤ |J| and I-J can be partitioned into a disjoint union I-J = I' ⊔ I” so that I' ≺ J-I < I”.

sentence:
[<cit.>] 
Let Q be a finite quiver without oriented cycles with
vertex set {1, …, n}.


  a) There is an explicit bijection L ↦ X_L from the set
of isomorphism classes of rigid indecomposables of the cluster category _Q
onto the set of cluster variables of the cluster algebra _Q.

  b) Under this bijection, the clusters correspond exactly to
the cluster-tilting subsets , i.e. the sets T_1, …, T_n
of rigid indecomposables such that

    Ext^1(T_i,T_j)=0

for all i,j.

  c) If L and M are rigid indecomposables such that the
space ^1(L,M) is one-dimensional, then we have the generalized
exchange relation

    X_L = X_B + X_B'/X_M

where B and B' are the middle terms of `the' non split triangles

    L [r]     B [r]     M [r]    Σ LM [r]     B' [r]     L [r]    Σ M

and we define

    X_B= ∏_i=1^s X_B_i

where B=B_1 ⊕⋯⊕ B_s is a decomposition into
indecomposables.

sentence:
Given a matroid M=([n],), the (basis) matroid polytope Γ_M of M is the convex hull of the indicator vectors of the bases of M:

    Γ_M := {e_B | B ∈}⊂^n,

where e_B := ∑_i ∈ B e_i, and {e_1, …, e_n} is the standard basis of ^n.

sentence:
If = (E,χ) is an oriented matroid, 
its underlying matroid  is the (unoriented) matroid 
:=(E,) whose bases  are precisely the sets {b_1,…,b_d} such that 
χ(b_1,…,b_d) is nonzero.

sentence:
Let  be an n-magma, where n = (n_1, , n_k). A norm is a map ·: →ℕ that satisfies the super-additive conditions:

    
  * All unary maps f_i: → must satisfy
    
    f_i(m) > m .

 

  * All   maps f_i: ^n_i→, n_i>1, must satisfy

    f_i(m_1, , m_n_i)≥∑_j = 1^n_im_j .



If  has a norm, then it will be called a normed n-magma.

sentence:
The span of a n-step SAW is the difference between the smallest and biggest x-axis coordinate of points, which are part of the walk:

    max_0 ≤ i ≤ nx_i-min_0 ≤ i ≤ nx_i.

The number of n-step half-space walks (respectively bridges) starting at the origin (0,0) and having span A is denoted by h_[-1,1]n,A (respectively b_[-1,1]n,A).

    B_1^*({𝐱, 𝐱_1}) ∩{𝐲, 𝐲_1}≠∅.

triples(A) includes a triple (r,i,j) such that X_i ∈ Span(P_r) and, if j>0), 
X_j ∈ Span(P_r).

sentence:
Suppose that prime P belongs to Independent Ancestor Set A.
We say that prime P is Independent if Span(P) in triples(A) is maximal and closed, Span(P)≠ A, and 
P does not belong to the span of its complement in A.

sentence:
Consider a permutation π∈_n.  
If 0 and n appear in the same cycle of C_π, say as (0  ⋯ n  b_1  b_2  ⋯ b_r), then strategic pile of π, denoted (π), is the set {b_1,b_2, …, b_r}. If 0 and n do not appear in the same cycle of C_π, set (π) = ∅.

sentence:
A read-once function f is linear read-once ( lro )
if it is either a constant function, or it can be represented by a nested formula
defined recursively as follows:

	
  * both literals x and x are nested formulas;
	
  * x  t, x  t, x t, x t are nested formulas,
	where x is a variable and t is a nested formula that contains neither x, nor x.

sentence:
A Thue system is an ordered pair (Σ, R), where Σ is an ordered alphabet[Although unnecessary in this definition, the alphabet is assumed to be ordered out of convenience and compatibility with the next definition.] and ∅≠ R⊆{ (y,y') | y,y' ∈Σ^*  and  y≠ y' }. 
Each element (y,y') of R is associated with two rewriting rules of the Thue system, 
which are suggestively denoted by y→ y' and y'→ y. 
Suppose w,w'∈Σ^*. We say that w transforms directly into w', denoted w→_R w', using the rewriting rule y→ y' iff 

    w=xyz   and  w'=xy'z  for some  x,z ∈Σ^*.
 
We say w transforms into w', denoted w⇒_R w', iff 
there exist w_0,w_1, …,w_n∈Σ^* such that

    w=w_0 →_R w_1 →_R w_2 →_R …→_R w_n=w'.

By definition, w ⇒_R w for every w∈Σ^*.

sentence:
A k-boundaried graph is a pair 𝐆=(G,x̅) where G is a graph and x̅=(x_1,…,x_k) is a k-tuple of the graph's boundary vertices (ordered, not necessarily distinct).
	The extension of 𝐆 is the graph G^* obtained from G by adding k new vertices x_1',…,x_k' and edges x_1 x_1', …, x_k x_k'.
	The join 𝐀⊕𝐁 of two k-boundaried graphs  𝐀 = (A, x̅), 𝐁=(B,y̅) is the graph obtained from the disjoint union of A and B by adding an edge x_i y_i for  i∈[k].

sentence:
The Lipschitz constant of G is given by 
    δ(G)=max{|f_i(a_i,a_-i')-f_i(a_i,a_-i”)|},

where the maximum ranges over all players i, all strategies a_i∈ A_i and all pairs a_-i',a_-i” of opponents' strategy profiles such that ρ(a_-i',a_-i”)=1.

saturating if any point of Π _q∖ S is
collinear with two points in S.

sentence:
The G-vertex-transitive graph Γ=(G,H,HSH) is called a GI-graph (`GI' stands for `Group automorphism inducing Isomorphism')
of G if for any graph Σ=(G,H,HTH) with T⊆ G∖ H and Γ≅Σ, there exists
τ∈(G) such that H^τ=H and HS^τ H=HTH.
A group G is called a DGI-group (`D' emphasizes that our graph may be Directed) if each G-vertex-transitive graph is a GI-graph of G.
A group G is called a GI-group if each undirected G-vertex-transitive graph is a GI-graph of G.

whith 4g-2 vertices of degree 3 and 6g-3 edges.

sentence:
Let 𝔱 be a tree and W be a subset of the vertices of
𝔱. We say that W is non-singular if its skeleton 𝔰(W) has
only vertices of degree 1 and 3, and if all the elements of W have
degree 1 in 𝔰(W).

sentence:
Let (𝔱,c_*) be a tree with g triples. For all i let
c_i={v_i^1,v_i^2,v_i^3} and let h_i^1,h_i^2,h_i^3 be the associated
incoming half-edges, as defined above. We proceed to the following construction:

  
  * we set 𝔪_0 = 𝔱
  
  * for i from 1 to g, let 𝔪_i be the map obtained by
  the only gluing of h_i^1,h_i^2,h_i^3 in 𝔪_i-1 that produces
  a unicellular map. We let v_i be the vertex created by that gluing
  operation.

We set v_*=(v_1,…,v_g), and Ψ(𝔱,c_*) =
(𝔪_g,v_*).

[Tropical barycentric volume] 
Let P ⊆^d be a tropical lattice polytope.
We define its tropical barycentric volume by

    (P) := max{ a_1+…+a_d + d : a ∈^d such that Δ_π(a) ∈_P }.

Fix an integer R > 0. 
Let d(x,y)  ≤ R. The quadratic Gradient-Ollivier curvature on the pair xy is given by

    K_R^q(x,y) = 1/2inf_g >0 
    ∇_R g(x)= 1 
    g(y)-g(x)=1Δ*∇_R g^2(x) - (g(y)-g(x))(Δ g^2/g(y) - Δ g^2/g(x))

sentence:
Define an orientation of a hedron to be a cyclic ordering of the set of its fronts and an orientation of a k-tree to be a choice of orientation for each of its hedra.
  If two oriented hedra share a front, their orientations are compatible if they correspond under the mirror bijection.
  Then an orientation of a k-tree is coherent if every pair of adjacent hedra is compatibly-oriented.

sentence:
[Matsumoto's Theorem]
Let X be an arbitrary Coxeter graph and let w ∈ W(X).  Then every reduced expression for w can be obtained from any other by applying a sequence of braid moves of the form 
	
    s_i s_j s_i s_j ⋯_m(s_i,s_j)↦s_j s_i s_j s_i ⋯_m(s_i,s_j)

where s_i, s_j ∈ S(X), and each factor in the move has m(s_i,s_j) letters.

sentence:
Let d be an LR-decorated diagram.  Then we say that d is -admissible , or simply admissible , if the following axioms are satisfied.



  * The only loops that may appear are equivalent to the following.





    < g r a p h i c s >





  *  If d is undammed (which can only happen if n is even), then the (non-propagating) edges joining nodes 1 and 1' (respectively, nodes n+2 and (n+2)') must be decorated with a  (respectively, ).  Furthermore, these are the only  (respectively, ) decorations that may occur on d and must be the first (respectively, last) decorations on their respective edges.


  *  Assume d has exactly one propagating edge e (which can only happen if n is odd). Then e may be decorated by an alternating sequence of  and  decorations.  If e is decorated by both open and closed decorations and is connected to node 1 (respectively, 1'), then the first (respectively, last) decoration occurring on e must be a .  Similarly, if e is connected to node n+2 (respectively, (n+2)'), then the first (respectively, last) decoration occurring on e must be a .  If e joins 1 to 1' (respectively, n+2 to (n+2)') and is decorated by a single decoration, then e is decorated by a single  (respectively, ).  Furthermore, if there is a non-propagating edge connected to 1 or 1' (respectively, n+2 or (n+2)') it must be decorated only by a single  (respectively, ).  Finally, no other  or  decorations appear on d.


  *  Assume that d is dammed with (d)>1 and has more than one propagating edge.  If there is a propagating edge joining 1 to 1' (respectively, n+2 to (n+2)'), then it is decorated by a single  (respectively, ).  Otherwise, both edges leaving either of 1 or 1' (respectively, n+2 or (n+2)') are each decorated by a single  (respectively, ) and there are no other  or  decorations appearing on d.


  *  If (d)=1, then the western end of d is equal to one of the following:



  * c]@c@


    < g r a p h i c s >

;


  * c]@c@


    < g r a p h i c s >

;


  * c]@c@


    < g r a p h i c s >

;


  * c]@c@


    < g r a p h i c s >

;


  * c]@c@


    < g r a p h i c s >

;

where the rectangle represents a sequence of blocks (possibly empty) such that each block is a single  and the diagram in (ii) can only occur if d is not decorated by any open decorations.  Also, the occurrences of the  decorations occurring on the propagating edge have the highest (respectively, lowest) relative vertical position of all decorations occurring on any propagating edge.  In particular, if the rectangle in (iv) (respectively, (v)) is empty, then the  decoration has the highest (respectively, lowest) relative vertical position among all decorations occurring on propagating edges.  We have an analogous requirement for the eastern end of e, where the closed decorations are replaced with open decorations.  Furthermore, if there is a non-propagating edge connected to 1 or 1' (respectively, n+2 or (n+2)') it must be decorated only by a single  (respectively, ). sentence:
[Tameness and type]
We say that A, B is a tame subcritical pair if ν_*(A+B)=ν(A)+ν(B) and there is a ν-measurable finite index subgroup K≤ G such that A,B, and K satisfy one of the conclusions (I)-(III) of Proposition <ref>.  If A, B, and K satisfy conclusion (I), we say that the triple A, B,  K has type (I) , and similarly for the other conclusions. We say that A, B has type (I) if there exists a finite index subgroup K≤  G such that A, B,  K has type (I), and similarly for the other types.

When the ambient group is compact, the terms “tame” and “type” can be applied, simply replacing Proposition <ref> with Theorem <ref> in the definition.

sentence:
A subcritical pair of sets A, B⊆ G is

  
  ∙ extendible if there are A'⊇ A, B'⊇ B such that μ(A')+μ(B')>μ(A)+μ(B), while μ_*(A'+B')=μ_*(A+B),

      

  
  ∙ reducible if there are sets A”⊆ A, B”⊆ B such that μ(A”)=μ(A), μ(B”)=μ(B), and μ_*(A”+B”)<μ_*(A+B).  In this case we say A, B reduces to A”, B”.
 
If the pair A, B is not extendible, we say it is nonextendible , and if it is not reducible, we say that it is irreducible .

The gallery δ∈Γ(γ_λ) is called positively folded at Δ_j' if Δ_j-1 = Δ_j and the half-space, which contains Δ_j and corresponds to the reflection hyperplane containing Δ_j', can be separated from the anti-dominant chamber ℭ_-f.

Let ℳ_m× n be the set of all the matrices with m rows and n columns. Two distinct matrices A,B ∈ℳ_m× n are said non-overlapping if all the following conditions are satisfied by A and B:

    A = [ A_11 A_12; A_21 A_22 ]  B = [ B_11 B_12; B_21 B_22 ]
 such that A_11,B_22∈ℳ_r× s, with 1≤ r ≤ m-1, 1≤ s ≤ n-1, and neither A_11=B_22, nor A_12=B_21, nor A_21=B_12, nor A_22=B_11.



  * there do not exist two block partitions

    A= [ A_11; A_21 ]  B=[ B_11; B_21 ]
 such that A_11,B_21∈ℳ_r× n, with 1≤ r≤ m-1, and neither A_11=B_21, nor A_21=B_11.


  * there do not exist two block partitions

    A= [ A_11 A_12 ] B=[ B_11 B_12 ]
 such that A_11,B_12∈ℳ_m× s, with 1≤ s≤ n-1, and neither A_11=B_12, nor A_12=B_11.

sentence:
Let P⊂ with n=|P|≥ 2.
A permutation w∈_P is a G-word if
it satisfies the two conditions
  
  
  (G1) w_1 = max(P) and w_n = max(P{w_1}); and
  
  (G2) If n≥ 4, then w_2>w_n-1.
  
It is an R-word if it satisfies the two conditions
  
  
  (R1) w_1 = max(P) and w_n = max(P{w_1}); and
  
  (R2) If n≥ 4, then w_2<w_n-1.
  
A G-word (resp., an R-word) is primitive if for every proper subword
x of length ≥ 4, neither x nor x^* is a G-word (resp., an R-word).
The set of all primitive G-words (resp., on P⊂, or on [n])
is denoted  (resp., _P, or _n).  The sets
, _P, _n are defined similarly.

sentence: Let π=π_1π_2 …π_n ∈ S_n.  Consider the graph of π, G(π), consisting of the points (i,π_i) for all i ∈ [n].  The entry π_i is said to match the quadrant marked mesh pattern (a,b,c,d), if in G(π) there are at least a points to the northeast of (i,π_i), at least b points to the northwest of (i,π_i), at least c points to the southwest of (i,π_i), and at least d points to the southeast of (i,π_i). The order in which we consider quadrants proceeds counterclockwise, beginning with the top right quadrant.

sentence:
Let G be a hot game and G a thermic version of G. Let  t_0=0,t_1,t_2,…,t_k=t(G) be the sequence of the vertical coordinates of the turning points of the left boundary of the thermograph of G. The Right stops of the sequence of G^L(i)=G^L_t_i-t_i define the segments of the boundary. If RS(G^L(i+1))=RS(G^L(i)), we have a vertical segment; on the other hand, if RS(G^L(i+1))<RS(G^L(i)), we have an oblique segment. Define

  
  * t_i to be left vertical if RS(G^L(i+1))=RS(G^L(i));
  
  * t_i to be left oblique if RS(G^L(i+1))<RS(G^L(i)).

We further define 
    T^L_=∑_t_i is left
    vertical (t_i+1-t_i)
 and 
    T^L_=∑_t_i is left
    oblique (t_i+1-t_i).

Right vertical, right oblique, T_^R, and T_^R are defined similarly.

sentence:
Let v be an interior vertex.  A 1-lens with pole at v is the interior of a Jordan curve that is a geodesic segment with endpoints v and  v.
Let v and w be interior vertices.  A 2-lens with poles at v and w is the interior of a Jordan curve that is a union of two geodesic segments,
each having endpoints at v and w.  For n = 1, 2, we say that an n-lens is sharp if for every pole v, only one of the four cells that meet at v is
inside the n-lens.  We say that an n-lens is empty if it contains only one cell.

sentence:
A cellset S is convex if it is an intersection of zero or more pseudo halfplanes.
The convex closure of a cellset S is the smallest convex set containing
S, i.e., the intersection of all half-planes containing S.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let R := (E, (ρ_i)_i ∈ I) be a relational structure on an
  infinite set. Then, _R is non-decreasing. And provided
  that either the signature μ is bounded or the kernel K(R) of
  R is finite, the growth of _R is either
  polynomial or as fast as every polynomial.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O

sentence:
Let f: [n] → [m]_0 such that ∑_i=1^nf(i)=m. Then we say (D,f) is a parking distribution if for all A ⊆ [n], we have

    ∑_i ∈ R_D(A)f(i) ≤ |R_D(A)|.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let S and M be as above.


  * The projective dimension of M, denoted by (M), is the length of the minimal free resolution associated to M.

  * The Castelnuovo-Mumford regularity (or simply, regularity ), denoted by (M), is a measure of the width of the minimal free resolution of M and is defined as
    
    (M):=max{j-i|β_i,j(M)≠ 0}.

sentence:
Let H be an r-uniform hypergraph of size n. A constructive process 𝒫 for H is a finite sequence of hypergraphs H_i, 1 ≤ i ≤ n satisfying the following properties: 




  * H_n = H,

  * H_j is a subhypergraph of H_k for j ≤ k, 

  * each H_i has exactly i hyperedges, and 

  * for each j, E(H_j+1) = E(H_j) ⋃{ e_j } for some e_j ∈ E(H).


We say that a constructive process 𝒫 for a hypergraph H is connected if and only if each H_i is connected for all i.  It is clear that a hypergraph is connected if and only if it has a connected construction process.  We say that a constructive process 𝒫 for a hypergraph H is minimally connected if and only if each H_i is minimally connected.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Define a ternary relation γ, that yields triples [a,b,c] such that if one proceeds from a → c, one has to pass through b. For a,b,c,d ∈ X, if this ternary relation γ satisfies:
	[1^o]
		
  * Cyclicity: if [a,b,c], then [b,c,a]
		
  * Antisymmetry: if [a,b,c] then not [c,b,a]
		
  * Transitivity: if [a,b,c] and [a,c,d], then [a,b,d]
		
  * Totality: if a,b,c are distinct then either,[a,b,c] or [c,b,a]
	      
	then it is called a cyclic order .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
Let Δ be a balanced d-dimensional simplicial complex and let D⊊Δ be an induced subcomplex that is isomorphic to a shellable and co-shellable subcomplex of 𝒞_d. The operation χ^*_D given by
	
    Δ↦χ^*_D(Δ)=(Δ∖ D) ∪ (_d∖ D)

	is called a cross-flip on Δ. If two balanced simplicial complexes Δ and Γ are connected by a sequence of cross-flips, we write ΔΓ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let Δ and Γ be combinatorial d-manifolds such that ∂Δ≅∂Γ. 
A pseudo-cobordism (Ω,φ,ψ) between Δ and Γ is shellable if there is an ordering F_1,…,F_t of the (d+1)-faces of Ω such that

	
  * F_1,…,F_t is a shelling order on the relative simplicial poset (Ω,φ(Δ)),
	
  * F_t,…,F_1 is a shelling order on the relative simplicial poset (Ω,ψ(Γ)).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let BC_d the set of basic cross-flips in dimension d. 
We call a set R⊆BC_d of basic cross-flips reducible if every cross-flip in R can be expressed as a combination of cross-flips in BC_d∖ R.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let π∈S_n and k be an integer such that 1 ≤ k
 ≤ n+1. The k-prefix of π is the permutation
 π'∈S_n+1 defined by π'(1) = k and 
    π'(i+1) =
     {[      π(i) π(i) < k,;    π(i)+1  π(i) ≥ k ].
 for i=1,…,n.
 We denote π' with k≻π. In a similar way we define
 the k-postfix of π as the permutation π≺ k in
 S_n+1.

sentence:
multiindex
  A multi-index is a vector σ∈_q^n, for some q
  and n.  The support of a multi-index σ is S(σ) =
  { i : σ_i > 0 }⊆ [n]. We extend notations defined for
  S(σ) to σ in the natural way, and write e.g.  |σ| instead of |S(σ)|, i ∈σ instead of i
  ∈ S(σ), and so on.

sentence:
We denote J(n,w,i) and call generalized Johnson graph  the graph with vertices the set of
n-tuples of 0's and 1's, with w coordinates equal to
1, and with edges connecting pairs of n-tuples having exactly i
coordinates in common equal to 1.

sentence:
Let S be a d-dimensional local CM normal domain, and N be a non-zero reflexive S-module. 
We say Λ_S(N) is a non-commutative crepant resolution (= NCCR) of S if Λ=d and  
Λ is a maximal Cohen-Macaulay (= MCM) S-module.

sentence:
A map τ:(∞)→(∞) is called a stable operator if the following conditions are satisfied:



  (a) If I⊂ P(∞) is a finitely generated strongly stable ideal, then β_ij(I)=β_ij(τ(I)) for all i,j.

  (b) If I,J⊂ P(∞) are strongly stable ideals with I⊂ J, then τ(I) ⊂τ(J).
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let m(g), respectively m̃(h), denote the maximum number of vertices of a 2-connected factor-critical equimatchable graph embeddable in the orientable surface of  genus g, respectively nonorientable surface of genus h. Then the following inequalities hold.

i) 
If g≤ 2 and h≤ 2, then 

    4√(2g) + 1 ≤ m(g) ≤ 4√(g) + 17 
      and  
    4 √(h) +1 ≤m̃(h) ≤ 2√(2h) +17.

ii) If g≥ 3 and h≥ 3, then 

    4√(2g) + 1 ≤ m(g) ≤ c_g√(g) + 5
      and  
    4√(h) + 1 ≤m̃(h) ≤c̃_h√(h) + 5,
 
where c_g≤ 12 and c̃_h≤ 10 are positive real constants such that the sequences
(c_g)_g=3^∞ and (c̃_h)_h=3^∞ are decreasing, lim_g→∞c_g = 2√(7)+2<7.3, and lim_h→∞c̃_h = √(2)(√(7)+1)<5.2.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let S be a finite totally ordered set. A (rooted, labeled)
  strictly decreasing forest F on S is a partially defined function
  F: S→ S such that for any ν where F is defined F(ν)>ν holds.

  Elements of S are called nodes of F. Nodes where F is not
  defined are called roots of F. A forest T with only one root is
  called a tree , in this case we denote the root T.

  The node F(ν) is called the father of ν.  The preimages of
  μ∈ F^-1(ν) by F are called the children of ν and we
  denote their set [F]ν or even ν if F is clear from
  the context and their number by [F]ν or
  ν. Finally, When depicting a tree, we always draw the children
  in increasing order from left to right .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

  cardinal. Denote byF_$̨ the restriction F [X]^$̨ to sets
  of size$̨.  The
  subsets which are closed under F_$̨ form the following notion of
  semi-closure𝒞_F,={D: DV ∧(Y∈[D]^F(Y)D)}.  LetK_F,denote the semi-closure
  operator corresponding to𝒞_F,and let us refer to
  setsD∈𝒞_F,as F_$̨-closed sets.

sentence:
[Disjointness conditions]


  * ℱ is almost disjoint  (a.d.)  if |A∩
  B|<min{|A|,|B|} for distinct A,B∈ℱ. 

  * ℱ is ν-disjoint, for a cardinal ν, if |A∩
  B|<ν for any distinct A, B∈ℱ. 

  * (Miller <cit.>, Erdős and Hajnal <cit.>)
ℱ  satisfies condition C(θ,ν) for cardinals θ,ν if  |⋂𝒜|<ν for all 𝒜∈ [ℱ]^θ (so,
C(2,ν) is ν-disjointness).

  * (Komjáth <cit.>, Hajnal, Juhász and Shelah <cit.>) ℱ is essentially disjoint (e.d) if there exists an assignment of
  subsets B(A)∈ [A]^<|A| for all A∈𝒜 such that the
  family {A B(A):A∈ℱ} is pairwise disjoint.

  * ℱ is ν-e.d if for every A∈ℱ there
  exists an assignment B(A)∈ [A]^ν such that {A B(A):A∈ℱ} is pairwise disjoint.  Remark: in <cit.>  the term
  sparse is used instead of “e.d”.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O

sentence:
Two families of sets ℱ and 𝒢
  are similar if there is a bijection f:ℱ→𝒢 such that |A∩ B|=|f(A)∩ f(B)| for all A,B∈ℱ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let s be a line in PG(n,q) and v∈𝒱(n,q). If s intersects v in α points (0⩽α⩽ q+1), we will call s an α-secant to v. Furthermore,
		
			
  * if α⩽3, s will be called a short secant ,
			
  * if α⩾ q-1, s will be called a long secant .

sentence: [Factors] If W is a finite set then by a factor  we mean simply a partition of W into finitely many pieces which, in this paper, we refer to as atoms .

sentence: The generalised Pertersen graph  P(n,m),  n≥ 3 and 1≤ m≤⌊n-1/2⌋ consists of an outer n-cycle u_i,u_2,...,u_n, a set of n spokes u_iv_i, 1≤ i≤ n and n edges v_iv_i+m, 1≤ i≤ n with indices taken modulo n.

sentence:
For a finite simple graph G with vertex set V={v_1, …, v_n} and edge set E the chromatic symmetric function of G is defined to be

    X_G=∑_κ x_κ(v_1)⋯ x_κ(v_n)
where the sum is over all proper colourings κ of G.

sentence: A fourientation Ø of an oriented graph (G,) is a subset of 𝔼(G).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A partial orientation of (G,) is a subset Ø of 𝔼(G) such that for each e ∈ E(G) at least one of e^+ or e^- is not in Ø. If e^+∉Ø and e^-∉Ø then we say e is neutral in Ø and we write e ∉Ø. If e^±∈Ø then we say e is oriented in Ø.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O

sentence: By abuse of language, a directed cut ( cycle ) of a partial orientation is a directed cut (cycle) of the underlying oriented graph for which all edges are oriented in agreement with the cut (cycle). A potential cut ( cycle ) of a partial orientation is a directed cut (cycle) of the underlying oriented graph for which all oriented edges are oriented consistently with the cut (cycle), but neutral edges are allowed. In symbols,  is a directed cut (cycle) of Ø if e^±∈𝔼() ⇒ e^±∈Ø for all e ∈ E, whereas  is a potential cut (cycle) of Ø if e^±∈𝔼() ⇒ e^∓∉Ø for all e ∈ E.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
If a polyhedral cone Q is written as 
    Q=H^+_a_1∩…∩ H^+_a_r
 such that no  H^+_a_i can be
omitted, then we say that this is an irreducible representation
 of
Q.

sentence:
We identify the form a(X_1,…,X_ℓ)=∑_i=1^ℓα_i X_i with the linear function a:_p^ℓ→_p given by a(v)=∑_i=1^ℓα_i v_i, where v=(v_1,…,v_ℓ)∈_i^ℓ (in essence this is obtained by letting the X_i range over scalars from _p rather than vectors from some space _p^n).

Given an invertible ℓ×ℓ matrix M over _p, the corresponding change of view of a is the linear form a'(X_1,…,X_ℓ)=∑_i=1^ℓα'_i X_i obtained by the following process: Consider the linear function corresponding to a, perform on its domain _p^ℓ the change of variables corresponding to M, and then take the linear form corresponding its representation a' in the new basis.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The function f is δ-differentially uniform if for any u ∈ (𝔽_2)^m ∖{ 0 } and 
for any v ∈  (𝔽_2)^m, |{ x ∈  (𝔽_2)^m: 
f̂_u(x) = v }|≤δ .

If f is 2-differentially uniform, then it is called an Almost Perfectly Nonlinear (APN) function.

sentence:
Let α be a k-anxious number. A rational function c( z )
				∈( z ) is called α-calm if it has no poles
				at α.

sentence:
Let α be a k-anxious number. A finite sequence of rational
				functions ( c_i(z) )_i = 1^n, c_i( z ) ∈( z ) is called α-precalm if there exists a
				polynomial 0 ≠ h( z ) ∈[ z ] such that h^*( c_i(
				z ) ) is α-calm.

sentence:
A polygon dissection is called a composite root with respect to a set of 2-connected patterns Δ ={δ _1,δ _2,...,δ _m } if the following two conditions hold:
 
  * It consists only of small polygons.

  * Let F be a face of the composite root that shares an edge with the unbounded face and let an edge e_1∈ F that is not an outer edge. Then, e_1 is connected to the root-edge with a simple path of adjacent polygons that constitutes a dissection of size less than H_Δ.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let (P,≤) be  a poset and A,B,C pairwise
  disjoint subsets of
  P satisfying the conditions Definition <ref>, i.e., 


  * A is a downset,

  * C is an up-set,

  * A<C,

  * A∪ B∪ C=P.

Then we call the triple A,B,C an extendible triple .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence: The skew sum of two vincular patterns (σ, A)∈k× [k-1] and (τ, B)∈ℓ× [ℓ-1] is the pattern (σ,A)⊖ (τ,B) = (σ⊖τ, C) where C=A ∪{i+k: i∈ B} (as in the case for direct sum).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let π be a filling of Young board λ, and let σ = σ_1 …σ_k be a consecutive pattern.  The subfactor π_i π_i+1…π_i+k-1 is a right-to-left maximal copy of σ if the following criteria are satisfied:
 
  
  * π_i π_i+1…π_i+k-1σ.
  
  * If j>i and π_j π_j+1…π_j+k-1σ and σ_m = min(σ_1, …, σ_k), then π_j+m-1 < π_i+m-1.  In other words, the minimal letter of π_i π_i+1…π_i+k-1 is greater than the minimal letter of any other copy of σ to starting the right of π_i.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A morphism φ on the binary alphabet {a,b} is k-uniform for some integer k ≥ 2 if |φ(a)| = |φ(b)| = k.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let A be an abelian group of even order and of exponent greater than 2, and let y be an involution of A. The generalised dicyclic group (A,y,x) is the group ⟨ A,x| x^2=y, a^x=a^-1, ∀ a ∈ A⟩. A group is called generalised dicyclic if it is isomorphic to some (A,y,x). When A is cyclic, (A,y,x) is called a dicyclic or generalised quaternion group .


We let ι̅_A:(A,y,x)→(A,y,x) be the mapping defined by (ax)^ι̅_A=ax^-1 and a^ι̅_A=a, for every a∈ A. In particular, ι̅_A is an automorphism of (A,y,x).
The role of the label “A” in ι̅_A seems unnecessary, however we use this label to stress one important fact. An abstract group R might be isomorphic to (A,y,x), for various choices of A. Therefore, since the automorphism ι̅_A depends on A and since we might have more than one choice of A, we prefer a notation that emphasizes this fact.

sentence:
Given two ordinals i < j,
and a sequence of orders 𝒪_j = (O_k)_k ∈ j,
the hierarchic order denoted (i, j, 𝒪_j)
is an order defined on the set of all elements of the preludes of 𝒪_j,
such that these preludes have length at least i.
This is the order satisfying ∀X, Y ∈((i, j, 𝒪_j)),

  
  * if (X) < (Y), then X < Y,
  
  * if (X) > (Y), then X > Y,
  
  * otherwise X = Y, or X, Y have a question (k, x_k, y_k), then:

  
  * if x_k < y_k in O_k, then X < Y,
  
  * if x_k > y_k in O_k, then X > Y.

sentence:
[Universal order]
We say that an order O is universal for a class of orders 𝒜,
 if for any order O' ∈𝒜,
 there exists an embedding of O' in O.
An order embedding is an injective mapping such that order is preserved.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let 𝒮⊆ M_n be a quantum graph, and ϕ M_n → M_d an orthogonal representation of 𝒮.
We say that ϕ is in locally general position if, for any fixed nonzero projection Q∈ M_n, (ϕ(P)) ≥(P) whenever P∈ M_n is a projection such that Q𝒮P = {0}.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let α I_M → X be a path.   A  trivial extension of α is any path α'  I_M'→ X of the following form.  For each  i with 0 ≤ i ≤ M, choose t_i ∈ with t_i ≥ 0.  Then define α' by


    α'(s) = α(0)     0 ≤ s ≤ t_0
    α(1)     t_0 + 1 ≤ s ≤ t_0 + 1 + t_1  
    α(2)     t_0 + t_1 + 2 ≤ s ≤ t_0 + t_1 + 2 + t_2  
      ⋮     ⋮
    α(M)    ∑_i=0^M-1 t_i + M ≤ s ≤∑_i=0^M t_i + M.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Fractional factorization]
Let k and ℓ be positive integers such that k-ℓ is a 
positive even number. Let G=(V,E) be a graph and let X⊂ V.
We say that a partition ℱ={M_1,…,M_ℓ,F_1,…,F_(k-ℓ)/2} of E is an 
(X,ℓ,k)-fractional factorization of G if the following holds.
	
		
  * M_i is an (X,1,k)-factor of G, for 1≤ i≤ℓ;
		
  * F_j is an Eulerian (X,2,k)-factor of G, for 1≤ j≤ (k-ℓ)/2.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Bifactorization]
Let k and ℓ be positive integers such that k-ℓ is a positive 
even number, and let G=(A_1,A_2;E) be a bipartite graph. 

Let ℱ_1,ℱ_2 be families of subsets of E
and put G_i = G[∪_F∈ℱ_iF], for i=1,2.
We say that 𝔽=(ℱ_1,ℱ_2) is an 
(ℓ,k)-bifactorization of G
if the following holds.

 
  (i) {G_1,G_2} is a decomposition of G ;
 
  (ii) ℱ_i is an (A_i,ℓ,k)-fractional 
factorization of G_i, for 1≤ i≤ 2.




If G admits an (ℓ,k)-bifactorization,
we say that G is (ℓ,k)-bifactorable.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A strong placement game is a combinatorial game which satisfies the following:


  (i) The starting position is the empty board.

  (ii) Players place pieces on empty spaces of the board according to the rules.

  (iii) Pieces are not moved or removed once placed.

  (iv) The rules are such that if it is possible to reach a position through a sequence of legal moves, then any sequence of moves leading to this position consists only of legal moves.

The Trivial placement game on a board is the strong placement game that has no additional rules.

sentence:
Let G be a graph and X be an inner product space.  An orthogonal representation of G in X is a function r:V(G) → X such that two vertices of G are adjacent if and only if they are mapped by r to nonorthogonal vectors, i.e., for any distinct u,v ∈ V(G),

    ⟨ r(u), r(v) ⟩≠ 0
     ⟺ {u,v}∈ E(G).

sentence:
Let G=(V,E) be a ribbon graph. We use (G) to denote the set _0(G)=_≤ 0(G), so that 

    (G):={F⊆ E(G) | F is the edge set of a spanning quasi-tree of G},

and D(G)=(E,) to denote the delta-matroid D_0(G)=D_≤0(G). We say that  D(G) is a ribbon-graphic delta-matroid.

sentence:
Let D=(E,ℱ) be a delta-matroid and n be a non-negative integer. Then we define _≤ n by

    _≤ n:={F A | F∈ and A⊆ E and |A|≤ n}.
  
We say that the set system   D_≤ n:=(E,ℱ_≤ n) is the n-spread of D .

sentence:
For delta-matroids D=(E,ℱ) and D̃=(Ẽ,ℱ̃) with E∩Ẽ=∅, the direct sum of D and D̃ is written D⊕D̃ and is the delta-matroid defined as 

    D⊕D̃:=(E∪Ẽ,{F∪F̃| F∈ℱ and F̃∈ℱ̃}).
 If a delta-matroid can be written as D⊕D̃ for some non-trivial delta-matroids D and D̃, then we say it is disconnected .  A delta-matroid is connected if it is not disconnected.

sentence:
Suppose a and b are sequences with generating functions p(x) and q(x), respectively. Then the Cauchy product (or discrete convolution if polynomials) of a and b is a new sequence a*b defined by 

    (a*b)_m=∑_i+j=m a_ib_j = ∑_i=0^m a_ib_m-i=[x^m](p(x)q(x)),

where [x^m](p(x))=a_m.

sentence:
[<cit.>]
A parallelepiped representation R of a tolerance graph G is
called canonical if every unbounded vertex in R is inevitable.

sentence:
Let G=(V,E) be an arbitrary graph and u∈ V be a vertex
of G. Then,



  * the set 𝒞(u)={v∈ V∖ N[u] | N(u)⊆ N(v)} 
is the covering set of u, and every vertex v∈𝒞(u)
is a covering vertex of u,

  * V_0(u) is the set of connected components of G∖ N[u] 
that have at least one covering vertex v∈𝒞(u) of u.

sentence:
Given a hypergraph H, a weight system on E(H) is a function
 w:  E(H) →ℕ. A function g: V(H) →ℕ is called a w-cover if ∑_v ∈ eg(v) ≥ w(e) for all e ∈ E(H).
 Let ν_w(H) be the maximum of w[F] over all matchings F in H, and let
τ_w(H) be the minimum of g[V] over all w-covers g.

sentence: A wheel graph on n vertices is defined by 𝒲_n=𝒞_n-1+K_1. K_1 is called the center of the wheel.

sentence:
The
 weight of a directed edge (x,y) of G is 

    w(x,y):= -1/(x)∑_i=0^(x)-1 i (y_i+1)/(y_i+1),
  
where  (x,y_i):=m_x^i(x,y) is the edge obtained by incrementing the edge (x,y) for i consecutive times by using the rotor mechanism at x.

sentence: We say that an ideal is squarefree if it is generated by squarefree monomials and squarefree Borel if it is generated by the squarefree monomials of some Borel ideal.  For a set of squarefree monomials T, the squarefree Borel ideal generated by T is the smallest squarefree Borel ideal containing T, denoted (T).

sentence: Let m be a monomial with factorization x_i_1⋯ x_i_r, and let d be a positive integer. If d≤ m, define the d-truncation of m, denoted _d(m), to be x_i_1⋯ x_i_d. If d >  m, then set _d(m) to be m itself. For a monomial ideal I, define the d-truncation of I to be the ideal _d(I)=(_d(m) : m ∈ I).

sentence:
Let P and Q be graded posets. We say that P and Q are Whitney Duals if for all 
  k≥0 we have that 
  
    |w_k(P)|=W_k(Q)  and  |w_k(Q)|=W_k(P).

sentence:

say λ is a generalized EW-labeling if it satisfies
 
  
  * the rank two switching property, 
  
  * the braid relation, and
  
  * the cancellative property.

sentence: If R⊊ V(G) with |R|≥ 5, and ϕ is a 4-coloring of G[R], we define the ϕ-identification of R in G , denoted by G_ϕ(R), to be the graph obtained from G by identifying for each i∈{1,2,3,4} the vertices colored i in R to a vertex x_i, adding the edges x_ix_j for all i,j∈{1,2,3,4} and then deleting parallel edges.

sentence: Let H be an almost 5-Ore graph and let w be a special vertex of H. A frame of H with special vertex w is a graph J isomorphic to K_4 such that V(J)=w∪ N_H(w) and H can be obtained from J by Ore-composition with 5-Ore graphs whose replaced edges are in E(J). We call the vertices of J the corners of the frame and the graphs used for the Ore-composition the bars .

sentence:
Let Δ be a (d-1)-dimensional pure simplicial complex. We recall that the facet graph of  (see White <cit.>), denoted by G(Δ), is defined as follow:


  - The set of vertices is V(G(Δ))= (Δ),

  - The set of egdes is 
    E(G(Δ))={{F,G}: F,G∈ (Δ)  and  |F∩ G|=d-1}.
  



Notice that a pure simplicial complex  is strongly connected if and only if G() is connected.


We say that  Δ is  a Cohen-Macaulay complex without cycles in codimension 1 if Δ is Cohen-Macaulay and G(Δ) is a tree.

sentence:
* Call a bipartition of the edges of any graph (for our purposes either R, S or T) such that one part gives a spanning tree and the other part gives a spanning 2-forest a valid edge partition.
  
  * Suppose we have a valid edge partition.  This gives a bipartition of all of the vertices of the graph according to which tree of the 2-forest they are in.  Call a cycle C compatible with the edge partition if all vertices of C are in the same part of the vertex partition and exactly one edge of C is in the part of the edge partition corresponding to the spanning tree.

sentence:
A strong (ℓ,d)-partition is an (ℓ,d)-partition each bag of which contains at least 5 × 2^ℓ d vertices;
a strong (ℓ,d)-graph is a graph which admits a strong (ℓ,d)-partition.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A line-bramble ℬ of G is a collection of connected subgraphs of G satisfying the following properties:


  * For all X ∈ℬ, |V(X)| ≥ 2.

  * For all X,Y ∈ℬ, V(X) ∩ V(Y) ≠∅.

Define a hitting set for a line-bramble ℬ to be a set of edges H ⊆ E(G) that intersects each X ∈ℬ. Then define the order of ℬ to be the size of the minimum hitting set H of ℬ.

sentence:
A tournament H is said to be a tournament forest if it is possible to partition its vertex set into
two transitive sets[Note that this means that if H is a tournament forest, then χ(H) ≤ 2.] L,R so that if we define an undirected bipartite graph U on the vertex sets L and R by connecting ℓ∈ L to r ∈ R if and only if H has an edge pointing from
r to ℓ, then U is a forest.

sentence:
Given a digraph , a syntax tree over  is a generalised tree  together with a collection of elements of W_, one associated with each node in . We denote the walk associated with node n by n.contents, and define the contents of  (as distinct from the contents of its root node) to be


    T.contents = T.root.contentsH_n.contents⋯H_2.contentsH_1.contents,

where the contents of a hedge are given by

    H_i.contents = T_i,1.contentsT_i,2.contents⋯T_i,k_i.contents.


     The syntax tree  is valid for a walk w if and only if it satisfies the following conditions:


  (i) T.contents = w,
       
  (ii) h(H_i.contents) ≠ h(H_j.contents) for i ≠ j. In other words, no two hedges contain closed walks off the same vertex.

     The purpose of the second condition is to disallow syntax trees where several closed walks off the same vertex are placed in different hedges, rather than into different generalised trees within the same hedge.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The set of all equivalence classes for a given dressing signature  is the quotient set of W_;αω by , denoted by W_;αω  /:

    W_;αω  /  = {[w]_ : w ∈ W_;αω}

sentence: A weighted digraph (, ) is a digraph  paired with a weight function  that assigns a weight [e] to each edge e of . To make the discussion concrete while retaining some generality, we consider here a weight function that assigns a complex matrix of size d_β× d_α to the edge (αβ). We denote the weight of the edge (αβ) by _βα = [(αβ)].
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A system of permutations on the edges of n_d-1
is a collection =(σ_ab)_1≤ a ≠ b ≤ d
of permutations σ_ab of [n]
such that
σ_ab is the reverse of σ_ba for all a, b. 
For each pair 1≤ i ≠ j  ≤ n we define the 
directed graph G_ij() of 
as the complete graph on [d], where edge ab is directed
a→ b if and only if the permutation σ_ab
is of the form …  i …  j …. 
We say that a system of permutations  is acyclic
if and only if all the graphs G_ij() are acyclic.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given a 1-extendable graph H, 
		 barriers B_1 and B_2 conflict if
		(a) B_1 ∩ B_2 ≠∅,
		(b) B_1 spans multiple components of H - B_2, or
		(c) B_2 spans multiple components of H - B_1.

sentence:
Let G,H be graphs, where H is connected, and let b be a
positive integer. All the following are defined with respect to G,
H and b. A bad vertex is a vertex v ∈ V(G) which is
not contained in any H-copy in G. A bad edge is an edge
e ∈ E(G) which is not contained in any H-copy in G. A
bad set is a set U  V(G) of size 2 ≤ |U| ≤ b+1
such that there is no H-copy Ĥ G satisfying
|V(Ĥ) ∩ U| = 1. A bad set of size 2 is referred to as a bad pair . A small component is a connected component of
G with at most (b+1)(v(H)-1) vertices.

sentence:
Any code equivalent to _k,s(η) with N(η)≠ (-1)^nk and η≠ 0
is called a (generalized) twisted Gabidulin code .

sentence:
A weighted tripartite graph ν with vertex sets
  X, Y, and Z satisfies the 3-linear forms condition if
  
    _x,x' ∈ X, y,y' ∈ Y, z,z' ∈ Z
        [ν(y,z) ν(y',z) ν(y,z') ν(y',z')
        ν(x,z) ν(x',z) ν(x,z') ν(x',z') 
    ·ν(x,y) ν(x',y) ν(x,y') ν(x',y')] = 1 + o(1)

  and also (<ref>) holds when one or more of the twelve ν
  factors in the expectation are erased.

  Similarly, a function ν_N → [0,∞) satisfies
  the 3-linear forms condition[We will
    assume that N is odd, which simplifies the proof of
    Theorem <ref> without too much loss in generality. Theorem <ref> holds more generally without this additional
    assumption on N.] if
  
    _x,x',y,y',z,z' ∈_N [ν(-y-2z) ν(-y'-2z) ν(-y-2z')
        ν(-y'-2z')
        ν(x-z) ν(x'-z) 
    ·ν(x-z') ν(x'-z')
        ν(2x+y) ν(2x'+y) ν(2x+y') ν(2x'+y')] = 1 + o(1)

  and also (<ref>) holds when one or more of the twelve ν
  factors in the expectation are erased.

sentence:
[3-linear forms condition] 
  A weighted tripartite graph ν with vertex sets
  X, Y, and Z satisfies the 3-linear forms condition if
  
    _x,x' ∈ X, y,y' ∈ Y, z,z' ∈ Z
        [ν(y,z) ν(y',z) ν(y,z') ν(y',z')
        ν(x,z) ν(x',z) ν(x,z') ν(x',z') 
    ·ν(x,y) ν(x',y) ν(x,y') ν(x',y')] = 1 + o(1)

  and also (<ref>) holds when one or more of the twelve ν
  factors in the expectation are erased.

  Similarly, a function ν_N → [0,∞) satisfies
  the 3-linear forms condition[We will
    assume that N is odd, which simplifies the proof of
    Theorem <ref> without too much loss in generality. Theorem <ref> holds more generally without this additional
    assumption on N.] if
  
    _x,x',y,y',z,z' ∈_N [ν(-y-2z) ν(-y'-2z) ν(-y-2z')
        ν(-y'-2z')
        ν(x-z) ν(x'-z) 
    ·ν(x-z') ν(x'-z')
        ν(2x+y) ν(2x'+y) ν(2x+y') ν(2x'+y')] = 1 + o(1)

  and also (<ref>) holds when one or more of the twelve ν
  factors in the expectation are erased.

sentence:
Let ℋ=(V,E) be any hypergraph, where V = {1,2, …, n} and |E|=m. Let f : V →ℕ^+ be a function satisfying ∑_u ∈ V f(u) = m+n. Let Q = Q_ℋ, f(x_1, …, x_n) be any polynomial of degree m such that Q(c(1), …, c(n)) = 0 whenever (c(1), …, c(n)) ∈{0, …, f(1)-1}×…×{0, …, f(n)-1} is not a proper coloring of ℋ. Let NZ(Q) denote the set of non-zeros of Q in {0, …, f(1)-1}×…×{0, …, f(n)-1}. If

    ∑_(c_1, …, c_n) ∈ NZ(Q) (-1)^∑_i=1^n c_i∏_i=1^nf(i)-1  c_i Q(c_1, …, c_n) ≠ 0,

then ℋ is f-AT.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let G be a connected graph and let H be a non-trivial graph. Then, every metric generator for G ∘ H is also an adjacency generator, and vice versa .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence: Given a set S ⊂^d, the S-Helly number _S (if it exists) is the smallest positive integer with the following property. Suppose that ℱ is a finite family of convex sets in ^d, and that ⋂𝒢 intersects S for every subfamily 𝒢 of ℱ having at most _S members. Then ⋂ℱ intersects S.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Given a discrete subset S of ^d, the quantitative S-Tverberg number _S(m,k) (if it exists) is the smallest positive integer such that among any _S(m,k) distinct points in S⊆^d, there is a partition of them into m sets A_1,A_2,…,A_m such that the intersection of their convex hulls contains at least k points of S.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let 𝒞 be a combinatorial class and C(x):=∑_γ∈𝒞x^|γ| its generating function. 
Given a coherent positive real value of x, i.e., chosen within the disk of
 convergence of C(x)), the  Boltzmann model of parameter x 
assigns to any element γ∈𝒞 the following probability, 

    ℙ_x(γ)=x^|γ|/C(x).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For a fixed positive integer k, a graph G, and a vertex x ∈ V(G), let 
    f_k(x) = |{y ∈ V(G) : d(x,y) ≤ k}|.
 Let 
    δ_k(G) = min_x ∈ V(G)f_k(x),
 the minimum k-distance degree of G.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O

sentence:
Given a graph G, we call a partition of the vertices, 
    V(G) = S_1 ∪ S_2 ∪⋯∪ S_t,
 into t disjoint parts a k-distance domatic partition if each S_i is a k-distance dominating set of G. Such a partition is equivalent to an assignment of t colors to the vertices, 
    c:V(G) →{1,2,…,t},
 such that for each vertex x ∈ V(G) and for each color i ∈{1,…,t}, there exists a vertex y ∈ V(G) such that d(x,y) ≤ k and c(y) = i. We will call such a coloring a proper k-distance domatic coloring . For a given positive integer k, let d_k(G) denote the maximum t for which such an assignment exists, the k-distance domatic number of G.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O

sentence:
Let S be a finite set. A binary matroid M on S is represented by
a matrix with entries in GF(2), whose columns are indexed by the elements of
S. A subset of S is dependent in M if and only if the corresponding
columns of the matrix are linearly dependent.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A connected bipartite graph G is called 4-perfect if E_1>0 , E_2>0 where E_1=n_2(A_11+1)-n_1A_12/n_2[A_12A_21-(A_11+1)(A_22+1)] and E_2=n_1(A_22+1)-n_2A_21/n_1[A_12A_21-(A_11+1)(A_22+1)].
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O

sentence: The master graph satisfies the balancing condition .
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
[Algebraic sets]  Let d ≥ 1 be a dimension.  An algebraic set in ^d is any set of the form

    { x ∈^d: P_1(x) =…=P_m(x) = 0}

where P_1,…,P_m: ^d → are polynomials.  If one can take m=1, we call the algebraic set a hypersurface .  An algebraic set is irreducible if it cannot be expressed as the union of two strictly smaller algebraic sets.  An irreducible algebraic set will be referred to as an algebraic variety , or variety for short.

The intersection of any subset of ^d with ^d will be referred to as the real points of that subset.  A real algebraic variety is the real points V_ of a complex algebraic variety V.[Strictly speaking, because two different complex varieties may have the same real points, a real algebraic variety should really be viewed as a pair (V_,V) rather than just the set V_; however, we will abuse notation and identify a real algebraic variety with the set V_ of real points.]
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let Σ be a set (of “signs”). We say that π is a Σ-labeled partition of [[n]] if π is a partition of [[n]] labeled by Σ such that 
  
  
  * for every R ∈π, R∈π, and 
  
  * S=S if and only if S∈π is signed. 
  
  We will write this as follows:
  
    π = S_σ_1|⋯| S_σ_l| R_1 |R_1|⋯| R_k |R_k.

  Here the signed blocks are denoted by S, and carry the sign σ_i ∈Σ as an index. The unsigned blocks are denoted by R_i. We call Σ(π):={σ_1, …, σ_l } the sign of π.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O

sentence:
Let q≥ 0 be an integer. A q-blooming tree on n+1 nodes is an increasing ordered tree on n+1 nodes, with q extra indistinguishable unlabeled nodes (called blooms ) appended to the root.
  The only thing that matters about blooms is their position in the total order of the children of the root.
  See Figure <ref> for some examples.

sentence: Let λ= max(λ(0.3, 0.6, 2), e^2 ). A component shall be deemed small if it has diameter less than λ√(log n). Two small components shall be deemed close if they contain two points lying at a distance less than 8λ√(log n) from one another.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Given x ∈Γ, let the global counting function X(x)=X_n,k(x) be the random variable taking the value 1 if there is a connected component H in S_n,k such that H has diameter less than λ√(log n) and x is the (almost surely unique) member of ℤ^2 closest to the (almost surely unique) bottom-most vertex of H.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Natural sequence d=(d_1,...,d_n) is called generating if ∑_i=1^n
d_i=2(n-1). Let 𝒯(d):={T∈𝒯(V): d_T=d} denote the
collection of trees with degree sequence d.

sentence: Let ℓ be a finite sequence in the set ∪{-∞}. We say that ℓ is a leaf sequence if there exists a simple graph G such that the sequence of values of its leaf function L_G is equal to ℓ, i.e. if  ℓ = (L_G(i))_i=0,1,2,…, G.

sentence:
A pure simplicial complex Δ 
is called vertex decomposable if


  * Δ is a simplex, or 

  * there is some vertex v ∈ V such that Δ∖ v and 
link_Δ(v) are vertex decomposable.

sentence: Let R _2 be a Unique Factorization Domain (UFD)[That is, R is a commutative ring with unit, without zero divisors, where every element can be decomposed as a product of irreducible elements in a unique way (up to order and associates).]. Then for every free R-module M, we have that M ↛ (1)_2^ (and a fortiori , M↛(κ)_2^ for every positive κ).

sentence:
Let a,b be weak compositions of length n. Let A and B be the words defined by A = (2n-1)^a_1⋯ (3)^a_n-1 (1)^a_n and B = (2n)^b_1⋯ (4)^b_n-1 (2)^b_n. Define the shuffle set of a and b , denoted by (a,b), by
  
    (a,b) = { C ∈ A  B |_A(C) ≥ a _B(B) ≥ b },

  where _A(C)_i (respectively _B(C)_i) is the number of letters from A (respectively B) in the ith increasing run of C.

sentence:
Let X_n = {x_1, x_2, … ,x_n} and Y_n = {y_1, y_2, … ,y_n}. Then the space of diagonal harmonics , DH_n, is the vector space of polynomials in these variables, f(X_n, Y_n), which satisfy

    ∂ ^a _x_1∂ ^b _y_1 f(X_n, Y_n) + ∂ ^a _x_2∂ ^b _y_2 f(X_n, Y_n) + ⋯ + ∂ ^a _x_n∂ ^b _y_n f(X_n, Y_n) = 0
for all a,b≥ 0 and a+b>0. That is, 

    DH_n = { f(X_n, Y_n) ∈ℂ [X_n, Y_n] ∑ _i=1^n∂ ^a _x_i∂ ^b _y_i f(X_n, Y_n) = 0, ∀ a,b≥ 0, a+b>0}.

sentence: [] If π is a parking function, then its area is the number of complete squares between the Dyck path of π and y=x, denoted by (π).

sentence: [] If π is a parking function, then its word is the permutation in one-line notation obtained by reading cars from the diagonal furthest from y=x to the diagonal y=x, and within a diagonal reading from right to left. We denote this by (π).

sentence: Two points a/b, c/d∈^∞ (given in lowest terms) are called -distinct if ad-bc = ± 1.

sentence:
[ Perfect matchings and weights ]
A perfect matching of a graph G is a subset P of the 
edges of G such that
each vertex of G is incident to exactly one edge of P. 
If the edges of  a perfect matching P of  
G_T^∘, are labeled τ_j_1,…,τ_j_r, then 
we define the weight x(P) of P to be 
x_τ_j_1… x_τ_j_r.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[ Minimal and Maximal Matchings ]  
By induction on the number of tiles it is easy to see that 
G_T^∘,  
has  precisely two perfect matchings which we call
the minimal matching P_-=P_-(G_T^∘,) and 
the maximal matching P_+
=P_+(G_T^∘,), 
which contain only boundary edges.
To distinguish them, 
if  rel(G̃_1,T^∘)=1 (respectively, -1),
we define 
e_1 and e_2 to be the two edges of 
G_T^∘, which lie in the counterclockwise 
(respectively, clockwise) direction from 
the diagonal of G̃_1.  Then  P_- is defined as
the unique matching which contains only boundary 
edges and does not contain edges e_1 or e_2.  P_+
is the other matching with only boundary edges.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let m≥ 0 and n≥ 0. Then the lollipop symmetric function is given by X_L_m,n, that is, the chromatic symmetric function of L_m,n.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let n be a positive integer and L a skew (p, q)-leaper with p < q. Then the leaper graph of L over W_n(L) is trivial and the direction graph extracted from it depends only on n. We refer to this direction graph as the pinwheel direction graph W_n of order n.

(The above continues to apply to non-skew leapers L in the sense that the leaper graph of L over W_n(L) is an instantiation of W_n.)

The pinwheel direction graph of order n is a dual direction graph of complement π_Pinwheel(W_n) when n is odd, where 
    π_Pinwheel = ([        ;         ])
 is the equivalence permutation induced by the unit 2 × 2 matrix and ( [  0  1; -1  0 ]), and π_Reflect∘π_Pinwheel(W_n) when n is even, and duality matrix A^Pinwheel_n.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A (p, q)-leaper L is basic if p + q is odd and p and q are relatively prime.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let F be an (m, n)-frame, m < n, and H an (n, 2n - m)-frame. Place F and H so that their centers coincide. (Or, equivalently, so that their inner contours coincide.) We define the transformation g, lifting F to H, as follows.

A g-translation is any of the eight translations corresponding to a move of a (0, n - m)-leaper or an (n, n)-leaper. Given a direction i, we write v^g_i for the g-translation pointing in direction i. For instance, v^g_ = (n - m, 0) and v^f_ = (n, n).

Let S be a subset of the squares of F. Then g(S) is a subset of the core of H, the disjoint union of 
    (S + v^g_i) ∩ H_i
 when i ranges over , , …, .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The direction matrix of a move of a skew (p, q)-leaper L, p < q, of direction i from a square a to a square b = a + v is the unique matrix A_i out of the following eight, 
    A_   = ([ 0 1; 1 0 ]),     A_   = ([ 1 0; 0 1 ]),
     A_   = ([ -1  0;  0  1 ]),     A_   = ([  0 -1;  1  0 ]),
     A_   = ([  0 -1; -1  0 ]),     A_   = ([ -1  0;  0 -1 ]),
     A_   = ([  1  0;  0 -1 ]),     A_   = ([  0  1; -1  0 ]),
 such that 
    v^T = A_i([ p; q ]).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A labeled oriented graph Ψ represents a direction graph Φ if Ψ is obtained from Φ by removing exactly one arc out of each symmetric pair.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A direction graph Φ is coherent if, for every pair of vertices x and y in the same connected component of Φ, the distance from x to y in Φ equals the zero matrix if and only if x and y coincide, and a direction matrix if and only if x and y are joined by an arc.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let n be a positive integer, d a nonnegative integer, and L a (p, q)-leaper with q ≠ 0.

Let W^I_n, d(L) be the board formed by all squares of N^I(L) whose centers lie on the boundary or in the interior of the rectangle R^I_n, d(L) bounded by 
    p - 2dq ≤ x + y ≤ p + 2(n + d)q
 and 
    -(2n + 2d - 1)q ≤ y - x ≤ (2n + 2d - 1)q.


Let R^i_n, d(L) and W^i_n, d(L), for i = II, III, and IV, be the rotations of R^I_n, d(L) and W^I_n, d(L) by 90^∘, 180^∘, and 270^∘ counterclockwise about O.

Then the expanded pinwheel board of order n and margin d for L, W_n, d(L), is the (disjoint if p < q) union of its four wings W^i_n, d(L), i = I, II, III, and IV.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given G=(V,E) and a threshold r, a set A_0⊆ V is called contagious if ⟨ A_0 ⟩=V. That is, activating A_0 results with the entire graph being activated.
The minimal cardinality of a contagious set in G is denoted in G by m(G,r).
The number of generations of a (not necessarily contagious) set A_0 which we denote by τ:=τ(A_0) is the minimal integer such that
⋃_i ≤τA_i=⟨ A_0 ⟩.

Given a toggle order H, define T_H^i to be the toggle group action that is the product of all t_p for p∈ P such that H(p)=i.

sentence: Given a word w=w_1⋯ w_n where the letters w_i are taken from some totally ordered alphabet A, a descent of w is an index i for which w_i>w_i+1.  The major index of w, denoted (w), is the sum of the descents of w.

sentence:
Given a word w=w_1⋯ w_n of positive integers, a Knuth move consists of either:
    
    
  * A transposition of the form xyz→ xzy where x,y,z are consecutive letters and y<x≤ z or z<x≤ y
    
  * A transposition of the form xyz→ yxz where x,y,z are consecutive letters and x≤ z<y or y≤ z<x.
     
    Two words w,w are said to be Knuth equivalent , written w w, if one can be reached from the other via a sequence of Knuth moves.  Knuth equivalence is an equivalence relation on words.

sentence: The cocharge contribution _(i,j)(σ) of an entry σ(i,j) of a filling σ is the number of descents that occur weakly below the entry (i,j) in its column, j.

sentence:
[shadow representation]
Let G=(V,E) be a multitolerance graph, R
be a trapezoepiped representation of G, and V_B,V_U be the sets of
bounded and unbounded vertices of G in R, respectively. We associate the
vertices of G with points and line segments in the plane as follows:



  * for every v∈ V_B, the points p_v,1=(a_v,Δ -ϕ
_v,1) and p_v,2=(d_v,Δ -ϕ _v,2) and the line segment 
L_v=(p_v,1,p_v,2),


  * for every v∈ V_U, the point p_v=(a_v,Δ -ϕ_v)
.


The tuple (𝒫,ℒ), where ℒ={L_v:v∈
V_B} and 𝒫={p_v:v∈ V_U}, is the shadow
representation of G. If ϕ _v,1=ϕ _v,2 for every v∈ V_B,
then (𝒫,ℒ) is the horizontal shadow
representation of the tolerance graph G. Furthermore, the representation (𝒫,ℒ) is canonical if the initial trapezoepiped
representation R is also canonical.

sentence:

For an arbitrary point t=(t_x,t_y)∈ℝ^2
the shadow of t is the region S_t={(x,y)∈ℝ
^2:x≤ t_x, y-x≤ t_y-t_x}. Furthermore, for every line
segment L_u, where u∈ V_B, the shadow of L_u is the
region S_u=⋃_t∈ L_uS_t.

D∩𝒫, and

sentence:
Let H and G be graphs.
	G is H-saturated
		if G contains no copy of H
		and for every edge e ∈ E(G) 
		there is at least one copy of H in G+e.
	G is uniquely H-saturated
		if G contains no copy of H
		and for every edge e ∈ E(G),
		there is a unique copy of H in G + e.

maximal cones have constant dimension d. An order C_1,…,C_m
of the maximal cones in  is called a shelling if
C_i∩(C_1∪…∪ C_i-1) is a union of facets of C_i
for all i.

sentence:
[The Cathedral Construction] 
Let G_0 be a saturated elementary graph 
and let {G_S}_S∈G_0 be a family of saturated graphs, 
some of which might be empty. 
For each S∈𝒫(G_0), 
join every vertex in S and every vertex of G_S.
We call this operation the cathedral construction . 
Here G_0 and {G_S}_S∈G_0 
are respectively called  
the foundation and the family of towers . 

0
Let G_0 be a saturated elementary graph.
For each class S∈𝒫(G_0), assign an saturated graph G_S, which might be empty,
and join every vertex in S and every vertex of G_S.
We call this operation cathedral construction .

sentence: Let G and H be graphs. Then H is a retract of G if and only if there exist homomorphisms ρ : G⟶ H and γ:H⟶ G such that ρ∘γ=id_H. The homomorphic ρ is called a retraction and γ a co-retraction .

sentence:
Let H be a graph and v a looped vertex of H. The local complement of H at v, denoted by H*v, is the graph obtained from H by complementing the subgraph induced by N_H(v).

In other words, for all p ⊆ V(H) = V(H*v) with |p| ∈{1,2}, we have p ∈ E(H*v) if and only if either (1) p ∉ E(H) and p ⊆ N_H(v) or (2) p ∈ E(H) and p ⊈N_H(v).

sentence:
The shifted raising operators , denoted by e_i, act on semistandard shifted tableaux by: e_i(T)=0 if m_i(w(T),k) = m_i(w(T)); otherwise, letting q be the largest index such that m_i(w(T),q) = m_i(w(T)), letting x denote the entry of T corresponding to w_q, and letting y be the entry south of x and z the entry west of x, we have
    
    
  (R1) 
    
  (a) if x=i+1 and z=i+1, then e_i changes x to i+1 and changes z to i;
    
  (b) else if x=i+1 and y does not exist or y < i, then e_i changes x to i
    
  (c) else if x=i+1 then e_i changes x to i+1 and changes the first entry i+1 southwest along the i+1-ribbon containing x that is not above an i or i+1 to i;
    
      
      
        
          [                               2    2 
      y                                        R1(a)↦                               1     2 
     y                               z     2 
     y                                        R1(b)↦                               z    1 
      y z      2     2 
          2 
          2    2                                        R1(c)↦  z     2     2  
           2
         1    2 ]
        
        An illustration of the shifted raising operators with x=i=1.
      
      
    
  (R2) 
    
  (a) if x=i+1 and y = i, then e_i changes x to i and changes y to i;
    
  (b) else if x=i+1 and z does not exist or z < i, then e_i changes x to i;
    
  (c) else if x=i+1, and the northeastern-most cell on the (i)-ribbon containing z is not on the main diagonal, then e_i adds a marking to that cell and changes x to i;
    
  (d) else if x=i+1, then e_i changes x to i.
    
      
      
        
          [                           z      2 
     1                                     R2(a)↦                           z     1 
      1                            z    2 
      y                                     R2(b)↦                            z    1 
      y 1 
 1     1     1     2 
         1      y                                     R2(c)↦   1 
 1     1     1     1 
              y ]
        
        An illustration of the shifted raising operators with x=i=1.

such that x_i_j=y_i_j>0 for j ∈ [t].

sentence:
[Kostochka et al. <cit.>]

Consider an n-vertex (d+1)-uniform hypergraph H such that every d-tuple of vertices is contained in at most t=O(1) edges,
and apply the following procedure:


  * let X be the subset of vertices obtained by choosing each vertex independently at random with probability p, such that
pn = ( n/(t logloglog n) )^3/(3d-1),

  * remove the minimum number of vertices of X so that the resulting subset Y induces a triangle-free linear[A hypergraph is linear if it has no pair of distinct edges sharing two or more vertices.] hypergraph H[Y].

Then with high probability H[Y] has an independent set of size at least ( n/tlogn/t)^1/d.

sentence:
Let the set Cov be

    Cov:= { (α, β, γ_1, …, γ_2g-2)∈ S_d×⋯× S_d | β^-1α^-1βα = γ_1⋯γ_2g-2,


    γ_i ⟨α, β, γ_1, …, γ_2g-2⟩ } .
 
There is an equivalence relation ∼ among elements in Cov: 

    (α, β, γ_1, …, γ_2g-2) ∼ (α', β', γ'_1, …, γ'_2g-2 )
 if and only if there exists τ∈ S_d
such that τ (α, β, γ_1, …, γ_2g-2) τ^-1 = (α', β', γ'_1, …, γ'_2g-2).
Moreover, let N = |Cov/∼| denote the cardinality of the set Cov modulo the equivalence relation.

sentence:
In a fixed border-strip decomposition, a border-strip B_a is above a border-strip B_b if there is 
a path from B_a to B_b going only down or right. In this case B_b is below B_a.

c(p,L) such that, for every locally-L pair (Γ,G), the largest p-th power dividing the order of an arc-stabiliser is bounded above by c(p,L).

sentence:
An edge contraction is a surjective simplicial map f K→ L between
simplicial complexes such that every vertex of L has only one preimage, apart
from one vertex, whose preimage is an edge, v*w (written here as the join of
its vertices).
We call f an elementary edge-zipping if any of the following equivalent
conditions hold:



  * (v)∩(w)=(v*w);

  * v*w is not contained in any “missing face” of K, i.e. in
an isomorphic copy of ∂Δ^n in K that does not extend to
an isomorphic copy of Δ^n in K;

  * the PL map triangulated by f is collapsible.


We say that a simplicial complex K edge-zips onto a simplicial complex L
if there exists a sequence of elementary edge-zippings K=K_0→…→ K_n=L.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A flag complex is a simplicial complex K such that every subcomplex of
K that is isomorphic to the boundary of a simplex of dimension >1 is
the boundary of some simplex of K.
Obviously, every full subcomplex of a flag complex is a flag complex.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O B-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
An affine polytopal complex (compare <cit.>) is a countable conditionally complete poset K where to every
σ∈ K there is associated an isomorphism of σ with
the poset of non-empty faces of a convex polytope P_σ (compare
Example <ref>) so that every face inclusion τσ
is realized by an affine isomorphism between P_τ and the face of
P_σ corresponding to τ.
This includes cubical and simplicial complexes as special cases.
Every affine polytopal complex is atomic since the poset of nonempty faces of
every convex polytope is.
Affine polytopal complexes are not equivalent to “cell complexes” in the sense
of Rourke–Sanderson <cit.>, who additionally require linear embeddability
into some Euclidean space.
For instance, the cubulation of the Möbius band into 3 squares is an
affine polytopal complex (and a cubical complex) but not a cell complex
in the sense of <cit.> (see <cit.>).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Suppose we have a covariant [resp. contravariant] commutative diagram,
indexed by a poset Λ, consisting of posets P_λ=(𝒫_λ,≤),
λ∈Λ, and monotone maps f_λμ P_λ→ P_μ whenever
λ>μ [resp. λ<μ] in Λ.
Then the homotopy colimit _Λ (P_λ,f_λμ)
is the preposet Q=(𝒬,≤), where
𝒬=_λ∈Λ𝒫_λ,
and given a p∈𝒫_λ and a q∈𝒫_μ, we have p≥ q
in Q if and only if either λ=μ and p≥ q in P_λ, or
λ>μ and there exists a p'∈𝒫_λ such that p'≤ p in
P_λ and f_λμ(p')=q [resp. there exists a q'∈𝒫_μ
such that q'≥ q in P_μ and f_μλ(q')=p].
If the maps f_λμ are closed [resp. open], it is clear that
_Λ(P_λ,f_λμ) is a poset.
Clearly, MC(P_nf_n…f_2P_1)=_[n](P_i,f_ij),
where f_ij P_i→ P_j is the composition P_if_i…f_j+1P_j.
Similarly MC^*(P_nf_n…f_2P_1)=_[n]^*(P_i,f_ij).
In general, it is easy to see that every homotopy colimit indexed by a poset
is in fact an iterated amalgam of the iterated mapping cylinders.
Since every f_λ_mu is a single-valued (not multi-valued) map,
every subposet P_λ of _Λ (P_λ,f_λμ)
is full in the homotopy colimit.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O

    P = _i=1^r T_i  and

  (Here,  indicates disjoint union.)

    2Δ≅(0,e_1,…,e_i),

where e_1,…, e_n∈^n are the standard basis in ^n

sentence: A connected graph G of diameter d is called distance-regular if there are non-negative integers b_i, c_i (0≤ i ≤ d) such that for any two vertices x and y in G at distance i=d(x,y), there are precisely c_i neighbours of y in G_i-1(x) and b_i neighbours of y in G_i+1(x). Clearly, G is regular with degree r=b_0, b_d=c_0=0, and c_1=1. The sequence i(G)={r,b_1,…,b_d-1;1,c_2,…,c_d} is called the intersection array of G; and the numbers a_i, b_i, and c_i (i=0,…,d), where a_i=r-b_i-c_i, are called the intersection numbers of G.

sentence:
Let 𝒮 = (, , ) be a generalized polygon and let (·, ·) denote the distance function in the point graph of 𝒮. 


  * A partial distance-j ovoid of 𝒮 is a set of points  such that for every two distinct points x and y we have (x, y) ≥ j. 


  * A distance-j ovoid of 𝒮 is a partial distance-j ovoid  such that (1) for every point a of 𝒮 there exists a point x of 𝒪 such that (a, x) ≤ j/2; (2) for every line ℓ of 𝒮 there exists a point x ∈𝒪 such that (ℓ, x) ≤ (j - 1)/2.

sentence:
(Matroid Union Theorem)
Let M_1,…,M_k be matroids on the same ground set E, with rank functions r_1,…,r_k respectively. The following conditions are equivalent:


  * there exist sets V_i with V_1∪…∪ V_k=E, such that for each i the set V_i is independent in M_i,

  * for each A⊂ E holds r_1(A)+…+r_k(A)≥| A|.

for 1≤ x≤ r and λ^(0)=∅.

sentence:
[Polynomials]  Let P G → K be a function from one additive group G = (G,+) to another K = (K,+).  For any subgroup H of G and for any integer d, we say that P is a polynomial of degree <d along H according to the following recursive definition[Our conventions here are somewhat nonstandard, but are chosen so that the proofs of our main theorems, such as Theorem <ref>, resemble the proofs of warmup results such as Proposition <ref>.]:


  (i)  If d ≤ 0, we say that P is of degree <d along H if and only if it is identically zero.

  (ii)  If d ≥ 1, we say that P is of degree <d along H if and only if, for each h ∈ H, there exists a polynomial P_h: G → K of degree <d-1 along H such that 

    P(x+h) = P(x) + P_h(x)

for all x ∈ G.

where π0,π1,π1,π2,… = (π), with the convention π0={0} (see end of Section <ref>).

We say that the signed graph G' is obtained by switching G at v if the vertex and edge sets for G' are V(G) and E(G), while the sign map σ' for G' is given by

    σ'({i,j}):={[        -σ({i,j}) if  v=i  or  v=j;         σ({i,j})             else ].   .

If H is obtained from G by a finite sequence of switches, we say that G and H are switching equivalent .

sentence:

and let δ, R and k_0 be as in Definition <ref>.

we say that the branching process _Y,Z,Y^0,Z^0 is of type (t,η)
(with respect to (_t), δ, R, and k_0) 
if the following hold:

  
  *  Writing := {(y,z) ∈^2:   |y|,|z|<R}, 
the expectations
	
    (y,z):=g_Y,Z(y,z) = (y^Yz^Z)     and    ^0(y,z) := g_Y^0,Z^0(y,z) = (y^Y^0z^Z^0)

are defined (i.e., the expectations converge absolutely) for all (y,z) ∈.

  *  For all (y,z) ∈ we have

    |(y,z)-g_t(y,z)|≤η    and    
     |^0(y,z)-g^0_t(y,z)|  ≤η .
