sentence:
Let G be an embedded graph with embedded medial graph G_m.  Define the medial weight system W_m(G_m) using the canonical checkerboard colouring of G_m as follows.  A vertex v has state weights given by an ordered triple (α_v, β_v, γ_v), indicating the weights of the white split, black split, and crossing state, in that order. We write (α, β, γ) for the set of these ordered triples, indexed equivalently either by the vertices of G_m or by the edges of G.  Then the topological transition polynomial of G is:

    Q(G, (α, β, γ), t) :=q(G_m; W_m,t).

sentence:
[Skeletons]
  A skeleton is a  tree T that admits a black-red
  coloring λ of V(T), a sequence T_0,T_1, …, T_t of
  trees, and a sequence P_1, …,P_t of paths, each of which is a 4-path or a 6-path, 
  such that: 
  
  
  * T_0 is a 3-path, T_t = T, and
  for i∈[t] the tree T_i is obtained from T_i-1 by
  adding P_i so that the joint of P_i is identified
  with a vertex of T_i-1;
   
  * for T_0=x_0x_1x_2x_3, we have λ(x_0)= λ(x_3)= black 
  and λ(x_1)= λ(x_2)= red;
  
  * for each P_i=x_0⋯ x_k, i∈[t], it holds that
  λ(x_0)= λ(x_k)= black, λ(x_1)= λ(x_k-1)= red,
  if k=4, then x_k/2= red, 
  and if k=6, then x_k/2= black 
  and λ(x_2)=λ(x_4)= red.

sentence: A square path ending east of size n is a lattice paths going from (0,0) to (n,n) consisting of east or north unit steps, always ending with an east step. The set of such paths is denoted by (n). We call base diagonal of a square path the diagonal y=x+l with the smallest value of l that is touched by the path (so that l≤ 0). The shift of the square path is the non-negative value -l. We refer to the line x=y as the main diagonal . A Dyck path is a square path whose shift is 0, i.e. its base diagonal is the main diagonal. The set of Dyck paths is denoted by (n). Of course (n)⊆(n).

sentence:
[Weak AMD code] 


Suppose (, , , E) is an AMD code.


  * The value Δ∈∖{0} is chosen according to the adversary's strategy.


  * The source s ∈ is chosen uniformly at random by the encoder
(i.e., we have equiprobable sources).

  * The source is encoded into g ∈ A(s) using the encoding function E.

  * The adversary  wins if and only if g + Δ∈ A(s') for some s' ≠ s.

The success probability of the strategy σ, denoted 
ϵ_σ, is the probability that the adversary wins this game using the
specific strategy σ.

We will say that the code (, , , E) is a weak (m,n,)-AMD code where
 denotes the success probability of the adversary's optimal 
strategy.
That is, 

    = max _σ{ϵ_σ} .

sentence:
[External difference family]
Let  be an additive abelian group of order n.
An (n,m,k,λ)-external difference family (or (n,m,k,λ)-EDF)
is a set of m disjoint k-subsets of , say A_1, … , A_m, such that
the following multiset equation holds:

    ⋃ _{ i,j : i ≠ j}^(A_i,A_j)  = λ (∖{0}).

sentence:
[Generalized strong external difference family]
Let  be an additive abelian group of order n.
An (n,m;k_1, … , k_m;λ_1, … , λ_m)-generalized strong external difference family 
(or (n,m;k_1, … , k_m;λ_1, … , λ_m)-GSEDF)
is a set of m disjoint subsets of , say A_1, … , A_m, such that
|A_i| = k_i for 1 ≤ i ≤ m and 
the following multiset equation holds for every i, 1 ≤ i ≤ m:

    ⋃ _{ j : j ≠ i}^(A_i,A_j)   = λ_i (∖{0}).

sentence:
[Strongly quadrangular matrix]We say that an m× n {0,1}-matrix
X=[X_i,j] is row strongly quadrangular ( RSQ ) if there does
not exist R⊆{1,2,...,m} with | R|≥2 such
that, defining R^'={k:X_i,kX_j,k=1 for some i≠ j in R},
we have | R^'| <| R| and
X_R^R^' has no zero-rows. We say that an m× n
{0,1}-matrix X is strongly quadrangular ( SQ ) if both X
and X^T are RSQ.

sentence:
[s-monotonicity]
Given s ≥ 1 and λ∈, we say that λ is
s-monotone if:


  (i) λ_1 ≤(λ) + 1, and

  (ii) its energy sequence e = (λ) satisfies the
inequality


    e_j ≤ e_i + 1     ∀  i < j ≤ i + s


(notice that the first requirement λ_1 ≤(λ) + 1 is
redundant if s≥ 2).

It is convenient to introduce also the (void) notion of 0-monotonicity,
satisfied by all mancala configurations.

sentence:
Let T be a proper triangle of size 2^k in  for some k≥ 1,
	and let ∂ T = {a, b, c)},
	for some  a,b,c∈^+. Without loss of generality we can assume b = a + (2^k,0) and c = a +(0,2^k).
	The midpoints of T are then given by
	
    A    = (b+c)/2 = a + (2^k-1, 2^k-1) 
    
    	B    = (a+c)/2 = a + (0, 2^k-1),
    
    	C    =(a+b)/2  = a + (2^k-1,0).

For proper triangles which are subsets of ^- the midpoints are
defined analogously. See Figure <ref> for a diagram of a proper triangle.

sentence:
Let T=(G,S,L) be a canvas and L_0 be a set of two colors. Let C be the boundary of the outer face of G. Suppose that P=p_1… p_k is an induced path in C such that, for every vertex v in P, v is not the end of a chord of C or a cutvertex of C,
åV(C) V(P), and L_0⊆ L(v). If k≥ 2, let x be the vertex of C adjacent to p_1 other than p_2 and y be the vertex of C adjacent to p_k other than p_k-1. If k=1, let x and y be the two neighbors of p_1 on C. We assume that L(x)- L_0∅. 

We define the democratic reduction of P in T with respect to L_0 and centered at x, denoted as T(P,L_0,x), as (G∖ V(P),S',L') where L'(w)=L(w)- L_0 if either w=x, or w y is a neighbor of a vertex in P, and L'(w)=L(w) otherwise; and S'=S∖ V(P) if |L'(x)|≥ 3 and otherwise let S' be obtained from S∖ V(P) by adding x as an isolated vertex.

sentence:
[Government]

Let ={ϕ_1, ϕ_2, …, ϕ_k}, k≥ 2, be a collection of disjoint proper colorings of a path P=p_1p_2 of length one. For p∈ P, let (p) denote the set {ϕ(p)|ϕ∈}.

We say  is a dictatorship if there exists i∈{1,2} such that ϕ_j(p_i) is the same for all 1≤ j≤ k, in which case, we say p_i is the dictator of . We say  is a democracy if k=2 and ϕ_1(p_1)=ϕ_2(p_2) and ϕ_2(p_1)=ϕ_1(p_2). We say  is a government if  is a dictatorship or a democracy.

sentence:
Given a partition, we read off the path formed by the boundary of its Ferrers diagram from top right to bottom left as a boundary word , where a 1 records a step left and a 0 records a step down.

If we are further given a positive integer (k+1), we may form an abacus display with (k+1) runners (labeled 0,1,…,k) by breaking the boundary word into consecutive runs of length (k+1) and then stacking them.  Given a (k+1)-core contained in R_k,{i_1,i_2,…,i_m-1}, we will choose the particular representative of it as an abacus display with (k+1) runners by forcing the first zero of the boundary word to lie in the leftmost column.

sentence:
[Definitions for Parity Proof Framework]
We proceed with further definitions.  Suppose we have a label set that can be partitioned into pairs of opposite labels.  We say such a label set is strictly symmetric .  Define a labelling ℓ to be an unordered, unoriented way of labelling a simplex, i.e. a multi-set of labels.  There is a natural notion of an opposite labelling -ℓ, where we take the opposite of each label in the multi-set.  We use i-labelling to refer to the labelling of an i-simplex, i.e. a multi-set of i+1 labels.  Let L^i denote the set of i-labellings.  Note that L^i may not be strictly symmetric even though the label set is strictly symmetric, e.g. labelling {+e_1,-e_1} is its own opposite.

Now we define the set of forbidden labellings F⊆⋃_i=0^n L^i.  (Assume F∩ L^0=∅; otherwise we would just make the label set smaller.)  In the case of Tucker's lemma, F is the set of labellings with a complementary edge.  In the case of Theorem <ref>, F is the set of labellings with a neutral simplex.  The idea is to choose F's such that L^i\ F is strictly symmetric for all 0≤ i≤ n.  That is, F must be symmetric and contain all the labellings which are their own opposite.

If M^i is a strictly symmetric subset of i-labellings, then from each pair of opposite labellings, we can choose one to be the `+' labelling and the other to be the `-' labelling.  Let M^i_+,M^i_- denote the set of +,- labellings, respectively.  We call M^i_+∪ M^i_- a partitioning of M^i.

sentence:
Let A and B be disjoint sets of size r, where r ≥ 3.  A
  bipartite digraph Δ with bipartition {A, B} is a
  critical graph if there are subsets X of A and Y of B
  such that
  
  
  * |X| + |Y| = r + 1,
  
  * for all x∈ X and y∈ Y, exactly one of (x,y) and
    (y,x) is in E(Δ),
  
  * if (u,v)∈ E(Δ), then {u,v}⊆ X∪ Y, and
  
  * no element of X∪ Y is a source or sink of Δ.

sentence:
Let M be a matroid, and let 0 ≤ k ≤ r(M) and 0 ≤ l ≤
  r(M) with k+l>0.  We say M is (k,l)-base-orderable if,
  given any two bases B_1 and B_2, there is a bijection σ B_1 → B_2 so that for every X ⊆ B_1 with |X| ≤
  k or |X| ≥ r(M) - l, the set (B_1 - X) ∪σ(X) is a
  basis.

sentence:
A Stirling s-permutation is a multipermutation of 
{1^s(1),2^s(2),…, a^s(a)}
that avoids the pattern 212. 
A 312-avoiding Stirling s-permutation is a multipermutation of the same multiset that avoids both patterns 212 and 312. We denote by _s the set of Stirling s-permutations, and by _s(312) the set of 312-avoiding Stirling s-permutations.

For s ∈, a complete 
noncrossing s-matching in 
_|s| is a 
noncrossing partition M of the set [|s|] such that M satisfies |M_i|=s(i) when we order 
the blocks of M={M_1<M_2<… <M_a} in the minimal order (such that min M_i < min M_j 
whenever i<j). We denote by _s the set of complete noncrossing s-matchings.

sentence:
Let G and H be games,



  * Equality of games: G = H if (∀ X)  α(G⊙ X)=α(H⊙ X).

  * Greater than: G ≥ H if (∀ X),  α(G⊙ X)≥α(H⊙ X).

where α represents a generic measure of winning.

sentence:
The disjunctive sum of two combinatorial games being played under simultaneous moves, means that each player chooses a component and plays a legal move in that component. 
 Formally, the set of options from G+H are as follows: 

    G+H =  
    { ^LG + H^R,   ^LG^R+H,  G^R +  ^LH,   G +  ^LH^R},
         if ^ℒG or ^ℒH and G^ℛ or H^ℛ are non-empty;
    ∅,   otherwise.

Using Table <ref>, consider G = 1 + 2 + 3. The game is not terminal because Left has moves in 1, 2, and 3, while Right has moves in 2 and 3. 


The extended normal winning convention is: if G+H = ∅, then



  * Left wins if she has a move remaining, in G, H, or both, but Right does not. 

  * Right wins if he has a move remaining, in G, H, or both,  but Left does not. 

  * Otherwise the game is a Draw.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The conjunctive sum of two simultaneous combinatorial games, written G∧ H,
means that each player plays a legal move in all components.  Formally, the set of options from 
G∧ H are as follows: 

    G∧ H=  { ^L(G∧ H)^R} =
    {^LG^R∧ ^LH^R},  if  and   are non-empty; 
    ∅,  otherwise.


If K_1∧ K_2∧…∧ K_n= ∅, then this means that at least one of the components is terminal. The extended normal play winning convention becomes:



  * Left wins if she has an option in every terminal component, but Right does not. 

  * Right wins if he has an option in every terminal component, but Left does not. 

  * Otherwise the game is a Draw.

sentence:
The bias of a function f:V→ k is defined by 

    b(f)=bias(f)=|_xe_q(f(x))|.

sentence: A star rainbow coloring of a graph G with q colors is a function c:V(G) →{1,…,q} such that for each v ∈ V(G) no color occurs more than once in N[v]. The number of star rainbow colorings of G with q colors is denoted χ_sr(G;q).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A non-monochromatic coloring of a graph G with q colors is a function c:V(G) →{1,…,q} such that for each v ∈ V(G) there are at least two colors occurring in N[v]. The number of non-monochromatic colorings of G with q colors is denoted χ_nm(G;q).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let G_1=(V(G_1),E(G_1)) and G_2=(V(G_2),E(G_2)) two graphs with V(G_1)∩ V(G_2)=∅. The graph join G_1⊎ G_2 of G_1 and G_2 has V(G_1⊎ G_2)=V(G_1) ∪ V(G_2) and two different vertices u and v of G_1⊎ G_2 are adjacent if u∈ V(G_1) and v∈ V(G_2), or [u,v]∈ E(G_1) or [u,v]∈ E(G_2).

Let _1 and _2 be signed graphexes in L^1∩ L^2. Then we define

    (_1,_2)=
    22(_1',_2'),

where _1' and _2' are trivial extensions of _1 and _2 to
measure spaces of infinite total mass. We refer to (_1,_2) as
the kernel distance of _1 and _2 and call  the
kernel metric .

sentence:
Let π:C → L be a cover. The balancing
condition implies that for every point ã in L the sum

    ∑_a|π(a)= ã_π a

is the same. This number is called the degree (π) of π.

sentence: We say that a cover π:C → L is 3-valent , if C has only 3-valent vertices besides the leaves. We call the 3-valent vertices the ramification points of a cover and their images the branch points .

sentence:
Let Y be a Young diagram with k rows. 
If A and D are disjoint subsets of [k-1]
such that if i ∈ A ∪ D, then the ith and (i+1)st rows of Y
have the same length, then we call the triple 𝒴 = (Y, A, D) an
AD-Young diagram .
We call Y the Young diagram of 𝒴,
A the required ascent set of 𝒴, and D the required descent set of 𝒴.



*(clear)            

           

   

   

If Y = (4^2,2^2), A = ∅, and D = {3}, then (Y, A, D) is an AD-Young diagram.


See Figure <ref>.

sentence:
Let Δ be a (d-1)-dimensional simplicial complex
on the vertex set V(Δ).


  * A subset T of V(Δ) is called a clique if every
two vertices of T form an edge of Δ.

  * A clique  T ⊆ V(Δ) is critical
if T ∖{v} is a face of Δ for some v ∈ T.

  * For an 1 ≤ i ≤ d, we say that Δ is i-banner
if every critical clique T of size at least i+1 is a face of Δ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A factor of (X,,μ) is a triplet = (Y,,π), where Y is a set,  is a σ-algebra, and π: X → Y is a measurable map.  If  is a factor, we let _ := {π^-1(E): E ∈} be the sub-σ-algebra of  formed by pulling back  by π.  A function f: X → is said to be -measurable if it is measurable with respect to _.  If f ∈ L^2(X,,μ), we let (f|Y) = (f|_Y) be the orthogonal projection of f to the closed subspace L^2(X,_Y,μ) of L^2(X,,μ) consisting of -measurable functions.  If = (Y,,π) and ' = (Y',',π') are two factors, we let ∨' denote the factor (Y × Y', ⊗', π⊕π').

sentence:
The Ehrhart quasipolynomial of an rational polytope P in ℝ^n is defined to be:


    i(P, q) = # (qP ∩ℤ^n)


As in Definition <ref> it is a theorem of Ehrhart <cit.> that i(P,q) is indeed a quasipolynomial of degree n in q for integer values of q. Moreover, if kP is an integer polytope, then the period of i(P,q) divides k.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A tropical   plane in ℝ^3 is a two dimensional polyhedral complex with a unique vertex v, whose 1-skeleton consists of the raysv+ℝ_≥ 0 (-e_1), v+ℝ_≥ 0 (-e_2), v+ℝ_≥ 0 (-e_3), and  v+ℝ_≥ 0 (e_1+e_2+e_3). The maximal faces are the cones generated by each pair of rays. In other words, it is a translation of the 2-skeleton of the fan of the toric variety ℙ^3.

sentence:
A filter on a countable set G is a non-empty family p of subsets of G such that


  * ∅∉ p.

  * If A∈ p and A⊂ B then B∈ p.

  * If A and B are both in p then A∩ B∈ p.

If in addition p satisfies the following condition, then p is an ultrafilter .


  * A∈ p (G∖ A)∉ p.

sentence:
Let G,H be countable commutative semigroups and let Γ be a set of functions from H to G.
  We say that Γ is licit if for any f∈Γ and any z∈ H, there exists a function ϕ_z∈Γ such that f(y+z)=ϕ_z(y)+f(z).

    D(m_1,^(1),c_1; s_1)⊃ D(m_2,^(2),c_2; s_2).

sentence:
The histoire d'Hermite arising from exploring
  (p_1,…,p_n) from the left is the same as the
  histoire d'Hermite arising from (p_1,…,p_n)
  resulting from recording the nesting numbers on the up steps.

sentence: [Heart]  Let w be a non-empty finite word. Suppose that r is the longest (possibly empty) prefix of w such that |w|_x = 1 for all x ∈(r) and that s is the longest (possibly empty) suffix of w such that |w|_x = 1 for all x ∈(s). If |w| > |(w)|, then there exists a unique (non-empty) word v with  |v| < |w| such that w=rvs and we call v the heart of w. Otherwise, if |w| = |(w)|, then r=s=w and we define the heart of w to be itself.

sentence:
For r > 0 we define

    W^+(r) = {f(z) = ∑_n ≥ 0 a_n z^n ∈(D(0,r)) : ∑_n ≥ 0 |a_n| r^n < ∞}.

The space W^+ := W^+(1) is often known as the analytic Wiener algebra of analytic functions. The space W^+(r) can be seen as a weighted version of the analytic Wiener algebra.

sentence:
Let (M,·) be a semigroup.


  * Suppose that (M,·) is Hindman and  is a semigroup structure based on (M,·).  Then for every -definable X⊆ M that is IIP, there is a nonprincipal idempotent type containing the formula X(x).

  * Suppose that for every semigroup structure  based on (M,·) and every -definable X⊆ M that is IIP, there is a nonprincipal idempotent type containing X(x).  Then (M,·) is really Hindman, meaning that whenever X⊆ M is IIP and X=Y∪ Z, then one of Y or Z is DIP.

sentence: Let p be a valuated matroid, and let σ be a (d-1)-sized subset of [e]. We define p(σ*) to be the vector in ^e whose kth coordinate is p(σ∪{k}). We call p(σ*) a cocircuit of the valuated matroid p unless p(σ*)=(-∞,…,-∞). We often identify π(σ*) as an element of 𝕋ℙ^e-1.

sentence:
Suppose Σ={a_1<a_2<… < a_s} is an ordered alphabet and w=w_1w_2… w_n is a nonempty word of length n over Σ with w_i∈Σ for all 1≤ i≤ n. 
Define the Parikh graph of w over Σ , denoted 𝒢(w)= (V,E), with the set of vertices 

    V={  (a_i, l) | 1≤ i≤ s, | w|_a_i≥ 1,
     and   1≤ l≤| w|_a_i }

 and for all (a_i,l), (a_i',l')∈ V, there is an (undirected) edge between them if and only if 
    | i-i'|=1  and  (i-i')(_a_i(w,l)-_a_i'(w,l'))>0.

sentence:
A d× (d+1) matrix M with real entries is called
  positively spanning if all the values (-1)^i(M,i) are nonzero and have 
  the same sign, where (M,i) is the determinant of the square matrix
  obtained by removing the i-th column.

sentence:
An (n,d)-complex Γ is said to be
  regular if it is isomorphic to a (perhaps non-proper) subcomplex of a regular triangulation of some point
  configuration 𝒜⊂^d.

sentence:
For every composition α=(  α_1,α
_2,…,α_ℓ), we define a power series M_α
∈𝐤[  [  x_1,x_2,x_3,…]  ] by

    M_α=∑_1≤ i_1<i_2<⋯<i_ℓx_i_1^α_1
    x_i_2^α_2⋯ x_i_ℓ^α_ℓ

(where the sum is over all strictly increasing ℓ-tuples (
i_1<i_2<⋯<i_ℓ) of positive integers). It is well-known
(and easy to check) that this M_α belongs to *QSym
_𝐤. The power series M_α is called the
monomial quasisymmetric function corresponding to α. The
family (  M_α)  _α∈*Comp is a
basis of the 𝐤-module *QSym_𝐤;
this is the so-called monomial basis of *QSym
_𝐤. (See <cit.> and <cit.> for
more about this basis.)

sentence: Let m,v ≥ 2 be integers. An m-modular symmetric design is a v × v (0,1)-matrix D satisfying that DD^⊤≡ (k - λ) I + λ J m and that DJ ≡ JD ≡ kJ for some integers k,λ, and where J is the v × v matrix of all 1's. Such a design is denoted by its parameters (v,k,λ;m).

sentence:
[Brion's Theorem]

Let P be a polyhedron in the nonnegative orthant _≥ 0^d. For each vertex v⃗ of P, define its vertex cone C_v⃗ to be the set of points in ^d satisfied by those inequalities defining P that are equalities at v⃗. Then 

    ∑_s⃗∈ P∩^dx⃗^s⃗=∑_v⃗ a vertex of P ∑_s⃗∈ C_v⃗∩_dx⃗^s⃗.

sentence:
Given a board of size (4,m), an open tour is called a 4 × m 
extender if the tour  starts at (4,m) and ends at
(4,m-1).

sentence:
Let P be a poset. A subdivision of the cover relation x<:y
  in P is the addition of new points z_1,z_2,…,z_l such that
  x<z_1<…<z_l<y and the new points z_i are incomparable with
  all points of P that are not greater than y or less than x. We
  say that Q is a subdivision of P if Q can be
  constructed from P by subdividing some of its cover relations.

sentence:
[Strong stability]
	A family of graphical degree sequences 𝒟 is called strongly stable if there exists a constant ℓ such that k_JS(d) ≤ℓ for all d ∈𝒟.

sentence:
A traversal of the mountain P on  {a,…,b} is a sequence (0,t) = (i_1,j_1),…,(i_k,j_k) = (t,b) with the properties 


  * |i_r - i_r+1| = |j_r - j_r+1| = 1,

  * P(i_r) + P(j_r) = P(t),

  * a ≤ i_r ≤ t and t ≤ j_r ≤ b,

for all 1 ≤ r ≤ k-1. We always assume that a traversal is minimal, in the sense that there is no subsequence of (0,t) = (i_1,j_1),…,(i_k,j_k) = (t,b) which is also a traversal.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[graphs and related concepts]
A (simple) graph is a pair (V,E) of a set V, 
whose elements are called vertices ,
and a set E of 2-subsets of V, 
called edges . 
Two vertices in the same edge are called neighbor , or adjacent ,
to each other. The number of neighbors of a vertex is referred to as its degree .
A graph whose vertices have the same degree is called regular .
An isomorphism between two graphs is a bijection between their vertices that induces
a bijection between the edges.
Two graphs are isomorphic if there is an isomorphism between them.
An automorphism of a graph is an isomorphism to itself.
A set of vertices of a graph is called independent if it does not 
include any edge.

sentence: [Kautz graph] The Kautz graph _n(m) has (m+1)m^n-1 vertices, identified with the Kautz strings of length n on m+1 symbols. The edges of the graph are labeled with the Kautz strings of length n+1 on m+1 symbols, such that the edge s_0s_1… s_n has source s_0s_1… s_n-1 and target s_1s_2… s_n.

sentence:
[(D,p,m)-bounded order] 
  Let H be a graph given with buffer sets ={_i}_i∈[r] and
  a restriction pair ={I_i}_i∈[r] and ={J_i}_i∈[r].
  Let =⋃_i∈[r]_i.
  Let τ be an ordering of V(H) and X^e⊂ V(H).
  Then τ is a (D,p,m)-bounded order for H, ,
   and 
  with exceptional set X^e if the following conditions are
  satisfied for each x∈ V(H).
  
   
  *  Define 
    D_x:=
           D-2    if there is yz∈ E(H) with y,z∈ N_H(x) and τ(y),τ(z)>τ(x)
    
           D-1    else if there is y∈ N_H(x) with τ(y)>τ(x)
    
           D    otherwise .

     We have (x)≤ D_x, and if x∈ N() even (x)≤ D_x-1. Finally, if x∈ we have (x)≤ D.
    
  *  One of the following holds:
      
        
  * x∈ X^e,
        
  * (x)≤1/2 D,
        
  * x is not image restricted and every neighbour y of x
          with τ(y)<τ(x) satisfies τ(x)-τ(y)≤ p^(x)m.
      
    
  *  If x∈ N() then all but at most D-1-max_z∉X^e(z)
      neighbours y of x with τ(y)<τ(x) satisfy
      τ(x)-τ(y)≤ p^D m.

sentence: We say that f is a Freiman homomorphism if whenever a quadruple a,b,c,d ∈ A satisfies a-b=c-d then ϕ(a)-ϕ(b)=ϕ(c)-ϕ(d).

sentence:
Let U=(X,B) be an abstract unital of order n and k≥ 3 and integer. We say that the blocks b_1,…,b_k form an embedded dual k-net in U, if the following hold for all 1≤ i<j≤ k:


  * b_i∩ b_j=∅.

  * For all P∈ b_i, Q∈ b_j, the block containing P,Q intersects all b_1,…,b_k in a point.

sentence:
Let v be a vertex of degree three in G and C be the component of D_3(G) containing v.



  * If |C|=1, then v sends +1/6 charge to each neighbor.

  * If |C|=2, then v sends +1/4 charge to each neighbor of degree at least four.

  * If C has diameter two, then v sends to each neighbor of degree at least four



  * +1/6 charge if v is a non-leaf vertex,

  * +1/3 charge if v is a leaf vertex. 



  * If C has diameter three, then v sends to each neighbor of degree at least four


  * +1/4 charge if v is a non-leaf vertex,

  * +3/8 charge if v is a leaf vertex. 




Let ^*(v) denote the final charge of v after applying the above discharging rules.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
[k-point correlation estimates]  
Let us say that a majorant satisfies the k-point correlation estimates if for any distinct m_1, …, m_l with l ≤ k we have

    ∑_n ν(n+m_1) …ν(n+m_l) ≪ N.

sentence:
We say that a sequence Γ={ S_1,…,S_N} of subsets of a set V with n elements is legal if it satisfies the following axioms:


  0. The only legal sequence on 0 elements is {∅}.

  1. Γ is convex, meaning that S_i∩ S_k⊂ S_j for all i<j<k.

  2. Every proper subsequence of Γ is legal.

  3. If an element a∈ V is not used at all in Γ, then Γ is a legal sequence on n-1 elements.


  4. If an element a belongs to every S_i then there are subsets S_i'⊂ S_i∖{a} such that {S_1',…,S_N'} is a legal sequence on n-1 elements.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let X∈ C be a facet and S⊂ V be a set of vertices in a pure and normal simplicial (d-1)-complex C with vertex set V. 
Let x∈ X. We say that a facet path (X=X_0,X_1,…,X_N) is a combinatorial segment from X to S anchored at x if either:


  * S∩ X∅ (in particular, x∈ X∩ S) and N=0. That is, the path is just (X). (Distance zero).

  * d=1, S∩ X=∅ and N=1, so that the path is (X,{v}) for a v∈ S. (Dimension zero).


  * d>1, S∩ X=∅ and the following holds. 


  * X_N is the unique facet in the path intersecting S.

  * Let δ=_C(X,S). Let X_k be the first facet in Γ with _C(X_k,S)<δ and let y∈ X_k be the unique
vertex with _C(y,S)=_C(X_k,S)=δ-1. (That is, let y be the only element of X_k∖ X_k-1).
Then x∈ X_0∩ X_1∩…∩ X_k and  the link of x in Γ_1:=(X_0,…,X_k) is a combinatorial segment in _C(x)
from the facet X∖ x to the set {z∈ V: _C(z,x)=1, _C(z,S)=δ-1}.


  * Γ_2:=(X_k,…,X_N) is a combinatorial segment from X_k to S in C anchored at y.

sentence:
We call a triple of pairs

    {.  (p_i,q_i)∈ℤ^2| 1≤
    i≤3}  , 0≤ p_i<q_i, with (p_i,q_i)=1,∀
    i∈{1,2,3},

sentence:
Let W be any non-empty finite set (for example /N). Define a
factor (or σ-algebra) to be a non-empty collection
ℬ of subsets of W that are closed under union,
intersection, and complement. Define an atom of ℬ to be
a minimal non-empty subset of W. If ℬ,ℬ' are
factors in W with ℬ⊂ℬ' we say that
ℬ' extends ℬ. More generally, if
ℬ,ℬ' are factors in W we let
ℬ∨ℬ' be their smallest common extension. If
f:W→ is a function we let
𝔼(f|ℬ) denote the conditional expectation

    𝔼(f|ℬ)(x)=𝔼_ℬ(x)f,

where ℬ(x) is the unique atom containing x.

elements of a finite set X, and let us write S_j(x) for the set of all 
s in S such that s_j=x. We shall say that S is homogeneous
if for each j the sets S_j(x) all have the same size.

sentence:
Let η>0 be a real number, let 0<q≤ p≤ 1 and let U_1,…,U_m be subsets of X chosen independently with probability p. Let ω_1,…,ω_k be the associated measures of sets W_1, …, W_k chosen independently with probability q. We say that U_1,… U_m and ω_1,…,ω_k are sufficiently random if |W_i| = (1+o(1))q |X| for every 1 ≤ i ≤ k and, for every j between 1 and k and every sequence (i_j+1, …, i_k) of distinct integers between 1 and m, the following statement holds. 


  * Let a sequence (a_1, …, a_j-1, V_i_j+1, …, V_i_k) be chosen randomly such that a_h ∈_n for every h < j and V_i_h=(U_i_h)_q/p for every h>j, and for each h>j let ν_i_h be the associated measure of V_i_h. Then the probability that the (k-1)-tuple (ω_1+a_1,…,ω_j-1+a_j-1,ν_i_j+1,…,ν_i_k) is (η,j)-good is at least 1 - o(|X|^-k).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let I,J,K be three discrete intervals in  thus I takes the form { i ∈: i_- ≤ i ≤ i_+} for some integers i_-, i_+, and similarly for J and K.  A triangular grid with dimensions I,J,K is a collection of lines (p_i^*)_i ∈ I, (q_j^*)_j ∈ J, (r_k^*)_k ∈ K in ^2, which we will view as duals of not necessarily distinct points p_i, q_j, r_k in ^2, obeying the following axioms:


  (i) If i ∈ I, j ∈ J, k ∈ K are integers with i+j+k=0, then the lines p_i^*, q_j^*, r_k^* are distinct and meet at a point P_ijk.  Furthermore, this point P_ijk is not incident to any line in the grid which is not already identical to one of the lines p_i^*, q_j^*, r_k^*.  Thus, for instance, if i' ∈ I is such that p_i'^* ≠ p_i^*, q_j^*, r_k^*, then p_i'^* cannot contain P_ijk.

  (ii)  If i ∈ I, j,j' ∈ J, k,k' ∈ K are such that i+j+k=i+j'+k'=0 and 0 < |j-j'| ≤ 2 or equivalently 0 < |k-k'| ≤ 2, then the intersection points P_ijk and P_ij'k' are distinct. In particular, this forces q_j^* ≠ q_j'^* and r_k^* ≠ r_k'^*.  Similarly for cyclic permutations of i,j,k and of j',k'.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

Let 𝖡_1 be the block of π containing 1, and for 1< j ≤ |π|, let 𝖡_j be the block of π containing the smallest number not in 𝖡_1 ∪𝖡_2 ∪⋯∪𝖡_j-1.   
The standard labeling of π  is  (_π | _π'),  where 
_π = (b_1,…, b_k) and _π' = (b_k+1, …,b_2k) in [1,n]^k,  and 

    b_ℓ = j    if  ℓ∈𝖡_j   for  ℓ∈ [1,2k].

sentence:
Given a greedoid G=(S,ℱ), a feasible set A∈ℱ
and an x∈ S, the shadow of x on A is
sh_A(x)=|A|-r(A-x). The shadow vector of A is
the vector sh_A∈ℝ^S for which sh_A(x) is the shadow of
x on A for every x∈ S. The shadow polytope
P_shadow(G) of G is defined as the polytope spanned by
the shadow vectors of all bases of G.

sentence:
A marked-graph Ω.2 Reidemeister move is
constructed as follows. Any finite sequence of marked pivots may be applied to
a marked graph H; let G denote the result. G is replaced with G-v-w,
G^+-v-w or G_c^vz-v-w as in one of the three propositions above. Any
finite sequence of marked pivots may then be applied. The inverse of an
Ω.2 move is also an Ω.2 move, as is the move obtained by first
toggling all loops in H, and then toggling all loops in the final graph.

sentence:
A Catalan pair of type 2 (or C2-pair for short)
is a relational structure (T,R) on a finite set X with the following
properties.

 
  C2a) R and T∪ R are both partial orders on X.
 
  C2b) Any two distinct elements of X are comparable by exactly one of
the relations T and R.
 
  C2c) There are no three distinct elements x,y,z∈ X satisfying xTy,
xTz and yRz, and also no three elements x,y,z∈ X satisfying yTx,
zTx and yRz.

We let _n denote the set of unlabeled C2-pairs on n vertices.

sentence:
Let R be an interval order on a set X, and let M be its Fishburn
matrix. The Fishburn triple of type 1 of R (or F1-triple of
R ) is the relational structure (T_1,S_1,R) on the set X, in which T_1 
and S_1 are determined by these rules:

 
  * For any two elements x,y∈ X, represented by distinct cells c_x and
c_y in M, we have xT_1y if and only if c_x is strictly NW from c_y, 
and
we have xS_1y if and only if c_x is weakly SW from c_y.
 
  * If c is a cell of M and X_c⊆ X the set of elements
represented by c, then S_1 induces a chain in X_c and T_1 induces an
antichain in X_c.

Similarly, for R and M as above, a Fishburn triple of type 2 of R
(or F2-triple of R ) is the relational structure (T_2,S_2,R) on X,
with T_2 and S_2 defined as follows:

 
  * For any two elements x,y∈ X, represented by distinct cells c_x and
c_y in M, we have xT_2y if and only if c_x is weakly NW from c_y, and
we have xS_2y if and only if c_x is strictly SW from c_y.
 
  * If c is a cell of M and X_c⊆ X the set of elements
represented by c, then S_2 induces an antichain in X_c and T_2 induces a
chain in X_c.

A limit permutation is a Lebesgue measurable function Z:[0,1]^2 →[0,1] satisfying the following conditions:


  (a) for every x∈[0,1], the function Z(x,·) is a cdf, i.e., (<ref>) holds;


  (b) 
 for every y∈[0,1], the function Z(·,y) satisfies
∫_0^1 Z(x,y) dx = y.

We denote the set of limit permutations by 𝒵.

sentence:
[Subpermutation density]
For positive integers k, n ∈, let τ∈ S_k and π∈ S_n. 
The number of occurrences Λ(τ,π)  of the permutation τ in π is the number of k-tuples
 (x_1,x_2,…,x_k) ∈ [n]^k_< such that
 π(x_i) < π(x_j) if and only if τ(i)<τ(j). 
The density of the permutation τ as a subpermutation of π is given by 

    t(τ,π)=
    nk^-1Λ(τ,σ)     if  k≤ n
     0     if   k> n.

sentence:

A limit permutation is a Lebesgue measurable function Z:[0,1]^2 →[0,1] satisfying the following conditions:


  (a) for every x∈[0,1], the function Z(x,·) is a cdf, i.e., (<ref>) holds;


  (b) 
 for every y∈[0,1], the function Z(·,y) satisfies
∫_0^1 Z(x,y) dx = y.

We denote the set of limit permutations by 𝒵.

sentence:
[Z-random permutation]
Given  a limit permutation Z we generate the Z-random permutation σ(n,Z) using the following. A sequence of n real numbers X_1,…,X_n is generated independently and uniformly on [0,1]. Conditional on (X_1,…,X_n), we generate n real numbers Y_1,…,Y_n, with each Y_i generated independently according to the cdf Z(X_i,·). Let (X_1^*,… X_k^*) and (Y_1^*,… Y_k^*) denote the values X_1, …, X_k and Y_1, …, Y_k, respectively, rearranged in increasing order. The Z-random permutation σ=σ(n,Z) is given by σ(i)=j if and only if
X^*_i=X_ℓ and Y^*_j=Y_ℓ for some ℓ∈ [n].

sentence:
Fix positive integers d_1, d_2 and g.
Fix n=2d_2+g-1 points p_1,…,p_n∈^2 in tropical general position.
Let N^_(Δ,d_1,d_2,g) be the number of connected tropical stable maps to E_×^1_ of leaky degree Δ, bidegree (d_1,d_2) and genus g satisfying the point conditions p_1,…,p_n, counted with multiplicity as in Definition <ref>. If we only list 3 subscripts, this refers to the case without leaking: N^_(d_1,d_2,g)= N^_({ 0,…,0},d_1,d_2,g).

sentence:
[Graph covers, see Definition 2.18 <cit.>] 
Let Γ be a graph with n labeled vertices x_1,…,x_n and r labeled edges q_1,…,q_r. Let Ω be an order, viewed as an element in the symmetric group on n elements, associating to i the place Ω(i) that the vertex x_i takes in the order Ω. 
As before, fix an orientation of E_ and points p_0,p_1,…,p_n ordered in this way when going around E_ starting at p_0.

A graph cover of type Γ and order Ω is a leaky tropical cover π:Γ'→ E_, where Γ' is a metrization of Γ, such that π^-1(p_Ω(i)) contains the vertex x_i. (Since there are n point conditions and n vertices, it follows that there is precisely one vertex of Γ in each preimage π^-1(p_j)).)

The multidegree of a graph cover is the vector a∈ℕ^r with k-th entry 
    a_k=|π^-1(p_0)∩ q_k|· w_k,
 where w_k denotes the expansion factor of the edge q_k.

sentence:
Let S be a 2-connected graph with at least two vertices and not isomorphic to K_2.
Then the following statements are equivalent and characterize
series-parallel graphs.


  * S does not contain a homeomorphic copy of K_4, i.e., the complete graph on four
vertices;

  * S can be recursively constructed starting from a digon by
either adding an edge with the same end-vertices as an existing
one or subdividing an existing edge by the insertion of a new
vertex.

sentence:
“Pruning” leaves.  
Suppose a cutvertex is incident with a leaf , or an edge incident with a one-valent vertex.  The operation called “pruning” the leaf from a graph will mean deleting all edges adjacent to the leaf.  
A graph is “pruned” when all of its leaves have been pruned.  Collect all of the leaves pruned in this way in the set L.  Note that here two vertices are deleted at a time, one from each vertex set if the graph is bipartite as below.

sentence:
Let G be a permutation group on Ω and k a natural
number with 1 ≤ k ≤ n=|Ω|. G is called
k-transitive if for every two ordered k-tuples
α_1,...α_k and β_1,...,β_k of points of
Ω (with α_i ≠α_j, β_i ≠β_j,
for i ≠ j) there exists g ∈ G which takes α_t into
β_t (for t=1,...,k).

sentence:
A minor model (sometimes abbreviated model ) of a graph
  H in a graph G is a pair ( M,φ) 
  where M is a collection of disjoint subsets
of G such that ∀ X ∈ M, GX
is connected and φH→ M is a
bijection that satisfies ∀{u,v}∈H, ∃ u'
∈φ(u), ∃ v' ∈φ(v), {u',v'}∈G. We say that a graph H is a minor of a graph G
(H  G) if there is a minor model of H in G. Notice that
H is a minor of G if H can be obtained by a subgraph of G
after contracting edges.

sentence:
[ <cit.>] 
A fat tree on a set V is a partition of V, whose parts are called vertices , together with edges linking elements of different vertices, such that: 


  * a walk on the fat tree is an alternating sequence (a_1, b_1, c_1, a_2, …, c_n), where for every i, a_i and c_i are elements of different vertices and b_i is an edge between a_i and c_i, and for every i between 1 and n-1, c_i and a_i+1 are elements of the same vertex;

  * For every pair of elements of different vertices (a,c), there exists one and only one walk from a to c.

 

A rooted fat tree is a fat tree with a distinguished element called the root .

sentence:
Let n,k, and q be integers such that 1 ≤ k ≤⌊ n/2 ⌋ -1
and 1 ≤ q ≤ n-1.
Denote by f(n,k,q) the maximal number of edges in an I_k+1-free CGG on n
vertices that admits a free boundary arc of order q. Then:


  * If q ≤ n-2k, then f(n,k,q)=kn. In particular, there exists a maximal
I_k+1-free CGG that admits a free boundary arc of order q.


  * If q=n-2k+ ℓ for 0 < ℓ < k, then f(n,k,q)=
kn- ℓ+12.


  * If q ≥ n-k, then f(n,k,q)= n2 -
q2.

sentence:
The signed (or colored ) descent set , denoted
by (Q), of a bitableau Q = (Q^+, Q^-) ∈(λ,
μ) is the element (S, ) ∈Σ^B (n) defined as
follows:
  
    
  ∙
    The set S consists of n along with all s ∈ [n-1] for which
    either s and s+1 appear in the same tableau (Q^+ or Q^-) and
    s+1 appears in a lower row than s,
    or s and s+1 appear in different tableaux.
    
  ∙
    For every s ∈ S, (s) = + if s appears in Q^+ and (s) = - otherwise.

A path i=i_0,…,i_r=j with i<j in a simple graph on [n] is called admissible , if 

  * i_l ≠ i_k for k ≠ l

  * for each k=1,…,r-1 one has either i_k<i or i_k>j

  * for any proper subset {j_1,…,j_s} of {i_1,…,i_r-1}, the sequence i,j_1,…,j_s,j is not a path.

sentence:
[Varieties]  An (affine) variety defined over k is a subset V ⊆ k^n of the form

    V = { x ∈ k^n: P_1(x) = … = P_m(x) = 0 }

where n,m are natural numbers, and P_1,…,P_m: k^n → k are polynomials.  We say that the variety has complexity at most M if n,m are at most M, and all the degrees of P_1,…,P_m are at most M.  If furthermore the polynomials P_1,…,P_m have coefficients defined over F, we say that V is defined over F (with complexity at most M).   A variety is (geometrically) irreducible if it cannot be expressed as the union of two strictly smaller subvarieties.

The Zariski closure of a subset E of k^n is defined to be the intersection of all the varieties in k^n that contain E.

The dimension of a non-empty variety V ⊂ k^n is the largest natural number d for which one has a chain

    ∅⊊ V_0 ⊊…⊊ V_d ⊂ V

of irreducible varieties V_0,…,V_d.  We adopt the convention that the empty set has dimension -∞.

sentence:
Let A_0,A_1,…,A_d be finite subsets of ^d, and let
=(A_0,…,A_d). Write F_i=F_i(λ_i,x) = ∑_u∈ A_iλ_i,ux^u
for a Laurent polynomial supported on A_i, where
λ_i=(λ_i,u| u ∈ A_i) are variables representing
the coefficients of F_i. Set λ=(λ_0,…,λ_d).
Let

    Ω_ = { (x,λ) | F_0(λ_0,x)=⋯ =
    F_d(λ_d,x)=0}⊂ (^*)^d ×∏_i=0^d ^|A_i|-1.

If the closure of the image of Ω_ under the projection 
(^*)^d ×∏_i=0^d ^|A_i|-1→∏_i=0^d
^|A_i|-1 has codimension 1, then the
resultant _(F_0,…,F_d) is defined to
be the unique (up to sign) irreducible polynomial in [λ] which vanishes
on this hypersurface. If this closure has codimension at least 2,
then we define _(F_0,…,F_d)=1.

sentence:
[Weighted Matrix-Tree Theorem]
Let G be a graph with n vertices, and let L̂ be its weighted Laplacian matrix.


  * If the eigenvalues of L̂ are λ̂_0=0,λ̂_1,…,λ̂_n-1, then
  
    ∑_T∈(G)∏_ij∈ T e_ij =
          λ̂_1⋯λ̂_n-1/n

where (G) is the set of all spanning trees of G.  

  * For 1≤ i≤ n, let L̂_i be the reduced weighted Laplacian obtained from
L̂ by deleting the i^th row and i^th column.  Then
    
    ∑_T∈(G)∏_ij∈ T e_ij = L̂_i.

A ray is an infinite graph R=(V, E), with 
	V = {v_0, v_1, v_2, ...} and E = {v_0v_1, v_1v_2, v_2v_3, ...}
	where the v_i are pairwise different.
	If a ray R_1=(V_1, E_1) is a subgraph of a ray R_2=(V_2, E_2), 
	then R_1 is called a tail of R_2.

sentence: A permutation π=π_1π_2…π_n∈ S_n is said to contain a permutation σ=σ_1σ_2…σ_k if there exist indices 1≤α_1<α_2< … <α_k ≤ n such that π_α_i < π_α_j if and only if σ_i <σ_j.  Otherwise, we say π avoids σ.

sentence:
Given a semi–standard tableau T,
S_k=(y_1,y_2,…,y_k) is a k–string (or just string, for short, when there is no ambiguity) of T if
y_1<⋯< y_k and the rightmost box in row y_j is labeled with j; the corresponding strip, denoted by st(S_k), is the union of all rightmost boxes in rows y_j, for all j=1, … ,k.

We say that S_k=(y_1,y_2,…,y_k) ≤ S_t=(z_1,z_2,…,z_t)
if k ≥ t and y_j≤ z_j for all j=1 , … ,t.

1.5mm

We define in a recursive way (S_m_1, S_m_2, …  S_m_s) a complete sequence of strings of the tableau T having content (m_1,m_2,…,m_s)^' (note that we are writing the content in terms of its conjugate)
if S_m_1 is a string of T and (S_m_2, …  S_m_s) is a complete sequence of strings of the tableau T ∖ st(S_m_1) (when this set is not empty) having content (m_2,…,m_s)^'.

In other word, (S_m_1, S_m_2, …  S_m_s) is a complete sequence of strings of T if
S_m_j is a string for T∖{⋃_k=1^j-1 st(S_m_k)} for all j=1, … ,s.

sentence:
Let Γ=(V,H) be a hypergraph with N vertices v_1,…,v_N and M hyperedges h_1,…,h_M. We define the N× M incidence matrix of Γ as ℐ:=(ℐ_ij)_ij, where
	
    ℐ_ij:= 1    if v_i is an input and not an output of h_j
     -1    if v_i is an output and not an input of h_j
     0    otherwise.
Therefore each row ℐ_i of ℐ represents a vertex v_i and each column ℐ^j of ℐ represents a hyperedge h_j.

sentence:
[APA]
Let 𝒞 be a class of finite structures. We say that 𝒞 has the amalgamation property with automorphisms ( APA ) if for every A,  B_1,  B_2 ∈𝒞 such that A⊆ B_1, B_2 there exists C∈𝒞 which is an amalgamation of B_1 and B_2 over A, has B_1, B_2⊆ C and furthermore the following holds:

For every pair of automorphisms f_1∈( B_1), f_2∈( B_2) such that f_i(A) = A for i∈{1,2} and f_1|_A = f_2|_A, there is an automorphism g∈( C) such that g|_B_i = f_i for i∈{1,2}.

sentence:
A non-oriented 3–hypergraph  is called a comparability 3–hypergraph if it admits a transitive orientation. 
[In  <cit.> the authors defined this class as “cyclic comparability 3-hypergraphs" however we believe that it should be simply called comparability 3-hypergraphs according to the classical concept of comparability graphs. ]

sentence: Suppose that (Q,) is a partial knowledge structure, with |Q|≥ 2. A subset Q'⊂ Q is yielding if for any  state L of  that is minimal for inclusion in some equivalence class [K], we have  |L∖∩[K] |≤ 1.  We recall that [K] is the equivalence class containing K in the partition of   induced by Q' (cf. Definition <ref>). For any non trivial child  of , we call ^+=∪{} a plus child of .

sentence:
Let M
be an ℓ× p matrix of integers and let b ∈ℕ^ℓ. The set of linear equations Mx=b has the removal property if for every δ >0 there is an
ϵ=ϵ(δ,M,b)>0 with the following property: if S
⊆ [n] is such that there are at most ϵ n^p-ℓ
vectors x ∈ S^p satisfying Mx=b, then one can remove from
S at most δ n elements to obtain an (M,b)-free set.

sentence: A permutation π∈ S_n has a descent at position i if π(i) > π(i+1), where i = 1, …, n-1, and the descent set of π, denoted Des(π) is the set of all descents of π. The descent number of π is defined as d(π) := | Des(π) | + 1.

sentence: φ∈{0,…, q-1}^|F| is called a q-flow of Δ if ∂φ^T≡ 0 q. It is nowhere-zero if φ∈{1,…,q-1}^|F|. The number of nowhere-zero q-flows is denoted Φ_Δ(q) and is called the flow quasipolynomial.

sentence: χ∈{0,…, k-1}^|R| is called a k-coloring of Δ. It is proper if χ∂· e_j≢0 k for all standard basis vectors e_j∈ℤ^|F|. The number of proper k-colorings is denoted X_Δ(k) and is called the chromatic quasipolynomial.

sentence:
A cycle in a graph Γ will be called a (0,1)-cycle if
  all directed edges appear in it with coefficients in {+1, 0,
  -1}; that is, the cycle is a sum of simple cycles with disjoint
  edge supports.

sentence:
A graph G is a pair (V(G), E(G)),
where V(G) is the labelled set of vertices,
and E(G) is the set of edges.
Each edge is a set of two vertices from V(G).
The number of vertices (resp. of edges) is n(G) = |V(G)|
(resp. m(G) = |E(G)|).
The excess k(G) is defined as m(G) - n(G).

The generating function of a family  of graphs is

    F(z,w) =
      ∑_G ∈
      w^m(G)z^n(G)/n(G)!,

and F_k(z) denotes the generating function of multigraphs from  with excess k,

    F_k(z) = [y^k] F(z/y,y).

Let Q be a  filling of a diagram D_α for α n with the integers {1,…, n}.
We say that Q satisfies the recording triple rule if whenever Q(i,j)>Q(i,) where j> then Q(i,j)>Q(i+1,).  (If cell (i+1,) is empty, we consider it to contain the entry infinity.)  This is equivalent to the statement that if a>b then a>c in the subarray pictured below.  (Here we assume that if the position immediately to the right of b is empty, then c=∞.)

sentence:
Let β be a composition of n.  A filling of a diagram of shape β with exactly {1,…, n} is a dual immaculate  recording tableau (DIRT)  if it has the following properties:


  * The rows increase from left to right.

  * The row strips start in the first (leftmost) column.

  * The first (leftmost) column increases from top to bottom.


  * The  recording triple rule is satisfied.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
An entry T(i,j) in a Young composition tableau T is said to be virtuous if the following hold.


  * The entry T(i,j)  is greater than all entries below it in its column.

  * The entry T(i,j) is at the end of its row.

  * Any other element which is at the end of its row in column i is in a row above j.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A planar X-labelled rooted tree is a planar rooted tree T with no internal vertices having exactly one child, and with a labelling of all vertices fulfilling the following restrictions: 

 
  - every internal vertex v with m children is labelled by an element x_v∈ X_m;
 
  - every leaf of T is labelled by a positive integer in such a way that the following two conditions are satisfied:
 
  
  * (labelling set condition) the leaf labels are in one-to-one correspondence with the set [l]={1,2,…,l} (where l is the number of leaves of T);
  
  * (local increasing condition) if we temporarily assign to each internal vertex v the smallest of the labels of leaves that are descendants of v in T  (thus every vertex of T, should it be an internal vertex or a leaf, has an integer assigned to it), then for each internal vertex i the integers assigned to its children increase from the left to the right.
 

Notation: for i≥ 0, l≥ 1 we denote by ℒ𝒯_i,l(X) the set of planar X-labelled rooted trees with i internal vertices and l leaves, 

    ℒ𝒯_l(X)=⋃_i≥ 0ℒ𝒯_i,l(X)

is the set of planar X-labelled rooted trees with l leaves, 

    ℒ𝒯(X)=⋃_i≥ 0, l≥ 1ℒ𝒯_i,l(X)

is the set of all planar X-labelled rooted trees. In particular, ℒ𝒯_0,l(X) is non-empty only for l=1 (and in that case it consists of exactly one element, a one-vertex tree with no edges), and ℒ𝒯_1(X)=ℒ𝒯_0,1(X) (since every internal vertex has at least two children, hence in the presence of an internal vertex we end up with at least two leaves).

sentence:
Let  be a set of patterns in ℒ𝒯(X). A tree T together with a collection of its subtrees T_1,…,T_k is said to be a k-cluster if the following two conditions hold:

 
  * For every i, the subtree T_i is an occurrence of a pattern from : (T_i)∈,
 
  * for every edge e of T that joins two internal vertices, it is an edge between the two internal vertices of some T_i.
 
By definition, the set of 0-clusters is the set of labels X.

sentence: Let QH_1(Γ,R) := {e ∈ E(Γ)  |  e ∪ R is in a cycle factor }. For k>1, let QH_k(Γ,R) := {e ∈ E(Γ)  |  QH_k-1(Γ,e ∪ R) is connected }. Then we say that Γ is k-quasi-hamiltonian if QH_k(Γ,{}) is connected.

A permutation is simsun if, for all k≥ 0, removing k largest
elements from it results in a permutation with no consecutive descents.

sentence: Given a finite 3-free set A={a_0,…,a_n}⊂_0, the Stanley sequence generated by A is the infinite sequence S(A)={a_0,a_1,…} defined by the following recursion. If k≥ n and a_0<…<a_k have been defined, let a_k+1 be the smallest integer a>a_k such that {a_0,…, a_k}∪{a} is 3-free. Though formally one writes S({a_0,…,a_n}), we will frequently use the notation S(a_0,…,a_n) instead.

sentence:
A tuple (G_1, G_2, … G_k, H, H_1, H_2, … H_k) is a gluing of G_1 … G_k if


  * H is a connected graph

  * H_1, … H_k are subgraphs of H

  * H_i∼ G_i for all i ∈ [k]

  * ∪_i=1^k E(H_i)=E(H).

We occasionally refer to H itself as a gluing.  The tuple (H_1, … H_k) is a decomposition of H.  If there exists only one tuple H_1, … H_k such that (G_1, … G_k, H, H_1, … H_k) is a gluing, we say that (G_1, … G_k, H) is uniquely decomposable .  In this case, we say that H[S] is the unique subgraph of H induced by {H_i}_i ∈ S.  We occasionally say that H itself is uniquely decomposable, if G_1, … G_k are clear from context.  If there exists an H such that (G_1, … G_k, H) is uniquely decomposable, we say that {G_1, … G_k} is uniquely composable .

sentence:
[Hyperplane-distance]

For each hyperplane H, the set nonempty ℑ={V_1,…,V_n} of hyperplanes is a separating chain for H if


  * Each V_i∈ℑ separates H from U.

  * If V_i,V_j∈ℑ are separated by a hyperplane V, then V∈ℑ.

  * The hyperplanes in ℑ are pairwise non-crossing.

  * 𝔍 is not properly contained in a set of hyperplanes satisfying (1)-(3).

These properties ensure that the halfspaces of the V_i∈ℑ can be labeled 𝐀 or 𝐁 so that {𝐁(V_i)}_V_i∈ℑ is totally ordered by inclusion.  Let 𝕀(H) be the set of all separating chains for H.  The hyperplane-distance of H (with respect to U) is

    d(H)=min{|ℑ|:ℑ∈𝕀(H)}.

If C is a collection of hyperplanes (or a subgraph of Γ(𝐗)), we let D(C)=∑_H∈ Cd(H).

Note that the combinatorial distance d_G(𝐗)(N(H),N(U)) in G(𝐗)=𝐗^(1) between the carriers of H and U counts the hyperplanes that separate U from H, since carriers are convex, and that d(H) is bounded above by this quantity.  Note also that d(H)=0 if and only if H U.

sentence:
If p, q, r ∈ then p is a small common multiple (SCM) of q, r if

    q | p,    
    r | p,    every node of p is a node of q or r (or both),    ℓ(p) < ℓ(q) + ℓ(r).

sentence:
Let k be a natural number, and G be an edge-point ribbon graph. 
A  k-valuation of G_m  is an edge k-colouring of G_m such that each vertex is incident to an even number (possibly zero) of edges of each colour, and all edges incident to a singular vertex are of the same colour.  

If G_m is canonically checkerboard coloured then the four possible configurations of colours about a vertex, are white , black , crossing , or total ,  as described in Figure <ref>. Singular vertices are always total. 
 We let (ϕ) denote the number of non-singular total vertices in a k-valuation ϕ.

sentence:
A HERG  G(V,E,H), or simply G_H, 
is a ribbon graph G(V,E)  with a set H of HRs together with an incidence relation which associates each HR with a unique vertex. The ribbon graph G is called the underlying ribbon graph of G_H. There is an
underlying HEG (V,E,H), denoted _H, obtained from G_H by keeping its
vertex, edge and half-edge sets and their incidence relation.

sentence:
[Completed and pruned graphs]
Let  _h=(, ,h) be an HEG and h_0∈ h be one of its 
half-edges incident to a vertex v_0. 

 Completing h_0∈ h in _h is the operation which replaces h_0 by an edge e_0 by adding a new vertex v_1 in the vertex set of _h such that e_0 is incident to v_0 and v_1. 
 The completed graph =(∪_h, ∪ h), 
 with |_h|=|h|,  
is the graph obtained after  completing all half-edges in _h. 

Consider a leaf v_0∈ in a HEG _h and e_0∈ the edge
incide to v_0. 

Pruning e_0∈ in _h is the operation which replaces e_0 by
a half-edge h_0 by removing v_0 from the vertex set of _h. 
Let _0 be a subset of leaves in , and _0=_0(_0) be the set of all edges
incident to the leaves in _0. 
 The pruned HEG with respect to _0,  _ h'(_0)=(∖_0, ∖_0, h'(_0) = h∪_0), is the HEG obtained from _h by pruning all leaves in _0.

The form the Hirota equations acquire for logarithms of
τ-functions is called the
Kadomtsev–Petviashvili hierarchy .

sentence:
Let C be column and I = { z_1 > … > z_k } the
set of 
unbarred letters z such that the pair (z,z) occurs in
C. The column C can be split when there exists a set of k
unbarred letters J = { t_1 > … > t_k }⊂ [n]
such that:

    
  * t_1 is the greatest letter in [n] satisfying: 
        t_1 < z_1, t_1∉C, and t_1∉C,
    
  * for i = 2, …, k, the letter t_i is the greatest
        one in [n] satisfying t_i < min(t_i-1, z_i), 
        t_i ∉C, and t_i∉C.


In this case we write:


    
  * rC for the column obtained by changing z_i
    into t_i in C for each letter z_i ∈ I, and by
    reordering if necessary,
    
  * lC for the column obtained by changing z_i into
        t_i in C for each letter z_i ∈ I, and by reordering if
        necessary.

The pair (lC,rC) will be called a split column , which we well
sometimes denote by lCrC.

sentence:
An admissible cover π: D→ C of degree d is a finite morphism of pointed curves such that:


  * The map π restricted to the complement of the inverse image of the marked points and nodes is étale of constant degree d. 

  * All inverse images of marked points of C are marked in D.

  * The set of nodes of D is precisely the preimage under π of the set of nodes of C.





 



  * Over a node, étale locally, D, C and π are described by

    D   :    y_1y_2 = a
    
    C   :    x_1x_2 = a^ℓ
    π   :    x_1 = y_1^ℓ,   x_2 = y_2^ℓ.

for some positive integer ℓ≤ d.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A morphism φ: 𝒳→𝒴 of toroidal embeddings is said to be locally analytically toric if for every point x∈𝒳, there exist étale charts around x and ϕ(x) such ϕ is given by an equivariant toric morphism. That is, we have the following diagram

    𝒱_σd   𝒱_x dlr   𝒳d
    𝒱_τ   𝒱_φ(x)lr   𝒴,

where the top row is a local toric chart around x in 𝒳, and the bottom row is a local toric chart around φ(x) in 𝒴. The leftmost vertical arrow is torus equivariant.

sentence: Let ℒ be a linear extension of a poset 𝒫 and let ρ_i act on ℒ by switching i and i+1 if they are not the labels of two elements with a covering relation.  We define the promotion of ℒ to be (ℒ) = ρ_n-1ρ_n-2⋯ρ_1 (ℒ).

sentence: Let Π⊂ℝ^2 be the set of points in the integer span of (2,0) and (1,1).  A rowed-and-columned (rc) poset ℛ is a finite poset together with a map π: ℛ→Π, where if p_1,p_2 ∈ℛ, p_1 covers p_2, and π(p_1)=(i,j), then π(p_2)=(i+1,j-1) or π(p_2)=(i-1,j-1).  For p ∈ℛ, we call π(p) ∈Π the position of p.

sentence:
[Theorem 7.4 of <cit.>]
If 𝒜 is a cluster algebra (i) of geometric type, or (ii) has nondegenerate exchange matrix, and (𝐱,B), (𝐱',B') are two seeds for 𝒜, such that cluster 𝐱' is simply the permutation σ of cluster 𝐱, then the exchange matrices B' and B must also be the same, up to simultaneous permutation of its rows and columns by the same σ.  In particular, the cluster determines the seed in the above cases.

sentence:
[Constructing a pair-weighted quiver from an exchange matrix]
To get a quiver Q_B from an (m+n)-by-n exchange matrix B is the reverse of the above construction, however, there are two nuances to emphasize.




  * For a cluster algebra seed to correspond to a quiver, the corresponding matrix B must satisfy b_ij = - b_ji for all pairs 0 ≤ i,j≤ n-1.  In other words, the top n-by-n portion of B must be skew-symmetric, not just skew-symmetrizable.  Since cluster algebras for non-skew-symmetric seeds are also quite prevalent in the literature, our package works with a slight generalization of quivers, which we call pair-weighted quivers .  

We do not allow parallel edges in such quivers, and instead, we label each directed edge as an ordered pair [b_ij, b_ji] such that the associated edge is oriented from v_i to v_j.  Consequently, the first entry of each such pair is necessarily positive and the second is negative, but the direction of the edge must also be recorded.  In the case that b_ji = -b_ij, i.e. the case of parallel edges, this label is simplified to be simply the positive number b_ij.  We also omit the label b_ij=1 when displaying graphics to make pictures easier to view.  

Note, that this notation differs from that in places such as <cit.> or <cit.>, but is necessarily for precise computations.  Our notation is inspired by Dlab-Ringel <cit.> and Dupont-Pérotin <cit.>.


  * If m > 0, i.e. the matrix has more rows than columns, and for any b_ij where i ≥ n, there is no b_ji in the matrix and so we do not have to worry about checking skew-symmetry for such entries.  However, such vertices v_i correspond to a frozen variable and so we designate these vertices accordingly as “frozen vertices” to remind the user not to mutate or apply exchanges at such vertices.

i.e., the complements in K_V of finite graphs.

sentence:
[Threshold graphs] 
Let A be a finite (multi)set of real numbers, and t be some “threshold” constant. Let H_A,t denote the graph with A as the vertices, and an edge between x,y ∈ A (possibly x=y) if and only if x+y ≤ t. We call such graphs threshold graphs . When A = {0, 1, …, n} and t = n, we write H_n for H_A, t.

sentence:
[First common ancestor]
	Let t be a tree, and u and v be two nodes (internal nodes or leaves) of t. 
	The first common ancestor of u and v is the node furthest away from the root ∅ that appears 
	on both paths from ∅ to u and from ∅ to v in t.

sentence:
[Rubey, personal conversation]
We define descents for vacillating tableaux using highest weight words. We call a letter j of w a descent if there exists a directed path from w_j to w_j+1 in the crystal graph for the defining representation of 

    1→ 2→…→ k → 0 → -k →…→ -1

and w_jw_j+1≠ j(-j) if for the initial segment w_1,…,w_j-1 holds #j-#(-j)=0.

 For k=1 this means that j is a descent if the j^th position is a 1 followed by a 0, or a 0 followed by a -1, or a 1 followed by a -1 if the numbers of 1's and -1's before the j^th position are different.

We define the descent set of w as

    (w)= j j  is a descent of  w.

sentence:
[Girdle]
  Let G be the planar map obtained by taking the union of all
  vertices and edges that either lie in the sequence from
  Lemma <ref> or on the boundary of a face in this
  sequence. We call this subgraph of T the girdle with
  respect to φ. Its cells from the cyclic sequence are called
  central cells of G, the other ones (which are only part of
  G because they lie on the boundary of a face from the sequence)
  are called outer cells of G. By construction, every face in
  the sequence is also a face of G (and hence a central cell); the
  other faces of G are called its sides . For every face in
  the sequence, precisely one of the edges on its boundary is a
  central cell and so is the other face incident with this edge. The
  union of such two faces and their boundaries is called a
  diamond . Note that every girdle has at least two central
  vertices; let j(G) be the smallest index for which c_j(G) is a
  vertex.

sentence:
A permutation tableau  is a Young diagram 
whose boxes are filled with 0's and 1's such that:


  * each column contains at least one 1, and 

  * there is no box containing a 0 which has both a 1 above it (in the 
same column) and a 1 to its left (in the same row).

sentence:
A crossing of a signed permutation π=(π(1),… ,π(n)) is a pair (i,j) with i,j>0
such that


  * i<j≤π(i)<π(j) or

  * -i<j≤ -π(i)<π(j) or

  * i>j>π(i)>π(j).

sentence:
[Intersection graphs]
A feature system is a triple (V, Ω, f), where V is a set of vertices, Ω is a set of features , and f is a function mapping vertices in V to subsets of Ω. Given a vertex v∈ V, we call f(v)⊆Ω its feature set . We construct a graph G on the vertex-set V from a feature system (V, Ω, f) by placing an edge between u,v ∈ V if their feature sets f(u), f(v) have non-empty intersection. We call G the intersection graph of the feature system (V, Ω,f).

We shall need a classic result from factor theory.
A 2-factor of a multigraph G (where loops are allowed) is a
2-regular spanning subgraph of G.

sentence:
(Ehrhart-Macdonald Reciprocity Law) Suppose that P is a convex polytope whose vertices have rational coordinates. Then the evaluation of its Ehrhart quasipolynomial, E(N), at negative integers yields

    E(-N) = (-1)^dim P E^∘(N),

where E^∘(N) is the number of integer points in the interior of the dilation NP.

sentence:
A configuration x
∈ R^+ is superstable if x-z ∉ R^+ for every z ∈ℤ^n, z ≥ 0 and z ≠ 0.

sentence: Let q+1 be an even integer. An edge-coloring ς E(K_q+1) → [(q+1)/2] is of Type P, if we obtain ς in the following way: Let G be the graph (isomorphic to K_q+2) obtained adding a new vertex u  and all the uV(K_q+1)-edges. Let ς_1 be an edge-coloring of Type H of G, and let ς(e) := ς_1(e) for every e∈ E(K_q+1). Note that the set { vw∈ E(K_q+1) ς(vw) = i} is a Hamiltonian path of K_q+1 for every i∈ [(q+1)/2].

sentence:
Let λ=(λ_1,…,λ_k) be a partition of n and (a,b),(c,d) ∈λ, we say that (a,b) and (c,d) are in the same block if and only if λ_a=λ_c. 
Let B be a block of λ and let i be the minimal integer such that (i,λ_i) ∈ B, then the box (i,λ_i) is called the upper right corner of B.

sentence:
Let G be a  graph of order at least two.


  * We call G a sub-removable graph (shortly, SR-graph) if γ(G-e)=γ(G_e) for any edge e of G.

  * We call G an anti-sub-removable graph (shortly, ASR-graph) if  γ(G-e)≠γ(G_e) for any edge e of G.

sentence:
Let p_1,…,p_n be points in ℝ^2 and λ'_1,…,λ'_l be cross-ratios that have pairwise distinct pairs of unordered numbers. These conditions are in general position if ∏_j=1^l_λ'_j^*( |λ'_j|)·∏_i=1^n_i^*( p_i)·ℳ_0,n(ℝ^2,Δ) is a nonempty finite set that is contained in the union of the interiors of top-dimensional polyhedra of ℳ_0,n(ℝ^2,Δ) and n+l=|Δ|-1. We say that p_1,…,p_n',λ_1,…,λ_l' with n'+l'<|Δ|-1 are in general position if there are p_n'+1,…,p_n,λ'_l'+1,…,λ'_l such that n+l=|Δ|-1 and p_1,…,p_n,λ'_1,…,λ'_l are in general position. If p_1,…,p_n,λ'_1,…,λ'_l with n+l=|Δ|-1 are in general position, we define

    N_0,n(λ'_1,…,λ'_l):=(∏_j=1^l_λ'_j^*( |λ'_j|)·∏_i=1^n_i^*( p_i)·ℳ_0,n(ℝ^2,Δ)),

the number of rational tropical curves of degree Δ satisfying the point conditions p_i and the cross-ratio conditions λ'_i. Denote by 𝒞_0,n( λ'_1,…,λ'_l) the set of tropical curves contributing to N_0,n(λ'_1,…,λ'_l).

sentence:
[Push-forward of affine cycles]
Let V=Γ⊗_ℤℝ and V'=Γ'⊗_ℤℝ. Let [X]∈ Z^aff_m(V) and [Y]∈ Z^aff_n(V') be cycles with representatives (X,ω_X) and Y. Let f:X→ Y be a morphism. Choosing a refinement of (X,ω_X), the set of cones

    f_*X:={f(σ)|σ∈ X  contained in a maximal cone of X on which f is injective}

is a tropical fan in V' of dimension m with weights

    ω_f_*X(σ'):=∑_σ∈ X^(m):   f(σ)=σ'ω_X(σ)· |Γ_σ''/f(Γ_σ)|

for all σ'∈ f_*X^(m). The equivalence class of (f_*X,ω_f_*X) is uniquely determined by the equivalence class of (X,ω_X).
For [(Z,ω_Z)]∈ Z^aff_k([X]) we define

    f_*[(Z,ω_Z)]:=[(f_*(Z^*),ω_f_*(Z^*))]∈ Z^aff_k([Y])

The map

    Z^aff_k([X])→ Z^aff_k([Y]),   C↦ f_*C

is well-defined, ℤ-linear and f_*C is called push-forward of C along f .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
[Multiplicities]
Let C=(Γ,x_1,…,x_N,h) be a tropical curve that satisfies given point conditions p_1,…,p_n and tropical cross-ratios λ'_1,…,λ'_l.

Let x_1 be the end of Γ that is contracted to p_1 under h. We refer to the vertex adjacent to x_1 in Γ as root vertex and orient all edges of Γ away from the root vertex. The head of a bounded edge γ is denoted by 𝔥(γ) and its tail by 𝔱(γ). Let V(Γ) be the set of vertices of Γ and let E^b(Γ) be the set of bounded edges of Γ. We refer to a vertex of Γ as v and to a bounded edge of Γ as γ for now. The vertices adjacent to ends x_1,…,x_N are denoted by v_1,…,v_N and do not need to be different. Define the complex


    θ:⊕_v∈ V(Γ)ℤ^2⊕⊕_γ∈ E^b(Γ)ℤ_M_1B⟶⊕_γ∈ E^b(Γ)ℤ^2⊕⊕_i=1^nℤ^2 ⊕⊕_j=1^lℤ_M_2



given by the maps (that are defined copywise)


    1_γ↦ n_γ+∑_i=1^lϵ(γ,i)    and   
    a_v↦∑_γϵ̃(γ,v)a_v+∑_i=1^nδ(v,v_i)a_v,

where a_v is the coordinate vector of h(v) and where (see definition <ref> for the notation of v(γ,𝔱(γ)))

    ϵ̃(γ,v):=
    
          1,    if v=𝔱(γ) 
    
          -1,    if v=𝔥(γ) 
    
          0,    otherwise   and   
    n_γ:=v(γ,𝔱(γ))

and

    δ(v,v_i):=
    
          1,    if v=v_i 
    
          0,    otherwise.

Let θ_ℤ be the map from above in the complex (<ref>)⊗_ℤℤ. Finally, we can define the multiplicity of C

    m_ℂ(Γ,h):=|θ_ℤ|,

which is equal to |(B)|.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O

sentence:
Let Λ:=⋃_j=1^l λ_j the union of all given degenerated cross-ratio constraints. Let 𝒮 be a lattice path subdivision in 𝒮_1(𝒜) and let P be a valid polytope or a pointed segment in 𝒮. Consider the summand P̃ of P and define for all entries τ_1,…,τ_m of labelings of edges of P associated to P̃  the sets Λ(P,i)⊂Λ of points and ends appearing in the cross-ratios λ_1,…,λ_l that can be reached from P via τ_i. That is, we obtain the elements of Λ(P,i) with the following procedure:


  * If the edge E of P where τ_i appears is contained in ∂Σ, then its dual edge is a labeled end determined by g(τ_i) (construction <ref>), and we add it to Λ(P,i).

  * Else there is a valid polytope (or a pointed segment) Q in 𝒮 such that Q≠ P and P,Q share an edge E such that τ_i appears in τ^E. Then either:


  * τ_i is mapped to Q̃ (via the map f_Q|_E from definition <ref>) and Q𝒜, then continue with all other labels mapped to Q̃ instead of τ_i. 

  * τ_i is mapped to Q̃ and Q=P_j∈𝒜, then  add the marked point x_j to Λ(P,i) and continue with all other labels mapped to Q̃ instead of τ_i

  * τ_i is mapped to a segment of Q, then there is exactly one τ_i' in another edge E' of Q that is mapped to the same segment. We continue with this.

In each case, we follow all appearing edges until we reach edges in ∂Σ for which we add the labels of the dual ends to Λ(P,i).


Furthermore, if P is a polytope appearing in the lattice path 𝒜 itself as j-th step, then we set Λ(P,0):={
 x_j }, the j-th marked point. Otherwise, we set Λ(P,0):=∅.

Moreover, we define 

    Λ(P)   :={λ_j={β_j_1,…,β_j_4}|β_j_i∈Λ(P,k_i)  for i=1,…,4 and k_i≠ k_i' if i≠ i'},

and we say that the lattice path subdivision 𝒮 fits the cross-ratios λ_1,…,λ_l if

    ∑_P#Λ(P)=l,

where the sum goes over all valid polytopes and pointed segments in 𝒮 and

    #Λ(P)=
    
    k    , if P is k-marked
    
    0    , otherwise.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[The rank of a divisor]
  For a divisor f∈(G), the rank of f is
  
    (f) = min{(g) - 1 : g ∈(G), g is effective, 
    ∄ h ∈(G) such that h ∼ f-g and h is effective}.

  When we wish to emphasize the underlying graph, we write _G(f) instead of (f).

sentence:
Let G be a graph and R⊊ V(G) with |R|≥ 2. The boundary of R is the set of vertices in R with neighbors in G∖ R. If G is 4-critical, we say R is collapsible if in every 3-coloring of G[R] all vertices in the boundary of R receive the same color. If R is collapsible, then we define the critical complement of R to be the graph obtained by identifying the boundary of R to one vertex v and deleting the rest of R. We call v the collapsed vertex of W.

Note then that the boundary of R is an independent set and for any u,v in the boundary of R, G[R]+uv contains a 4-critical subgraph. We say a collapsible subset is tight if for any u,v in the boundary of R, G[R]+uv is 4-critical.

sentence: Let A, B⊆ G, and let y∈ G. We say that y is ϵ-good for A with respect to B if |(A-y)∩ B|≤ϵ |B| or |B∖ (A-y)|≤ϵ |B|. We say that B is ϵ-good for A  if y is ϵ-good for A with respect to B for all y∈ G.[For those familiar with <cit.>, this is equivalent to saying that B is an ϵ-good subset in the Cayley graph Γ(G,A).]

sentence:
[totally ϵ-uniform]
Let A⊆ G:=_p^n and H⩽ G be a subspace. We say that H is totally ϵ-uniform for A if every y∈ G is ϵ-uniform for A with respect to H.  In other words, H is totally ϵ-uniform for A if |f^y_H,A(t)|≤ϵ for all y∈ G and t∉ H^⊥.

sentence:
A hollowed 2-tree is defined as follows: (i) any cycle of length at least four is a hollowed 2-tree, (ii) a graph obtained from a hollowed 2-tree by adding to it a simplicial vertex of degree 2 is a hollowed 2-tree,
and (iii) there are no other hollowed 2-trees.

sentence:
Let s∈ℝ and G∈.
   The game G is left-s-protected if  (G)≥  s
   and either
    G is right-atomic
    or for all    G^R, there exists G^RL
     such that G^RL is left-s-protected. Similarly,
G is right-s-protected if
     (G)≤  s and, for all
     G^L, there exists G^LR
     such that G^LR is right-s-protected.

sentence: The cyclic zonotope Z(d,n) defined by t_1<t_2<⋯<t_d is the n-zonotope Z_0(_1,…,_d)=Z(±_1,…,±_d) generated by the d vectors _i=(1,t_i,…,t_i^n-1) in ^n.

sentence:
Let r=2k. Given a graph G with vertex set [n] and ω(G)=m whose clique complex has no structural facets and without loss of generality F_1∩ F_2={1,2,…,r/2}, we'll construct a directed tree T with root v in the following way:


  * Let v=F_1 ∩ F_2.

  * V(T)={F_i: i ∈ [l]}∪v

  * E(T)={v→ F_i: F_i ⊃ [r/2]}∪{F_i  F_j: i<j minimal such that
 (F_j∩⟨ F_1,F_2,…,F_j-1⟩ )⊆ F_i,[r/2]⊆ F_i,  where  x ∈ F_i∖ F_j} .

We call this a K_m tree . One can recover the original clique complex from the K_m tree.

sentence:
A signed graph G_σ is called antibalanced if G_-σ is balanced.  Equivalently, 
G_σ switches to have all negative signs.  Also equivalently, all positive cycles have even length and all negative cycles have odd length.

sentence: In an unsigned graph G, two vertices v and w are called parity connected if there exist both an odd-length and an even-length chain between them.  Equivalently, v and w are sign connected in G_-.  The graph G is called parity connected if every two vertices are parity connected in G; equivalently, G_- is sign connected.

sentence:
<cit.> Given a composition α n we define a standard reverse composition tableau (abbreviated to SRCT )  of shape α and size n to be a bijective filling 

    : α→{1, … , n}
of the cells (i,j) of the reverse composition diagram α such that


  * the entries in each row are decreasing when read from left to right

  * the entries in the first column are increasing when read from top to bottom

  * triple rule: If i<j and (i,k)>  (j, k+1), then (i,k+1) exists and (i,k+1)>  (j, k+1).

We denote the set of all SRCTs of shape α by (α).

sentence: Let f  X → Y be a map of digital  images.  If there is a map g  Y → X such that g∘ f ≈id_X and f ∘ g ≈id_Y, then f is a homotopy equivalence , and X and Y are said to be homotopy equivalent , or to have the same homotopy type.

sentence:
A digital image is contractible (to a point) if it is homotopy equivalent to a point.  Notice that this is equivalent to saying there is some x_0 ∈ X and some N,  for which we have a homotopy
H  X × I_N →  X  with H(x, 0) = x, and H(x, N) = x_0.

sentence:
Let G be a graph and k ≥ 3.
Let v be a vertex of G and 𝒟 be a {2k-1,2k,2k+1}-decomposition of G.
We say that 𝒟 is k-balanced (or simply balanced ) at v if 
the number of paths of 𝒟 of 
length at most 2k with end vertex v is at least 
the number of paths of 𝒟 of 
length at least 2k+1 with end vertex v.
Further, we say that 𝒟 is a k-balanced decomposition of G 
if it is k-balanced at every vertex of G
and the number of paths of length 2k-1 is equal to the number of paths of length 2k+1.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Quasi-balanced decompositions]
        Let X be an extension of s(j,l). 
        We refer to a {2k-1,2k,2k+1}-decomposition 𝒟 of X 
        as quasi-k-balanced (or simply, quasi-balanced)
        if 𝒟 is k-balanced at all vertices of X,
	except possibly, at the vertices of odd degree of X
	incident to an edge of {e_j-1,e_j+l+1}.
	In addition, if 𝒟 is not k-balanced at 
	v ∈ e for  e ∈{e_j-1,e_j+l+1}, then 
	e ∈ X.

sentence:
Let M be a positive affine monoid. An element x∈ M is irreducible if x≠ 0 and x=y+z with y,z∈ M implies
y=0 or z=0. A subset B
of M is a system of generators if
M=_+B. The unique minimal
system of generators of M given by its irreducible elements
is called the Hilbert basis and denoted by (M).

sentence:
Let G and H be digraphs with roots g_0 and h_0.  A robust map
from G to H is a map ϕ V(G) → V(H) with ϕ(g_0) = h_0 such

vertex z in G such that ϕ(z)=w and vz∈ E(G).

sentence:
A rooted ribbon tree (RRT) is a tree T with a choice of a root α_∈ T and a cyclic ordering of the edges incident to each vertex; we orient such a tree toward the root.
We say that a vertex α of an RRT T is interior if the set (α) of its incoming neighbors is nonempty, and we denote the set of interior vertices of T by T_.
An RRT T is stable if every interior vertex has at least 2 incoming edges.
We define K^_r to be the set of all isomorphism classes of stable rooted ribbon trees with r leaves.

We denote the i-th leaf of an RRT T by λ_i^T.
For any α, β∈ T, T_αβ denotes those vertices γ such that the path [α,γ] from α to γ passes through β.
We denote T_α T_α_α.

  ⊆ [0,1] be intervals. We say that (I, J) is

    |d_f(A, B) - d_f(I, J)| ≤ϵ.

   is interval ϵ-regular for f if all except at most ϵ k^2
  pairs of intervals (I, J) of  are interval
  ϵ-regular for f.

sentence:
Let ρ be a permutation of size K and π_1,⋯,π_r be permutations such that ∑_i=1^r |π_i| = K.
An ordered set-partition (I_i)_1 ≤ i ≤ r of {1, … K} is compatible with ρ, π_1,⋯,π_r
if for all i, _I_i(ρ) = π_i.

Let d_π_1,…,π_r^ρ be the number of ordered set-partitions compatible with ρ, π_1,⋯,π_r.
We denote by

    c_π_1,…,π_r^ρ = d_π_1,…,π_r^ρ/K|π_1|,…,|π_r|

the proportion of ordered set-partitions of {1, … K} which are compatible with ρ, π_1,⋯,π_r.

sentence:
A cluster algebra has polynomial growth if the number of
distinct seeds which can be obtained from a fixed initial seed by at most n mutations is bounded from above by
a polynomial function of n.  A cluster algebra has exponential growth
if the number of such seeds is bounded from below by an exponentially
growing function of n.

sentence:
We define the collection of inductively toggle-alternating sets of subsets to be the smallest collection of ℒ⊆ 2^E, with essentializations (ℒ',E'), such that:


  * if |E'|≤ 4, then T(ℒ) is toggle-alternating;

  * if |E'|≥ 5, 
then there exists e∈ E' such that at least one of the following holds:


  * ℒ_e is inductively toggle-alternating, ℒ_e∪ t_e(ℒ_e) = ℒ, and ℒ_e∩ t_e(ℒ_e) ≠∅, or

  * ℒ_e is inductively toggle-alternating, ℒ_e∪ t_e(ℒ_e) = ℒ, and ℒ_e∩ t_e(ℒ_e) ≠∅.

sentence:

  * ∅∈ℒ and E∈ℒ;

  * If X,Y∈ℒ, then X∩ Y∈ℒ; and

  * If X∈ℒ∖{E}, then there exists e∈ E∖ X such that X∪{e}∈ℒ.

The elements of ℒ are called the convex sets .

sentence:
[Jin. Set of differences is piecewise syndetic]
Jin's theorem
Let A and B be two sets of natural numbers with positive upper Banach density. Then, the set of differences[Actually, Jin has proved this for the set of sums A+B, but that is of negligible importance here.]

    A-B := {a-b : a∈ A,b∈ B}∩

is piecewise syndetic .
