sentence: Let G be a graph with distinct vertices a and b. The shortest path graph (SPG) of G with respect to a and b, denoted S(G,a,b), is a graph where each vertex corresponds to a shortest path in G from a to b, and two vertices U,W ∈ V(S(G,a,b)) are adjacent if and only if their corresponding paths in G differ in exactly one vertex.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A topologically closed set C⊆ R^n is called a cone
if for all u,v∈ C and λ,μ≥0, λ u+μ v∈ C.  A
cone C is called line-free if u,-u∈ C implies u=0.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O

sentence:
A sequence (f_n) of monotone increasing Boolean functions
is said to be 1-witness-disjoint if

    lim_n→∞max_W∈_1(⋃_
    W' ∈_1∖{W}
     W'∩ W ≠∅{ω_W'≡ 1} | ω_W≡1) =0 .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: The boundary ∂(D) of D is the set of all of its boundary vertices; that is  ∂(D) = {v ∈ V | ∃ u ∈ V, ∀ w ∈ N(v) : d(u,w)≤ d(u, v)}.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The eccentricity Ecc(D) of a digraph D is the set of all of its eccentric vertices;  
	Ecc(D) = {v ∈ V(D) | ∃ u ∈ V(D), ecc(u) = d(u, v)}.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Monoid of regressive order preserving functions]
  Let (P, ≤_P) be a poset. The set (P) of functions f: P → P which are
  
  
  * order preserving , that is, for all x,y∈ P, x≤_P y implies
    x.f≤_P y.f
  
  * regressive , that is, for all x∈ P one has x.f ≤_P x
  
  is a monoid under composition.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For h≥ 0, and n≥ 1, we define the h-Fibonacci sequence
ℱ^(h)={F_n^(h)}_n≥ 1 whose elements are

    F_n^(h) = 
    1    if  n ≤ h+1 , 
    
    F_n-1^(h)+F_n-h-1^(h)   if  n>h+1.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A curve is called shortest if any other curve between the same endpoints has more or equal length.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: An edge covering of a graph G = (V, E) is such a subset E' of its edges that any vertex of graph is incident to at least one edge from E'.
word_labels: B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: An edge precovering of graph G with selected vertex v is such a subset E' of its vertices that any vertex in the graph G, except v is incident to at least one edge from E' (vertex v may or may not be incident to edges from E').
word_labels: B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let Δ be a simplicial complex. A (finite, simplicial) homology subdivision of Δ (over ) is a simplicial complex Δ' together with a map σ: Δ' →Δ such that the following hold for every F ∈Δ: (a) the set Δ'_F := σ^-1 (2^F) is a subcomplex of Δ' which is a homology ball (over ) of dimension (F); and (b) σ^-1 (F) consists of the interior faces of Δ'_F.

Such a map σ is said to be a topological subdivision if Δ'_F is homeomorphic to a ball of dimension (F) for every F ∈Δ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let σ and τ be affine simplices of complementary dimensions k+ℓ
= m in ^m 
with vertices σ_0, …, σ_k and
τ_0, …, τ_ℓ respectively, of complementary dimensions k+ℓ
= m. Suppose  that σ_0, …, σ_k, τ_0, …, τ_ℓ are in
general position and the simplices are oriented according to the
increasing order of the indices. Then σ and τ intersect in
at most one point. The intersection numberintersection number!of simplices (σ,
τ) is defined to be zero if σ and τ don't intersect
and ± 1 according to the orientation of the full dimensional
simplex (p, σ_1, …, σ_k, τ_1, …, τ_ℓ)
if σ and τ intersect in p. This definition extends
bilinearly to simplicial chains in ^m. (We consider integral chains, that is, 
formal combinations of affine simplices in ^m with integer coefficients.)
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let U ⊂^k and V ⊂^ℓ be sets that are closures of their interiors 
and φ : U →^m and ψ : V →^m smooth parametrized surfaces.
The surfaces φ and ψ intersect transversally at p =
φ(α) = ψ (β) with α∈∘U and β∈∘V, if 

    T_p^m = dφ(T_α U) ⊕ dψ(T_β V)

In other words k + ℓ = m and the vectors 

    .∂φ/∂ u_1|_α , …, 
    .∂φ/∂ u_k|_α ,
    .∂ψ/∂ v_1|_β , …, 
    .∂ψ/∂ v_ℓ|_β

span ^m.
In this situation the index of intersection of φ and ψ in
p is defined by 

    _p(φ, ψ)   :=   (
    .∂φ/∂ u_1|_α , …, 
    .∂φ/∂ u_k|_α ,
    .∂ψ/∂ v_1|_β , …, 
    .∂ψ/∂ v_ℓ|_β).

The surfaces φ and ψ are in general position if they
intersect transversally only. In particular there are no intersections
at the boundary. Surfaces in general position intersect in finitely many points only and the
intersection number intersection number!of parametrized surfaces is defined by

    (φ, ψ)  
    := ∑_p = φ(α) = ψ(β)_p(φ, ψ).

We also write (φ(U), ψ(V)) for (φ, ψ) when we want to 
emphasize the fact that the images intersect.

sentence:
A weighted involution in _n is a pair (w, ϕ)
where w ∈_n and ϕ is a map (w) → with ϕ(i,j) = ϕ(i+n,j+n) for all (i,j) ∈(w).
We refer to ϕ as the weight map of (w,ϕ).
Define 
 the weight of (w,ϕ) as the number (w,ϕ) = ∑_γϕ(γ) where the sum is over a set of cycles γ representing the distinct equivalence classes in (w) under the relation  (i,j) ∼ (i+n,j+n).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let B_4^* be the poset resulting from B_4 if the two-element sets, or doubles , are replaced with chains of length 3. Then B_4^* is not diametrally reversing.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let Π_1 and Π_2 be two polyhedral complexes. An affine map Π_1→Π_2 is a map
f:|Π_1|→|Π_2|, such that for every p∈Π_1 there exists q∈Π_2, satisfying the conditions f(p)⊂ q and π_q∘ f∘π_p^-1:P_p→ P_q is an affine map.  The set of affine maps Π_1→Π_2 will be denoted by (Π_1,Π_2) and called the affine hom-complex between Π_1 and Π_2 . The set (Π_1,Π_2) is a subspace of the topological space of continuous maps |Π_1|→|Π_2| with the compact-open topology.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let n, k ∈ with k ≤ n.
An oriented k-shuffle is performed as follows.
Remove k cards from the deck. Then choose any j ∈{0,1,…,k} of the
k cards
and flip these j cards  over as a block.
Place the j flipped cards on top of the deck, and then put the k-j
unflipped cards on top of them.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let G be a graph, let G_0=G, and for i≥ 1, let G_i=G_i-1-{all non-articulation points of the outer blocks of G_i-1}. We will say a block of G has depth i if it is an outer block of G_i.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Under the Assumption <ref>, let ϕ=f_1∘…∘ f_k be a legal composition, and  x∈(ϕ). The orbit of 
x under ϕ, denoted by Ø_x, is defined to be the set {x}∪{f_t∘…∘ f_k(x): 1≤ t≤ k}. We sometimes use the notation 


    Ø_x={x_0,x_1,…,x_k},


where x_0=x and x_i=f_k-i+1∘…∘ f_k(x) for 1≤ i≤ k. 

We say that ϕ(x) touches 0 (or 1) if the orbit of x under ϕ includes 0 (or 1).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let μ and ν be two probability measures on a finite set X.
The total variation distance d(μ,ν) is defined to be
max_A⊂ X|μ(A)-ν(A)|.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O

sentence:
Suppose that 𝒜=( ℱ
_1,M_1,ℱ_2,M_2,… ,ℱ_k,M_k) is a
tuple such that for every n=1,2,… ,k, ℱ_n is a nonempty
finite collection of partial semigroup homomorphisms from S_≤ n to S_≤ n-1, and M_n is an adequate subsemigroup of S_n for n=1,2,… ,k. We say that 𝒜 is a tetris action on S
if and only if it satisfies for any n=2,3,… ,k, and σ∈ℱ_n the following conditions:



  * the image of M_n under σ is an adequate partial
subsemigroup of M_n-1;


  * the image of S_n under σ is an adequate partial
subsemigroup of S_n-1;


  * the restriction of σ to S_≤ n-1 either belongs to ℱ_n-1, or it is the identity map of S_≤ n-1, and


  * for any σ _1,σ _2∈ℱ_n one has that σ _1|_M_n=σ _2|_M_n.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let G be a group of order mn containing a subgroup N of order n. A k-subset R of G is called a relative (m,n,k,λ) difference set (relative to N) if the list of nonzero differences r-r' with r,r'∈ R contains all elements in G∖ N exactly λ times and no element in N. The subgroup N is called the forbidden subgroup .

sentence:
Let C be a d-dimensional cube. For any cubical subdivision Γ of
    C, we define a polynomial _C (Γ, x) = _0 + _1 x + ⋯ +
    _d+1 x^d+1 by
      
    _C (Γ, x)  = ∑_F ∈(C) (-1)^d - (F)  h^(c)
            (Γ_F, x).

    We call _C (Γ, x) the (long) cubical local h-polynomial of
    Γ (with respect to C). We call _C (Γ) = (_0,
    _1,…,_d+1) the (long) cubical local h-vector of Γ
    (with respect to C).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O

sentence:
Let P be a locally graded poset and κ∈ I(P) be unitary.
     
       
  (a) Assume that P is lower graded. A function f: P →[x] is
       called κ-acceptable if f κ = f, i.e., if
         
    ∑_s ≤_P   t f_s (x) κ_st (x)  =  f_t (x)

       for every t ∈ P.
       
  (b) A function g ∈ I(P) is called κ-totally acceptable
       if g κ = g, i.e., if
        
    ∑_s ≤_P   t ≤_P   u g_st (x) κ_tu (x)  = g_su (x)

      for all s ≤_P t.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let X be a finite T_0–space. We say that X is quasicellular if there exists an order preserving map ρ:X⟶_0, which will be called quasicellular morphism for X , such that


  * The set {x∈ X:ρ(x)=n} is an antichain for every n∈_0. 

  * For every x∈ X, the reduced homology of Û_x is concentrated in degree ρ(x)-1.

sentence:

We define the principally specialized character of V(Λ) as follows:

    χ__n^Λ(t) = χ__n^Λ|_e(Λ)=1 
     e(-α_i)=t,  for all  i ∈ I.

Here t is an indeterminate. Considering (<ref>), χ__n^Λ(t) is written as

    χ^Λ__n=∑_μ∈ wt(V(Λ))  (_(q) V_μ )t^∑_i ∈ Iμ_i
    =∑_m ∈_≥ 0( ∑_μ∈ wt(V(Λ)),
    (Λ-μ)=m (_(q) V_μ ) )t^m.

sentence:
Let P:^n→ be a degree-d polynomial, possibly non-classical. Define the derivative polynomial
∂ P:(^n)^d→ by the following formula

    ∂ P(h_1,…,h_d) D_h_1⋯ D_h_dP(0),

where h_1,…,h_d∈^n.[Notice since P is a degree d polynomial, D_h_1… D_h_dP(x) does not depend on x and thus we have the identity ∂ P(h_1,…,h_d)=D_h_1… D_h_dP(x) for any choice of x∈^n.]
Moreover for k< d define

    ∂_kP(x, h_1,…,h_k) D_h_1⋯ D_h_kP(x).

sentence:
Let G be a triangulation of a surface  F^2 possibly with non-empty boundary. Let v_1v_2v_3 be
a cycle  of G such that deg(v_i)=4 for i=1, 2, 3 and
 {a_1, a_2, a_3}  be the only three vertices
such that a_i is adjacent to v_j and v_k for {i, j, k}={1,2,3}. The subgraph H⊂
G induced by the vertex set {a_1, a_2, a_3, v_1, v_2, v_3} is said to be  an
 octahedron component  centered at
v_1v_2v_3 with remaining vertices a_1, a_2, a_3 if the cycle a_1a_2a_3 exists in G (and
hence in H) and one of the following conditions holds:



  * v_i∉∂ G for all i=1,2,3.

  *  Only one v_i lies in ∂ G and ∂ G coincides with
v_ia_ja_k.

  * Exactly v_i, v_j∈∂ G and hence  ∂
G=v_iv_ja_k.

  * v_i∈∂ G  for all i=1,2,3 and hence
∂ G= v_iv_jv_k.

An octahedron component of G is said to be external if two edges a_ia_j, a_ja_k lie in
∂ G (in particular, δ(a_j)=4). Observe that this happens only under  condition 1.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:

G consists of a subgraph 𝒩 of G determined by two faces sharing an edge, where
their two non-incident edges are contractible and at least one of them lies in ∂ G (Figure
<ref>).



        
    < g r a p h i c s >



N-component: two  faces share the  edge xz the non-incident  edges xy and vz must
be contractible and, at least one of them must lie in ∂ G.

sentence:
A set U ⊂ is  complete if
  (U)=⋃_t ∈ U C_J(t, U).

sentence:
[cf. Definition <ref>]
    
         Fix a coloring of the cells of the set M_n into 2 colors ±1. We say that in this coloring there exists percolation between two sides A and B of the hexagon P in M_n , if some cell of the side A is joined with some cell of the side B by a chain of adjacent cells such that each cell in the chain has color +1, including the initial cell of the side A and the final cell of the side B.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G be a simple graph. For each pair of
distinct vertices v and w of G, let β(v,w) and β(w,v) be
distinct variables. Then the Naji equations for G are the following.


  * If vw is an edge of G then β(v,w)+β(w,v)=1.


  * If v,w,x are three distinct vertices of G such that vw is an edge of G and vx,wx are not edges of G, then β(x,v)+β(x,w)=0.


  * If v,w,x are three distinct vertices of G such that vw,vx are edges of G and wx is not an edge of G, then β(v,w)+β(v,x)+β(w,x)+β(x,w)=1.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let (P,≼,∧,∨) be a poset and f a complex-valued function defined on P. The function f is semimultiplicative if

    f(x∧ y)f(x∨ y)=f(x)f(y)  for all x,y∈ P.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The Minimization Price Bound of order n∈^* for a linear combination
  of layered permutations f is the value
  
    _n,f    = min{q_n,f(x_1,x_2,…,x_n) : ∑_j=1^nx_j = 1
         and ∀ j∈[n], x_j≥ 0}.

sentence: For r=p/q, a point x∈ X is q-swift if (x,f_r(x),…,f_r^q(x))=p and the open arc (f_r^q(x),x)_S^1 does not contain any point of X.

sentence:
[ Cyclic grid graphs ] To define cyclic grid graphs, we introduce the Cartesian product group ⟨≜(ℤ/ℓ_1ℤ) ×(ℤ/ℓ_2ℤ) ×…×(ℤ/ℓ_dℤ), + ⟩.
Elements in  are d-dimensional vectors.
We denote the canonical basis vectors (_i)_1≤ i ≤ d such that _i[j] = 1 if j = i and 0 otherwise.
We consider that two elements v_1,  v_2 of  are neighbors if v_1 -  v_2 = ±_i.
Then the cyclic grid graph with parameters d and (ℓ_i)_1≤ i ≤ d is the graph = ⟨, ⟩ such that ( v_1, v_2) ∈ if and only if v_1 and v_2 are neighbors.

sentence:
Let G = (V, E) and G' = (V', E') be graphs.
A mapping h  V → V' is a homomorphism of G to G', denoted h  G → G', if h maps edges to edges, i.e., for all u, v ∈ V, (u,v) ∈ E implies (h(u), h(v)) ∈ E'.
A homomorphism h  G → G' is strong if, in addition, it maps nonedges to nonedges, i.e., for all u, v ∈ V, (u,v) ∉ E implies (h(u), h(v)) ∉ E'.
In other words, h  V → V' is a strong homomorphism if for all u, v ∈ V, (u,v) ∈ E if and only if (h(u), h(v)) ∈ E'.
If h  G → G' is surjective (and strong), then G' is called a strong homomorphic image of G.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let T(X) be the set of all terms of type (2,0) over a set X of variables, using juxtaposition as the binary operation symbol and ∞ as the unary operation symbol.
In other words, T(X) is defined inductively as follows:


  *  Every x ∈ X is a term, and ∞ is a term.

  *  If t_1 and t_2 are terms, then (t_1 t_2) is a term.

  * T(X) is the set of all terms which can be obtained from <ref> and <ref> in finitely many steps.


Unless otherwise mentioned, we assume that X is the standard set of variables {x_1, x_2, x_3, …}.
The set of variables occurring in a term t is denoted by (t).
The leftmost variable occurring in t is denoted by L(t).
A term is called trivial if it contains an occurrence of the symbol ∞.

sentence:
[Separation]
  A separation of a graph G is a pair (A, B) such that
  [(i)]
  
  * A ∪ B = V(G) and
  
  * there are no edges between A ∖ B and B ∖ A in G.
  
  Informally, we sometimes call A and B the sides of (A, B). The integer |A ∩ B| is called the order of the separation. We say that a separation (A, B) is nontrivial if A ∖ B ≠∅≠ B ∖ A.

Let (Y, y_0) be a based digital image with Y ⊆^n.
A based loop of length N in Y is a path γ I_N → Y that satisfies γ(0) = γ(N) = y_0.  If γ I_N → Y is a based loop in Y, then for any k,


    γ∘ρ_k S(I_N, k) → I_N → Y


is also a based loop (of length kN + k-1), in that we have S(I_N, k)  = I_kN + k-1 and γ∘ρ_k(0) = γ(0) = y_0 and γ∘ρ_k(kN+k-1) = γ(N) = y_0.

sentence:
[Cut metric] For a graphon
W  [0,1]^2 →, define the cut norm by

    W_□ := sup_S,T ⊆ [0,1]∫_S  T
    W(x,y)   dx dy,

where S and T range over measurable subsets of [0,1]. Given two
graphons W, W'  [0,1]^2 →, define

    d_□(W,W') := W - W'_□

and the cut metric (or cut distance ) δ_□ by

    δ_□(W,W') := inf_σ d_□(W^σ,W'),

where σ ranges over all measure-preserving bijections [0,1] →
[0,1] and W^σ(x,y) := W(σ(x), σ(y)).

sentence:
A partial matching in a poset P is a partial matching
in the underlying graph of the Hasse diagram of P, that is, a
subset M⊆ P× P such that (x,y)∈ M implies

of M.  For (x,y)∈ M we write x=d(y) and y=u(x),
where d and u stand for down and up, respectively.

sentence:
[Nondeterministic Read-once branching programs (NROBPs).]
Let V be a set of Boolean variables.
Let Z be a directed acyclic graph (DAG) with one source and one sink so that some
of the edges are labelled with literals of V.
We say that v ∈ V occurs on edge e is Z is Z is labelled with a literal
of v. The occurrence can be positive or negative if the labelling literal
is v and v, respectively.

We say that Z is a nondeterministic read-once branching program (NROBP) implementing a function
on V if each variable of V occurs exactly once [The requirement of
exactly one occurrence rather than at most one means that the NROBP is uniform. Since it is known that every
NROBP can be simulated by a uniform one with only a polynomial increase of the number of nodes (see e.g. <cit.>),
we assume the uniformity w.l.o.g.] on each source-sink path of Z.

For a path P of Z we denote by A(P) the set of literals labelling P and Var(A(P)) is denoted by Var(P).
Then the set of satisfying assignments of the function represented by Z consists of all A(P) 
such that P is a source-sink path of Z.

Let 𝔽^n be a vector space. Let v_1,…,v_k ∈𝔽^n. We say that these vectors are affine independent if 
    λ_1v_1 + ⋯ + λ_kv_k = 0
 implies that 
    λ_1 =  ⋯ = λ_k = 0
 for any λ_1,…,λ_k ∈𝔽 for which λ_1 + ⋯ + λ_k = 0. Otherwise, these vectors are affine dependent . We say that a set of vectors S is a basis for an affine subspace if they are affine independent and every vector in the subspace is an affine combination of vectors in S.

sentence:
<cit.>.

A Boolean function f : _2^m _2 is bent
if its Hada­mard transform has constant magnitude.
Specifically:

 
  * The Sylvester Hada­mard matrix H_m, of order 2^m,
is defined by

    H_1    :=
    [
    [ 1 1; 1 - ]],
    
    
    H_m    := H_m-1⊗ H_1,   for   m > 1.



  * For a Boolean function f : _2^m _2,
define the vector f by

    f   := [(-1)^f[0], (-1)^f[1], …, (-1)^f[2^m-1]]^T,

where the value of f[i], i ∈_2^m is given by the value of f on the binary digits of i.

  * In terms of these two definitions, the Boolean function f : _2^m _2 is bent if

    H_m f   = C [1, …, 1]^T.

for some constant C.

sentence:
Given a graph G=(V,E) on n vertices and A⊆ 2^<n, we say that an indexing V={a_η: η∈ A} of V by the elements of A is a type tree , if for each η∈ A the following holds.  


  * If η∧ 0 ∈ A, then a_η∧ 0 is non-adjacent to a_η.  If η∧ 1∈ A, then  a_η∧ 1 is adjacent to a_η.

  * If η∧ 0 and η∧ 1 are both in A, then for all η'◃η, a_η∧ 1 is adjacent to a_η' if and only if a_η∧ 0 is adjacent to a_η'.

sentence:
A weakly increasing binary tree is
    
        
  * a binary tree that is not necessarily complete, i.e. , the nodes have arity 0, 1 (with two possibilities:
        either a left child or a right one) or 2;
        
  * the nodes are labeled according to the following constraints:
        
            
  * If a node has label k, then all integers from 1 to k-1 appear as
            labels in the tree. The set of labels is therefore a complete interval of integers 
            of the form {1,2,…,m} where m is the maximal label occurring in the tree. 
            
  * Along each branch, starting from the root, the sequence of labels is (strictly) increasing.

sentence:
Let C be a code in H(m,q) with covering radius ρ, and s be an integer with 0≤ s≤ρ. Then,
 
  
  * C is s-regular if, for each i∈{0,1,…,s}, each k∈{0,1,…,m}, and every vertex ν∈ C_i, the number |_k(ν)∩ C| depends only on i and k, and,
  
  * C is completely regular if C is ρ-regular.

sentence:
Let Z ⊂[d]k be any family of k-subsets.  The totally nonnegative cell associated to Z in Gr(k,d)^tnn is the set

    S_Z = {M ∈ Gr(k,d)^tnn : Δ_I(M) = 0  if and only if  I ∈ Z}.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let k,d be positive integers with k < d, and ℐ = (I_1, …, I_d) a sequence of k-subsets of 1d.  Then ℐ is a Grassmann necklace of type (k,d) if it satisfies:


  * If i ∈ I_i then I_i+1 = (I_i \{i}) ∪{j} for some j ∈1d.

  * If i ∉I_i then I_i+1 = I_i.

for each i ∈1d.  Note that all indices are taken modulo d.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Given a compact set E ⊂ R^d define  the set of distinct  similar simplices determined by E to be  S_k(E):= E^k+1 / ∼, where (x^1, …, x^k+1) ∼ (y^1, …, y^k+1) iff {x^i}_j=1^k+1 and {y^i}_j=1^k+1 are nondegenerate and, for some λ>0, |x^i-x^j|=λ |y^i-y^j|,  for 1 ≤ i<j ≤ k+1.

sentence: A strong-Baxter permutation is a permutation that avoids all three vincular patterns ,  and .

sentence:
Define the transformation T [0,1]∖→ [0,1]∖ by Tα = 1/α, where { x } denotes the fractional part of x. (One may extend the definition to  by setting Tα = 0 for x ∈ if one wishes to have a map T [0,1] → [0,1].)
	
	Define the measure μ on [0,1] by μ(A) = 1/log 2∫_Adx/x+1 for A ∈([0,1]), where ([0,1]) denotes the Borel σ-algebra.
	
	We refer to the transformation T as the continued fraction transformation and to  μ as the Gauss measure .

sentence:
A weighted planar binary tree is a pair (t, ω) made up of a planar binary tree t∈n with n leaves having some weight ω= (ω_1, …, ω_n) ∈^n. We call 
ω the weight and
n the arity of the tree t or the length of the weight ω.

sentence:
The Loday realization of weight ω is the  polytope

    _ω{M(t, ω)| t∈n}⊂^n-1 .
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let u and v be vectors of length n. 
Then u≼ v (that is u is majorized by v) if

    ∑_i=1^k u_[i]≤∑_i=1^k v_[i],    1≤ k≤ n-1
    ∑_i=1^n u_i = ∑_i=1^n v_i

where the vector (u_[1],u_[2],…,u_[n]) is obtained from u by rearranging its components so that they are in decreasing order, and similarly for v.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The Kronecker matrix has rows indexed by the product

    {}×{}×{}

and columns indexed by the product

    {}×{}×{},

where the ((p, q, r), (s, t, u)) entry is given by the formula 

    ∑_σ∈ S_nY(σ s,p) ·Y(σ t, q) ·Y(σ u, r).

Its columns define the Kronecker matroid .
The convex hull of its columns defines the Kronecker polytope .

sentence: A simplicial poset is a poset with a minimal element 0̂ in which every principal order ideal [0̂,x] is a boolean algebra.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The complementary depth of an n × n {± 1} matrix A
is the maximum m_d < n such that a maxdet matrix of order m_d
occurs as a proper submatrix of A, or 0 if n=1.
The depth of A is d(A) := n-m_d(A).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O

sentence:
The complementary depth m_d:→ is the maximum of the
complementary depth of A over all maxdet matrices A of order n.
The depth d:→ is defined by d(n) := n - m_d(n).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O

sentence: The Cartesian product G   H is the graph created by placing copies of G at all of the vertices of H and connecting corresponding vertices of adjacent G's in H.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[collapsible simplicial complex] 
Let  be a simplicial complex and F' be a maximal proper face of
exactly one facet F of . The complex Γ={F,F'} is
said to be obtained from  using an elementary collapse . If a
sequence of elementary collapses reduces  to a single point, then
 is called collapsible .

sentence:
[Fourier decay] We say that a majorant ν has Fourier decay of level θ if

    ν̂ - 1̂_[N]_∞≤θ N.

sentence:
Let G=(V,E) be a graph and ϕ E→{,}.
	We say ϕ is extremal if there is a pair of distinct vertices 
	r∈ R^ϕ and b∈ B^ϕ for which no monochromatic r-b-path exists.
	If no such pair of vertices exists, then we say ϕ is non-extremal .

sentence:
Let 𝒫 be an order-hereditary property of k-colourings with 𝒫_n ≠∅ for every n∈. For every n∈, we define the extremal entropy of 𝒫 to be 

    (n, 𝒫)=max{(t)  :    t  is a k-colouring template for K_n  with ⟨ t ⟩⊆𝒫_n}.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: (Whitman <cit.>) A lattice L satisfies Whitman's Condition if for all a,b,c,d ∈ L satisfying a ∧ b ≤ c ∨ d, a ≤ c ∨ d, b ≤ c ∨ d, a ∧ b ≤ c, or a ∧ b ≤ d.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: (<cit.>, p. 81) A variety 𝒱 of lattices is semidistributive if every member of 𝒱 is semidistributive.

sentence:
Let P ∈_d(d+3) satisfy Property Z. If P is even, assume that P is not cyclic. Then
P={ P_1 ∪ P_2 ∪ P_3}, where P_1, P_2 and P_3 are regular simplices inscribed in ^d-1 and contained in three mutually orthogonal linear subspaces of ^d.
Furthermore:


  * If d is odd and P has maximal volume over _d(d+3), then the dimensions of P_1, P_2 and P_3 are ⌊ d/3 ⌋ or 
⌈ d/3 ⌉. In particular, in this case we have

    ( v_d(d+3) = ) _d(P) = 1/d!·∏_i=1^3 (k_i+1)^k_i+1/2 k_i^- k_i/2,

where k_1+k_2+k_3 = d and for every i, we have k_i ∈{⌊d/3⌋,  ⌈d/3⌉}. 

  * The same holds for the dimensions of P_1, P_2 and P_3, if d is even, and P has maximal volume over the family of not cyclic elements of _d(d+3), satisfying Property Z.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O

sentence: A family  on n points is left-compressed if whenever A ∈, i ∈ A, j ∉ A, and j < i, then (A ∖{i}) ∪{j}∈. (Informally, we can shift i to j.)
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O

sentence: A set A ⊆_m is s-agreeing if every a,b ∈ A satisfy a-b ∈{-(s-1),…,s-1}. Two sets A,B ⊆_m are cross-s-agreeing if every a ∈ A and b ∈ B satisfy a-b ∈{-(s-1),…,s-1}.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Fix n,m ≥ 1 and s ≤ m/2. For y ∈_m^n, the mapping σ_y_m^n → 2^[n] is given by σ_y(x) = {i ∈ [n] : 1 ≤ x_i-y_i ≤ s}.
 
 If  is a family on _m^n and  is a family on n points then ≈ (or,  is equivalent to ) if = σ_y^-1() for some vector y ∈_m^n. In words,  arises from  by going through all sets S ∈, replacing each i ∈ S by all values in {y_1+1,…,y_1+s}, and each i ∉ S by all other values.
 
 We say that  is equivalent to a (t,r)-Frankl family if ≈ for some family  equivalent to a (t,r)-Frankl family (see Definition <ref>).

sentence:
Let r>2 be an integer. The double wheel of order r (denoted r) is a cycle of length r whose each vertex is adjacent to two different extra vertices, in other words it is the graph of the form
   
   
    G =    {o_1, o_2, w_1,…, w_r}
    G =    {w_1,w_2, w_2,w_3, …, w_r-1, w_r,
         w_r, w_1}
       ∪o_1,w_1, …,
           o_1,w_r
       ∪o_2,w_1, …,
         o_2,w_r

   (see Figure <ref> for an example)
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Trees and cycles]
Given a tree T we denote by T the set of its leaves,  vertices of degree 1
and by (T) its diameter, that is the maximum length (in number of edges) of a path
in T.

For every two vertices u,v ∈T,
there is exactly one path in T between u and v, that we denote
by uTv. Also, given that uTv has at least 2
vertices, we denote by uTv
(resp. uTv) the path uTv without vertex
u (resp. v).

Let C be a cycle on which we fixed some orientation.
Then, there is exactly one path following this orientation between any two
vertices u,v ∈C. Similarly, we denote this path by
uCv and we define uCv and
uCv as we did for the tree.

In a rooted tree T 
of root r, the least common ancestor of two vertices u and
v, written T(u,v) is the first common vertex of the paths
uTr and vTr. We refer to the root of T
by the notation (T).

For every integer h>0, we denote by B_h the complete binary tree
of height h.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: For π∈ S_n, let ℋ_{0,2}(π) be the set of valid hook configurations ℋ∈ℋ(π) in which each point in NE(ℋ) is the northeast endpoint of exactly two hooks.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O

sentence:
For every integer 1≤ k< n, the characteristic polynomial of ^(k,n) is

    χ(^(k,n),q)=q(q-n)^n-1 .
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O

sentence:
[Cf. <cit.>]
Let =(V,A) be a (finite) directed connected multigraph without loops, where V=[n] for some n∈.
A function [n]→_0 is a -parking function if for every non-empty subset I⊆[n] there exists a vertex i∈ I such that the number of elements j∉ I such that (i,j)∈ A, counted with multiplicity, is greater than or equal to (i).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: An angle in a -graph is a pair of adjacent half-edges at a vertex.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A checkerboard embedding of a  -graph Γ into S is an embedding such that the cells of S ∖Γ admit a 2-coloring under which any cells with a common edge have different colors.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A -atom is a closed 2-surface S into which a connected graph Γ (the skeleton of the -atom) is embedded in such a way that it divides S into black and white cells so that cells sharing an edge have different colors.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A permissible partition of the indices of M(D'_Γ, C) is a partition of the indices of M(D'_Γ, C) (which are just the chords of D'_Γ, C) into two parts, in such a way that chords arising from the same triad in D_Γ, C are in the same part, and chords arising from the same double chord in D_Γ, C are in different parts.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let G be a finite group.  If G has subgroups S_1,S_2,…, S_m with the property that S_1^*,S_2^*,… , S_m^* partition G^*, then the collection of subgroups S_1,S_2,…, S_m is called a group partition of G.  A group partition is called trivial if m=1.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O

sentence:
We say that a connected divide P' is a subdivide of P, if P' can be obtained from P by several desingularizations and isotopies. 
We then write P' P.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A discal graph is a graph embedded into D such that the edges intersect ∂ D in vertices only, and whose vertices are 
colored as follows: 
the vertices lying in the interior of D are black, those lying on ∂ D are white. 
If there is exactly one vertex on ∂ D, we can also draw a star instead of coloring in white. 

We denote by  the family of all isotopy classes of discal graphs.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: For Σ an oriented surface in ^3, the signature of Σ is the signature of any symmetrized Seifert matrix S+^tS.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A sum-`n+2' transform always results in a better sequence.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
For a graded gentle tree G,
let V be a vertex with neighborhood

    @C=1.5pc@R=1.5pcR_1 [dr]^γ_1      B_2 @< [dl]_δ_2
        V    
    B_1 @ [ur]^δ_1      R_2 @<-[ul]_γ_2

where B_i, R_i are the sub trees
and γ_i, δ_i are degrees, i=1,2.
The straight line represent one color
and the curly line represent the other color.
Define the forward mutation μ_V at vertex V (on G) as follows:


  * if δ_1 ≥ 1,
    μ_V on the lower part of of the quiver is:
        
    @C=1.8pc@R=1.8pc    V    
    B_1 @ >[ur]^δ_1      R_2 @<-[ul]_γ_2
    @C=0.8pc@R=0.8pc         
    @=>@/^1pc/[rrr]^μ_i         @C=1.8pc@R=1.8pc    V    
    B_1 @ >[ur]^δ_1-1      R_2 @<-[ul]_γ_2+1


  * if δ_1 = 1, denote
    
    @C=0.8pc@R=1.5pc
    B_1    @=[r]       @C=1.5pc@R=1.5pcE_1 [dr]^θ_1      
        W    
    L_1 @ >[ur]^β_1      E_2 @<-[ul]_θ_2

    and μ_V on the lower part of of the quiver is:
    
    @C=1.5pc@R=1.5pcE_1 [dr]^θ_1        V @< [dl]_1 [dr]^γ_2   
        W       R_2 
    L_1 @ >[ur]^β      E_2 @<-[ul]_θ_2
    @C=0.8pc@R=0.8pc      
    @=>@/^.7pc/[rr]^μ_i      @C=1.5pc@R=1.5pc    V @< [dl]_β[dr]^1       E_2^×@< [dl]_θ_2
    L_1        W    
       E_1^×@ >[ur]^θ_1      R_2 @<-[ul]_γ_2

    where X^× is the operation of swapping colors
    on a graded gentle trees X.

  * μ_V on the upper part follows the mirror rule of the lower part. 


Dually, define the backward mutation μ_V^-1 to be the reverse of μ_V
(which follows a similar rule).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
If π∈_n is a permutation of [n]={0,1,…,n-1}, then we
  shall call “π-family” any n-tuple (P_0,P_1,…,P_n-1) where
  P_i is a Schröder-type path form i0 to 0π_i for
  i∈[n]. If π is the identity permutation of [n] we shall call a
  π-family simply an “n-family”. A π-family is called
  disjoint if (P_0), (P_1), … and (P_n-1)
  are all disjoint.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A subset A is -rainbow if no two elements of A are congruent modulo . We write _ for the collection of all -rainbow subsets of .
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: For a network N with leaf set X, let H(𝒬(N)) be the incompatibility graph with vertex set V=X. Define an edge between leaves a and b if there exists single or double reticulation quarnet q∈𝒬(N) such that {a,b}⊂ supp(q) and there is a non-trivial cut edge on the path between a and b on q (see Figure <ref>).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let E be a binary code of length n. We will  define

    (E) = __2{ d(E), ℓ(1^n) }
 to be the code
generated by d(E) and ℓ(1^n). We call the binary code (E) of length 2n the
extended doubling (or simply the doubling ) of E.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O

sentence:
A simplicial complex Δ on vertex set V
is called vertex decomposable if


  * Δ is a simplex, or

  * there is some vertex v ∈ V such that Δ∖ v and 
link_Δ(v) are vertex 
decomposable and do not share any facets; such a vertex v is called a 
shedding vertex of Δ.

sentence:
Let Δ be a simplicial complex on the vertex set
V and let W ⊆ V.  The restriction of Δ to W
(or equivalently, the induced subcomplex over W ) is the
subcomplex

    Δ |_W = {σ∈Δ | σ⊆ W}.

sentence:
Let E be a linearly ordered set. Let G=(V,E) be a graph with set of edges E.

We call filtration of G (or of E) a 
sequence (F'_, …, F'_0, F_c , F_0, …, F_) of subsets of E such that:



=0mm

  * ∅= F'_⊂...⊂ F'_0=F_c=F_0⊂...⊂ F_= E;

  * the sequence min(F_k∖ F_k-1), 1≤ k≤  is increasing with k;

  * the sequence  min(F'_k-1∖ F'_k), 1≤ k≤, is increasing with k.

sentence: An infinite word w is Sturmian if _n(w) = n+1 for all n ≥ 0.

sentence:
An infinite word w over alphabet A (|A| ≥ 2) is episturmian if w has the property _n(w) and has
    at most one right special factor of length n for all n ≥ 0.

sentence:
Episturmian word w is A-strict if for each n ≥ 0 there exists a unique right special factor u of
    length n and ua ∈(w) for all a ∈ A.

sentence:
Let G be a well-tempered scoring game.  A subgame of G is G or a subgame of an option of G.
If S is a set of numbers, we say that G takes values in S or is S-valued if every subgame of G
that is an integer is an element of S.  We denote the class of S-valued well-tempered scoring games 𝒲_S.

sentence:
Let f : S_1 ×⋯× S_n →ℤ be a function.  Then we say that f is order-preserving if

    f(x_1',…,x_n') ≥ f(x_1,…,x_n)

whenever x_i' ≥ x_i for all i.
If f is order-preserving, we call the extension to games f̃ a generalized disjunctive operation .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
Suppose P̃_b is a BLUE path and P̃_r a RED path.
  Then the pair (P̃_b, P̃_r) is a one-step path
    extension of (P_b,P_r) if exactly one of the following holds:
  
  
  * P̃_b is P_b with one additional element at the end
    and P̃_r = P_r, or
  
  * P̃_r is P_r with one additional element at the end
    and P̃_b = P_b, or
  
  * P̃_b is the path P_b with the last element x_b
    removed and P̃_r is P_r with x_b and some integer x
    added in that order at the end, (in this case x_b
    switches to RED), or
  
  * P̃_r is the path P_r with the last element x_r
    removed and P̃_b is P_b with x_r and some integer x
    added in that order at the end, (in this case x_r
    switches to BLUE).
  
 
  
  
  
  
  (P̃_b,P̃_r) is a path extension of
  (P_b, P_r) if it can be obtained from (P_b,P_r) by a sequence of
  one-step path extensions.  Also, if (P̃_b,P̃_r) is a
  path extension of (P_b, P_r), P̃_r=P_r, and x is
  the last element of P̃_b, then we say that
  (P̃_b,P̃_r) is a BLUE path extension of
    (P_b, P_r) to x .  We similarly define a RED path
    extension of (P_b, P_r) to x .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Suppose (P̃_b,P̃_r) is a one-step path extension of
  (P_b,P_r) obtained by Case (3) (i.e. x_b switches to RED and is
  followed by x on P̃_r.)  We say that x_b strongly
    switches to RED if there is no BLUE path extension to x.  We
  similarly define what it means for x_r to strongly switch
  to BLUE.
  
  We say (P̃_b,P̃_r) forms a strong one-step
    path extension of (P_b,P_r) if the pair
  (P̃_b,P̃_r) is a one-step path extension of
  (P_b, P_r) via either Cases (1) or (2), or via Cases (3) or (4)
  with a strong switch.
  
  We say that (P̃_b,P̃_r) forms a strong path
    extension of (P_b,P_r) if it can be obtained from (P_b,P_r)
  by a sequence of strong one-step path extensions.

    ϕ_G = ∑_(T_1,T_2) ∈𝒯 (ρ^T_1)^2∏_e ∉T_1∪ T_2α_e + ψ_G∑_i =1^|E(G)|α_im_i^2.

A pair of vertices u and v is distinguished by a vertex x in a graph X if the distances (x,u) and (x,v) in X are distinct.

sentence:
[Definition 1, <cit.>]
A tree decomposition of G is a pair ({X_i : i ∈ I },T ), where I is an index set, {X_i : i ∈ I } is a collection of subsets of V(G) and T is a tree whose node set is I, such that the following conditions are satisfied:


 
  * ∪_i ∈ I X_i=V(G).
 
  * ∀{u,v}∈ E(G), ∃ i ∈ I such that u,v ∈ X_i.
 
  * ∀ i,j,k ∈ I : if j is on a path in T from i to k, then X_i∩ X_k⊂ X_j.


The width of a tree decomposition ({ X_i : i ∈ I },T) is max{|X_i| : i ∈ I} -1. The treewidth of G, tw(G) , is the minimum width over all tree decompositions of G.

sentence:
[Tubular, tubecentric subdivision]
A tubular subdivision of a complex C is any subdivision E of C for which there exists a sequence of complexes C = C_0, C_1, …, C_m = E, so that each C_i+1 is obtained from C_i by tubing some face τ.

A tubecentric subdivision is a subdivision of a d-complex C obtained by tubing first all d-faces of C, then all (d-1)-faces of C, then all (d-2)-faces, and so on.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Shelling sequences]  Let C be a simplicial d-complex with N facets. Assume that d (N-1) > 0. A shelling step is the removal from a pure simplicial d-complex C of a single d-face whose intersection with the remaining complex is pure (d-1)-dimensional and shellable. Given two pure simplicial d-complexes C and D, we say that “C shells to D”, and write C ↘_ D, if there is a sequence of shelling steps which leads from C to D. The intermediate complexes between C and D form a sequence of subcomplexes (C_i), which we call shelling sequence . By definition, C_i+1 is a subcomplex of C_i obtainable from C_i via a single shelling step.
Clearly, a complex C is shellable if and only if C shells to some facet Δ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Pseudosimplex]
A (d-dimensional) pseudosimplex Δ in S^d is the intersection of d+1 or less hemispheres whose centers lie in convex position. The boundary ∂Δ has a natural decompositon into pseudosimplices, which we will call faces . In the special case when Δ is defined by one hemisphere, we call ∂Δ an equator . If p is a point, we denote by L_p the hemisphere with center p, and by E_p the equator ∂ L_p.

sentence:
We say that a k-uniform hypergraph F=(V_F,E_F) is 
-simple for a set system ⊆([k]), 
if there is an ordering E_F={f_1,…,f_m} of its edges such that for every 
i=1,…,m there is an ordering of the vertices of f_i={x_i_1,…,x_i_k} with the property that for every 
h<i there is a set Q∈ such that

    {r x_i_r∈ f_h∩ f_i}⊆ Q .
  
Here the orderings of the vertices for every edge of F can be chosen independently and 
might not be compatible with each other.

sentence:
Fix any total order s_1 < s_2 < … < s_m on S and any total order on G ∖{e} (no compatibility with the group structure, nor with the action, is needed).
  Let λ be the edge labeling of _n(G,S) defined as follows (A, B and C are as in Definition <ref>).
  
    λ(x, y) =
        
          (0,  max(min A, min B))    if (x,y) is coherent
    
          (2,  min C,  α(x,y))    if (x,y) is non-coherent
    
          (1,   k)    if (x,y) is colored of color s_k
    
          (1,   2)    if y =.

  The values of λ are compared lexicographically.

  For a subset R⊆ S, let R_≤ s = { r ∈ R | r ≤ s}.

          (2,  min C,  α(x,y))    if (x,y) is non-coherent
    
          (1,   |S(x)_≤ s|)    if (x,y) is colored of a color s ∈ S(x)
    
          (1,   |S_≤ s∪ S(x)|)    if (x,y) is colored of a color s ∉S(x)
    
          (1,   2)    if y =.

Let α=(α_1,…,α_k) be a vector of positive reals satisfying ∑_i α_i=1. Given a partition of V(G) into k sets of sizes |V_i|=α_i n we denote by C(V_1,…,V_k) the number of copies of K_k in G with precisely one vertex
in each of the sets V_i. We say that a graph satisfies C_α if for any partition of the vertices of V(G) into k sets of sizes |V_i|=α_i n we have

    C(V_1,…,V_k)=p^k  2/k!n^k∏^k_i=1α_i ± o(n^k) .

sentence: We say that a Laurent polynomial is positive if all of its coefficients are in _>0. An element h∈[] is called universally positive  (for the 𝒜-cluster structure) if for every 𝒜-cluster seed  Σ̌_G^𝒜 the expansion 𝐡^G of h in  is a positive Laurent polynomial. Similarly f∈[×^*] is called universally positive if its expansion 𝐟^G in the variables ∪{q} is given by a positive Laurent polynomial for every seed Σ̌_G^𝒜.

sentence:
[Quiver]
A quiver Q is a directed graph; we will assume that Q has no 
loops or 2-cycles.
If there are i arrows from vertex λ to μ, then 
we will set b_λμ = i and b_μλ = -i.
Each vertex is designated either  mutable or frozen .
The skew-symmetric matrix B = (b_λμ) is called the exchange matrix of Q.
word_labels: O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O

sentence:
Let μ_i^□ be the Young diagram associated to 
the k-element subset of horizontal steps
J_i^+:=[i+1,i+k-1]∪{i+k+1}, where the index i is always interpreted modulo n.  
Then for i  n-k,  
the Young diagram μ_i^□ 
turns out to be the unique diagram in  obtained by adding a single  box to μ_i.
And for i=n-k, the Young diagram  μ_n-k^□ associated to 
J_n-k^+ is the rectangular (n-k-1) (k-1) Young diagram obtained from μ_n-k by removing a rim hook.


We define the superpotential dual to the Grassmannian  to be the regular function W:^* → given by

    W= ∑_i=1^nq^δ_i,n-kp_μ_i^□/p_μ_i,

where q is the coordinate on the ^* factor and δ_i,j is the  Kronecker delta function. 
	
For i=1,…, n we also define W_i∈[] by

    W_i:= p_μ_i^□/p_μ_i=p_J_i^+/p_J_i,

so that

	W= q W_n-k + ∑_i≠ n-k W_i.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A non-empty binary matrix M=(m_i,j) of size n× k, is a Dyck matrix if it satisfies the
following conditions.


  (M1) There exists 0<h≤ k such that m_1,j=1 if and only if j≤ h.

  (M2) For each 1 ≤ i < n, there exist 1≤ a_i≤ b_i<c_i≤ k such that a_i is
    the smallest index satisfying m_i,a_i=1 and m_i+1,a_i=0, b_i is the greatest index
    such that m_i,b_i=1, and
    c_i is the greatest index such that m_i+1,c_i=1. Moreover, the following hold: 

    (M2.1) m_i+1,j=m_i,j,  for j=1,…,a_i -1;

    (M2.2) m_i+1,j=0,  for j=a_i,…,b_i;

    (M2.3) m_i+1,j=1,  for j=b_i+1,…,c_i;

    (M2.4) m_i+1,j=0,  for j=c_i+1,…,k.

sentence:
A 3-link in H is a set of 3 hyperedges h_1, h_2, h_3 ∈ E(H) such that h_1 ∩ h_2  ≠∅, h_2 ∩ h_3 ≠∅ and h_1 ∩ h_3 = ∅. The hyperedges h_1 and h_3 are called terminal hyperedges of this 3-link. (Notice that a given 3-link defines four different Berge paths because each end vertex can be chosen in two ways. Also note that a 3-link is simply the set of hyperedges of a linear path of length three.)  

Given a hypergraph H and abc ∈ E(H), let p_abc(H) denote the number of 3-links in H in which abc is a terminal hyperedge and let p(H) denote the total number of 3-links in H. Notice 
    p(H) = 1/2∑_abc ∈ E(H) p_abc(H).

sentence: A path in a graph G is a sequence u_1,…,u_n of vertices of G so that {u_i,u_i+1}∈ E, i = 1,…, n-1. G is called connected if for any two vertices v and w of G there is a path u_1,…,u_n in G with v=u_1 and w=u_n. G is called disconnected if it is not connected. See Figures <ref> and <ref>.

sentence:
There is a natural cyclic order on [n]. In this section it is convenient to “break” this order into a linear order, as follows:

    1<2<…<n.

We refer to this total ordering as the broken order . (See Section <ref> for more on this symmetry-breaking.)

sentence:
Suppose that T is a tabloid and T is a corresponding tableau such that, for some column indices c_1, c_2 and some nonnegative integers i, k, l, column c_1 of T is filled (in order from top to bottom) with the elements i+1, i+2, …, i+k+l and column c_2 is filled with the elements i+k+l+1, i+k+l+2, …, i+k+2l.  Then the forward column rebase of type (i, k, l) of T is the sequence of tableaux (T = T_0, T_1, …, T_(k + l) · l), where T_j is formed from T_j - 1 by switching the elements in positions ((k + l)m - j + 1, c_1) and (m, c_2), where m = ⌈ j/(k + l)⌉ is the unique integer such that

    (k + l) · (m - 1) + 1 ≤ j ≤ (k + l) · m.
 
We say that the reversed sequence is the backward column rebase of T' := T_(k + l) · l.  The forward column rebase of T is the sequence of tabloids that we get by forgetting the row orders in every tableau in the forward column rebase of T, and similarly for the backward column rebase of the tabloid T' associated to T'.

sentence: A geodesic metric space (X,d) satisfies Bottleneck Property (BP) if there exists some constant Δ>0 so that given any two distinct points x, y∈ X and a midpoint z such that d(x,z)=d(z,y)=1/2 d(x,y), then every xy-path intersects N_(z).

sentence:
Given r∈ℕ, two vertices a and b are r-separated by a subset S⊂ V(G) if considering the connected components of G∖ S, G_a and G_b containing a and b respectively, for every pair of vertices v∈ G_a and w∈ G_b, 
d(v,w)>r. If a and b are two vertices r-separated by S then S is said to be an  ab-r-separator .

sentence:
Let τ I → J be a matching and C one of its open clusters.  
  Consider the list consisting of all numbers in I∪ J, sorted in ascending order.
  (If i_m = j_m' for some m and m',
  then include that number twice in the list.)
  Let the endpoint separation C of the cluster C
  be the number of entries in this sorted list lying strictly between
  the numbers labelling the two endpoints of C.
  For closed clusters C, we set C=0.

sentence: We say f:_d →^+ ∪{∞} admits a Helly theorem if given 1>ε>0 there is an integer H(f,d,ε) such that for any finite family  and λ >0, if every subfamily ' of cardinality at most H(f,d,ε) satifies f(∩') ≥λ, then f(∩) ≥ (1-ε)λ.

sentence:
Given a monotone function f:_d →^+ ∪{∞}, we say that there is a floating body for f if for every 1 > ε > 0, there is a δ = δ(ε) > 0 such that any convex set K with f(K) < ∞, there is a convex set K(f,ε) such that 
	
		
  * f(K(f,ε)) ≥ (1- δ)f(K) and
		
  * for any convex set A, if f(A ∩ K) ≥ (1-ε)f(K), then K(f,ε) ⊂ A.
	
	Morevoer, we require that δ (ε) → 0 if ε→ 0.  Throughout the rest of this section we will assume that f and d are fixed.  Even though δ (ε) depends on them, it will be useful to denote it this way.

sentence:
A∈𝒮𝒫_N^2 is nested if no pair of partitions {λ,μ} in A satisfies any one of the following conditions:


  *  λ=(λ_1≥λ_2>0), μ=(μ_1≥μ_2>0), with 
    λ_1>μ_1≥λ_2>μ_2 ;


  *  λ=(λ_1>λ_2>0), μ=(μ_1>0), with 
    λ_1≥μ_1≥λ_2 ;


  *  λ=(λ_1>0), μ=(μ_1>0).

A pair satisfying one of the above conditions is called a bad pair .

sentence:
Suppose we have two linear data Ψ = (V, (W_i)_i ∈ I, (ψ_i)_i ∈ I) and Ψ' = (V', (W'_i)_i∈ I', (ψ'_i)_i ∈ I').  Suppose further that for some pair j ∈ I, j' ∈ I' the subspaces W'_j' = W_j are identified.  Finally, let c > 0 be a positive real number.

  We say Ψ' dominates Ψ respecting (j,j') with exponent c if the following holds: for n ≥ 1 and any collection of functions (f_i)_i ∈ I, f_i  W_i^n → with f_i_∞≤ 1, there exist functions (g_i)_i ∈ I', g_i W'_i^n →, g_i_∞≤ 1, such that g_j' = f_j, and
  
    | Λ_Ψ((f_i)_i ∈ I) | ≤| Λ_Ψ'((g_i)_i ∈ I') |^c .

  * If I∈ℐ and J⊆ I, then J∈ℐ.

  * If I,I'∈ℐ and |I|<|I'|, then there exists e∈ I'-I such that I∪ e∈ℐ.

sentence:
[Combinatorial Cartan-Hadamard]
Let G=(V,E,F) be a tessellation. For a fixed vertex v_0∈ V, define the cut locus of f_0 to be 

    C(v_0) := { v'∈ F: d(v_0,v') ≤ d(v_0,v) v  v' }


If κ(v,f)≤ 0 for every corner (v,f), then G has no cut locus, i.e. C(v_0)=∅ for all v_0∈ V.

sentence:
[Tessellation]
A connected and locally finite planar graph G is a planar tessellation , or just tessellation , if it satisfies the following conditions.



  (i) Every edge is contained in exactly two different faces.

  (ii) Every bounded face is a polygon: it is homeomorphic to the closed disk 𝔻, and its boundary is a simple cycle (i.e. a finite path in which the first and the last vertices coincide). The edges of the cycle are called sides of the polygon.

  (iii) The intersection of any two distinct faces are either an empty set, or a vertex, or an edge.

sentence:
[Transport plan]
Let G=(V,E) be a locally-finite and connected graph. Let 
    P(V):={μ:V→ [0,1]  |  ∑_x∈ Vμ(x)=1, μ(x)>0  x}
 be the space of all probability measures on V with finite supports. 

Given any μ,ν∈ P(V), a transport plan (or, in short, a plan ) from μ to ν is a function π: V× V → [0,1] satisfying 

    μ(x) = ∑_y∈ Vπ(x,y)         ν(y)=∑_x∈ Vπ(x,y).


Furthermore, define ∏(μ,ν) to be the set of all transport plans from μ to ν, and the (transportation) cost of a plan π is given by 
    (π)=∑_x,y∈ V d(x,y)π(x,y).

sentence:
A path of size n is a sequence of North (N = (0,1)) and East (E=(1,0)) steps, containing n-1 steps in total. 
Given three paths u, m, and d of the same size n, 
all containing the same number of E (and N) steps, 
(u,m,d) is a triple of non-intersecting lattice paths (for short, triple of NILPs) of size n 
when the embeddings of u, m and d in the plane never meet, 
with u (resp. m, resp. d) starting at the point of coordinates (0,2) (resp. (1,1), resp. (2,0)).

sentence: Given a graph G representing a position in a game of narrow Dots-and-Boxes/Triangles, let V_BG be the set of all vertices that are incident to an exterior leg, incident to an interior leg, or part of a path joining two vertices that are both incident to legs. Then the graph induced by V_BG and the ground vertex is called the base graph . Any vertices and edges that are not part of the base graph are said to be pendant vertices and pendant edges , respectively.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O

sentence:
A chain of length k≥0 is a collection of k+1 edges in the base graph satisfying one of the following.
 

  
  * Every interior leg is a chain of length zero.

  
  * An exterior leg together with the edges of the path connecting it to the nearest interior leg in the same component comprise a chain, which excludes the interior leg.

  
  * Edges of the path connecting two consecutive interior legs in the same component comprise a chain, again excluding the interior legs.

  
  * If a component has two exterior legs and no interior legs, then all edges of the base graph in that component comprise a chain of length at least two.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For a function field ℂ(C),
	a function ν : ℂ(C) →ℤ∪{∞} is a valuation if 
	
		
  * ν (x) = ∞ if and only if x = 0.
		
		
  * ν (xy) = ν (x) + ν (y).
		
		
  * ν (x + y) ≥min{ν (x) , ν (y) }, with equality if ν (x) ≠ν (y).
		
		
  * ν (x) = 0 if x ∈ℂ∖{0}.

	If there exists linearly independent α,β∈ℤ^2 such that L_t.α^2 and L_t.β^2 are constant
	but (L_t.α).(L_t.β) is not constant,
	then (p_t,L_t) is a scissor flex.

sentence:
In the case where open knot type is one of the overcrossing closure , undercrossing closure , or the over-undercrossing closure , open knot type is invariant under the usual Reidemeister moves ( i.e. those which do not interact with the loose ends).

  In the case where open knot type is the min-closure knot type, the min-closure knot type is not invariant under Reidemeister moves. However, we have that any two knotoid diagrams S, S' related by a sequence of Reidemeister moves are not orthogonal in the vector space of knot types; ⟨ [S], [S'] ⟩ > 0.

  By definition, any two knotoid diagrams with the same knotoid type are furthermore related by a sequence of Reidemeister moves.

sentence:
Let G be a graph with vertices u and v.


  * We say that G admits perfect state transfer (PST) from u to v if there is some time t>0 such that

    |U(t)_u,v| = 1.


  * We say  G admits pretty good state transfer (PGST) from u to v if, for any ϵ>0, there is a time t>0 such that

    |U(t)_u,v| > 1-ϵ.

sentence: For positive integers k,n, an unoriented de Bruijn graph uBg(k,n) contains (k^n+k^⌈ n/2 ⌉)/2 vertices labeled by the equivalence classes [v] of k-ary words of length n-1.  Edges of uBg(k,n) are labeled by distinct equivalence classes of words of length n.  An undirected edge labeled [e] connects the vertices labeled by the equivalence classes of the prefix and suffix of e, respectively.  Thus, there is an (undirected) edge [v] ↔ [w] if v→w or v→w' is a (directed) edge in the de Bruijn graph Bg(k,n).
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For any set Ω of non-negative integers which contains 0,1 and at least one integer greater than 1, a (k,Ω)-front coding tree of size n is a tree T consisting of (kn+1) white nodes and n black nodes which satisfies:


  * T is rooted at a white node, every white node has only black nodes as children and every black node has only k white nodes as children.

  * The number of black children of the white root belongs to the set Ω and the number of black children of any other white node belongs to the set {i | i+1∈Ω,i≥ 0}.

  * The white root of T is labeled by a k-subset A of [n+k]={1,2,…,n+k} and the black nodes are labeled by the integers from the set [n+k]-A such that for every white node, the subtrees stemming from its black children are not ordered between themselves.

The labels on the white root and black nodes determine the labels on the rest white nodes. We start from the white root and recursively label other white nodes. For every white node, we label it with a set {r_1,…,r_i-1,r,r_i+1,…,r_k} if the white node is the i-th child (from left to right) of a black node labeled by r and the white parent of this black node is labeled with the set {r_1,…,r_k}.

If the white root of a (k,Ω)-front coding tree has precisely one black child, we call it reduced (k,Ω)-front coding tree.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
A Young diagram is a finite subset of (_≥ 0)^2 which 
satisfies the following closure properties:


  * If (x,y) ∈λ and x>0, then (x-1, y) ∈λ.

  * If (x,y) ∈λ and y>0, then (x, y-1) ∈λ.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A partial matching in a poset P is a partial matching in the underlying graph of the Hasse diagram
  of P, i.e., it is a subset M⊆ P × P such that
  
  
  * (a,b)∈ M implies b ≻ a; i.e. a<b and no c satisifies a<c<b.
  
  * each a∈ P belongs to at most one element in M.
  
  When (a,b) ∈ M, we write a=d(b) and b=u(a).

  * A partial matching on P is called acyclic if there does not exist a cycle
  
    a_1 ≺ u(a_1) ≻ a_2 ≺ u(a_2) ≻⋯≺ u(a_m) ≻ a_1

  with m≥ 2 and all a_i∈ P being distinct.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let A and B be finite sets.  
  Let M  be a collection of maps from A to B called homomorphisms.  
  Let P(A,B) be the polyhedral cell complex ∏_i∈ AΔ_B, where Δ_B is the simplex with vertices labeled by elements of B.  
  We record a face of P(A,B) by an |A|-tuple of the form X=(X_i)_i∈ A, with each ∅≠ X_i⊆ B.
  The homomorphism complex _M(A,B) is the subcomplex of P(A,B) consisting of all cells labeled by (W_i)_i∈ A∈ P(A,B) satisfying the following property: if η:A→ B is such that η(i)∈ W_i for all i∈ A, then η∈ M.  
  We call such a (W_i)_i∈ A∈ P(A,B) a multi-homomorphism , and we call A the test object and B the target object for the complex.
  The faces of _M(A,B) are partially ordered by X≤ Y if and only if X_i⊆ Y_i for all i∈ A.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
We will say that a curve c on a surface S is a handle curve if at least one of the connected components of the surface S∖ c is a torus with one hole (a “handle”). 
All other curves will be called non-handle curves.

sentence:
Let M be a positroid on [n] and let S_1, S_2, …, S_t be the ground sets of the connected components of M. Then Π_M={S_1, …, S_t} is a non-crossing partition of [n], called the non-crossing partition of M .

Conversely, if S_1, S_2, …, S_t form a non-crossing partition of [n] and M_1, M_2, …, M_t are connected positroids on S_1, S_2, …, S_t, respectively, then 
M_1 ⊕…⊕ M_t is a positroid.

sentence:
Let G be a finite group, 𝒦 be a partition of G into unions of conjugacy classes, and 𝒳 be a set of characters of G. We say that the pair (𝒦,𝒳) is a supercharacter theory of G if


  (SCT1) |𝒳|=|𝒦|,

  (SCT2) the characters χ∈𝒳 are constant on the members of 𝒦, and

  (SCT3) each irreducible character of G is a constituent of exactly one character in 𝒳.

The characters χ∈𝒳 are called supercharacters and the blocks K ∈𝒦 are called superclasses .

sentence:
[-compatible]

  Let H=(W,E_H) and R=([k],E_R) be graphs and let R'=([k],E_R') be a
  subgraph of R. We say that a vertex partition W=(W_i)_i∈[k] of H is
  -compatible 
  with an integer partition (n_i)_i∈[k] of n
  and with R'⊂ R if the following holds. For
  i∈[k] let S_i be the set of vertices in W_i with neighbours in some
  W_j with ij∉E_R' and i≠ j, set S:=⋃ S_i and
  T_i:=N_H(S)∩ (W_i∖ S). Then for all i,j∈[k] we have that
  
    
  * 
      |W_i|≤ n_i,
    
  * 
      xy∈ E_H for x∈ W_i and y∈ W_j implies ij∈ E_R,
    
  * 
      |S_i|≤ n_i and
      |T_i|≤·min{n_j:i and j are in the same
      component of R'}.
  
  The partition W=(W_i)_i∈[k] of H is -compatible
  with a partition V=(V_i)_i∈[k] of a graph G and with R'⊂ R if 
  W=(W_i)_i∈[k] is -compatible with (|V_i|)_i∈[k] and with
  R'⊂ R.

sentence: A Young diagram is a finite, connected collection of boxes such that there exists a bottom-left most box that we label as (1, 1). Moreover, if the box (k, ℓ) (which is in the k^th column from left and ℓ^th row from bottom) in the Young diagram, then every box (k', ℓ') with 1 ≤ k' ≤ k, 1 ≤ℓ' ≤ℓ is also in the diagram.

sentence:
Define the staircase grid B_a as a staircase-like grid with a rows and a columns such that the top row and right column have a boxes, the second-to-top row and second-to-right column have a-1 boxes, and so on. By a box , we mean a unit square. See Figure <ref> for an example.

More specifically, define the staircase encoding of π as the grid B_a combined with a number in each box. For the box in the i^th row from the top and the j^th column from the bottom, fill in the number of elements in π which are strictly between π_k_i and π_k_i-1 as a value and between position k_j and k_j+1 in the order of the permutation (assume π_k_0 = k_a+1 = n+1). For an example, see Figure <ref>.

sentence: Given a 123-avoiding permutation π of length n, define the boundary grid of π as a subset of an (n-1) × (n-1) grid of boxes such that if we label the vertices of the boxes from (1, 1) to (n, n) in a standard Cartesian coordinate way, a box is in the boundary grid if and only if it is above and to the right of at least one left-to-right minimum and below and to the left of at least one right-to-left maximum. See Figure <ref> for an example.

sentence:
Let 𝖡_1 be the block of π containing 1, and for 1< j ≤ |π|, let 𝖡_j be the block of π containing the smallest number not in 𝖡_1 ∪𝖡_2 ∪⋯∪𝖡_j-1.   
The standard labeling of π  is  (_π | _π'),  where 
_π = (b_1,…, b_k) and _π' = (b_k+1, …,b_2k) in [1,n]^k,  and 

    b_ℓ = j    if  ℓ∈𝖡_j   for  ℓ∈ [1,2k].

[Convex Hull]
The set S is defined as S=P ∩ Z^n where P⊆ ^n. The convex hull of S is denoted as conv(S) and  conv(S)={y ∈^n:y=∑_i=1^kλ_ix^i}, where x^i∈ S and λ_i∈_+ ∀ i, with ∑_i=1^kλ_i=1.

sentence:
A non-ambiguous binary tree () is a filling of a rectangular Ferrers diagram F where every cell is either empty or dotted such that:


  *  Every row and every column has a dotted cell.

  *  Except for the top left cell, every dotted cell has either a dotted 
cell above it in its column or to its left in its row, but not both.

 The dot in the top left cell (implied by (<ref>) and (<ref>)) is called the root dot, or simply the root .

sentence:
Let d_2, δ_2>0. A bipartite graph G with the bipartition V(G)=X Y is called (δ_2, d_2)-regular if for all subsets X'⊆ X and Y'⊆ Y we have

    |e(G[X',Y'])-d_2|X'||Y'||≤δ_2 |X||Y| .

sentence:
A consistently edge-labelled graph G is an edge-labelled graph that


has a transitive orientation D_c of its inclusion edges such that for each
(u,v)∈ D_c, N[v]⊆ N[u].

sentence:
Let Δ be a simplicial complex, and let u, v be vertices of Δ.  An independent set A of Δ
    is nested if the vertices of A can be linearly ordered so that v ≤ u implies
    _Δ(u) ⊂_Δ(v); such an order is a nesting order of A.  A proper vertex
    k-colouring = C_1  C_k of Δ is nested if every colour class of  is nested.
    The nested chromatic number χ_N(Δ) is the least integer k such that a nested k-colouring of
    Δ exists.

sentence:
Let G be a graph. The quantity 

    χ^∗(G):=inf{k/d|∃ (k,d) -colouring of G}∈ℝ_+

is called the star chromatic number resp. circular chromatic number of G.

sentence:
Let X be a finite subset of {1,2,…}.
  A partition matrix on X is an upper
  triangular matrix over the powerset of X satisfying the
  following properties:
  
  
  (i) each column and row contain at least one non-empty set;
  
  (ii) the non-empty sets partition X;
  
  (iii) (i)<(j)  i<j,  
  
  where (i) denotes the column in which i is a member. Let
  _n be the collection of all partition matrices on [1,n]={1,…,n}.

sentence:
[]
Let (Q,≼) be a quasi-order:


  * Q is wqo(set) if for every f:ℕ→ Q
    there is an infinite set A such that for all n,m ∈ A, n <_ m
    → f(n) ≼ f(m);

  * Q is wqo(anti) if it has no infinite descending sequences
    and no infinite antichains;

  * Q is wqo(ext) if every linear extension of ≼ is a
    well-order.

sentence: A rotor configuration on D is a function ϱ that assigns to each non-sink vertex v an out-edge with tail v. We call ϱ(v) the rotor at v.

Let A be an abelian group with a shift invariant probability measure μ. Let F={f_S | S⊆ [k]} be a collection of 2^k functions in L_∞(A,μ). We define the k-th order convolution _k(F) as the k variable function

    _k(F)(t_1,t_2,…,t_k)=∫_x ∏_S⊆ [k]f_S(x+∑_i∈ St_i).

is labeled by a pair (a, α)∈{0, 1}×{+, -}.

A tree of two-boundaried cycles is a tree of cycles G for which the following holds. 


  * Each chordless cycle of G has at most two edge separators.

sentence:
The class of mamba trees is the class of graphs recursively defined as follows.

	
  * Each mamba is a mamba tree.
	
  * For each mamba tree G and each mamba M, the graph obtained from a disjoint union of G and M by identifying a vertex of G with a head vertex of M is a mamba tree.

sentence:
For a univariate polynomial f∈ K[x_k], say f=∑_i=0^d c_i x_k^i with c_i∈ K, c_0c_d ≠ 0, the Newton polygon (or extended Newton polyhedron ) is defined to be
  
    Δ(f):= ({(i,ν(c_i))| i=0,…,d}∪{(0,∞)}).

  Similarly, for a multivariate polynomial f∈ K[x_1,…,x_k], say f=∑_i=0^d f_i· x_k^i with f_i∈ K[x_1,…,x_k-1] and a weight w∈^k-1, we define the expected Newton polygon of f at w to be
  
    Δ_w(f):=({(i,(f_i)(w))| i=0,…,d}∪{(0,∞)}).

  And we say f has a unique Newton polygon at w, if for all vertices (i,(f_i)(w)) ∈Δ_w(f) the initial form _w(f_i) is a monomial. We write Λ(f) or Λ_w(f) for the set of all negative slopes of Δ(f) or Δ_w(f) respectively.

    d_R: nBpw→n-|R|Bd_R(p)d_R(w)

sentence:
Let A and B be two linearly ordered sets of equal size.
We say that a quasi configuration is obtained from 
  A and B in a crossing way if the first element 
  of A is paired with the last element of B, and so on, 
  until finally the last element of A is paired to the first 
  element of B.

sentence:
Let M={D_1,D_2,… , D_m } be a disk system. We say M is a Vietoris-Rips system if D_i∩ D_j ≠∅ for each pair i,j∈{1,2,…, m}. 
Moreover, if the disk system M has the nonempty intersection property ⋂_D_i ∈ M D_i ≠∅, then M is called a Čech system.

sentence:
The boundary complex of a simplex and {∅} are edge decomposable ,
and, recursively, a pure simplicial complex Δ is said to be edge decomposable
if there exists an edge {i,j}∈Δ such that Δ satisfies the Link condition w.r.t.{i,j} and both _Δ({i,j}) and 𝒞_Δ(i,j) are edge decomposable.

sentence:
[Crystal operators on fillings]
Let F ∈(λ/μ) and define the crystal biword W̃,
with entry ([ j; c ]) appearing in W̃
if and only if there is a box with value j in column c.
The entries in W̃ are then sorted decreasingly, primarily on the bottom row entry ,
see <ref>. 
Note that this is map to W̃ is invertible if λ/μ is fixed.
We then define _i(F), and _i(F) as the result when applying 
e_i and f_i, respectively, on the first row of W̃.

For the subset of coinversion-free fillings F with (F)=0, 
these operators are essentially a generalization of the raising– and lowering 
operators defined on semistandard Young tableaux.

by ∂ A.

for all v ∈_P^l and x ∈ X.

sentence: [Factor]  Let (X,,μ) be a probability space.  A factor of (X,,μ) is a triplet = (Y,,π), where Y is a set,  is a σ-algebra, and π: X → Y is a measurable map.  If  is a factor, we let _ := {π^-1(E): E ∈} be the sub-σ-algebra of  formed by pulling back  by π.  A function f: X → is said to be -measurable if it is measurable with respect to _.  If f ∈ L^2(X,,μ), we let (f|Y) = (f|_Y) be the orthogonal projection of f to the closed subspace L^2(X,_Y,μ) of L^2(X,,μ) consisting of -measurable functions.  If = (Y,,π) and ' = (Y',',π') are two factors, we let ∨' denote the factor (Y × Y', ⊗', π⊕π').

[Linear forms condition] 
  A weighted hypergraph
ν = ν^(N) on the hypergraph system V = V^(N) = (J,
(V_j^(N))_j ∈ J, r, H) is said to obey the H-linear forms
  condition (or simply the linear forms condition if there is no confusion) if one has

    [∏_e ∈ H∏_ω∈{0,1}^eν_e(x_e^(ω))^n_e,ω|
        x_J^(0), x_J^(1)∈
        V_J
        ]
        = 1 + o(1)

for any choices of exponents n_e,ω∈{0,1}.

Let A ⊆^finℕ. For NIM(A):

    
  * We say that Player 1 wins normally if W(n;d,e)=1, and the player has enough money to employ the strategy used in regular NIM. Note that this is equivalent to W(n;d,∞)=1. Similar for Player 2.
    
  * If a player wins by removing min(A) on every move, we say that the player wins miserly.

sentence:
[<cit.>]
Let >0 be fixed. Then:



  *  For all integers k> ℓ≥ 2, if p≤  (1-)e^k-ℓ/n^k-ℓ, then  H_n,p^(k) is not ℓ-Hamiltonian.

  *  For all integers k>ℓ≥ 3, there exists a
constant K=K(k) such that if p≥ K/n^k-ℓ
and n is a multiple of k-ℓ then
 H_n,p^(k) is ℓ-Hamiltonian . 

  * If k>ℓ=2 and p≥ω/n^k-2
and n is a multiple of k-2,
then H_n,p^(k) is 2-Hamiltonian .

  *  For all k≥ 4, if p≥  (1+)e/n, then
 H_n,p^(k) is (k-1)-Hamiltonian, i.e. it contains a tight Hamilton cycle.

sentence:
[Good function, (C,α)-dense]
  A function S ∈_ℓ^r,t(Y) is (r,ℓ,t,C,α)-good
  for a tuple eq and (X,Y) if there exist
  sets 
    E_q+1,…,E_ℓ⊂ E(X),     d(E_j) ≥ 2^-ℓα C
 such that for every e_q+1∈ E_q+1, …, e_ℓ∈ E_ℓ, we have eℓ→ S.

  When the constants (r,ℓ,t,C,α) and the sets (X,Y) are clear
  from the context, we shall omit them. We shall abbreviate
  `(r,ℓ,t,C,α)-good for e0 and (X,Y)' to
  `(r,ℓ,t,C,α)-good for (X,Y)'.

  The pair (X,Y) is (C,α)-dense in copies of Z_ℓ^r,t
  if there exist at least 2^-ℓα |Y|^s families S ∈(Y)
  which are (r,ℓ,t,C,α)-good for (X,Y).

sentence:
[Booster trees]
  Let C,p_0 ∈ and β, > 0. A
  (p_0,C,,β)-booster tree for (X,Y) is an oriented rooted tree , 
  whose vertices are pairs (X',Y') such that X' ⊂ X
  and Y' ⊂ Y, and all of whose edges are oriented away from the
  root, such that the following conditions hold:
  
    
  *  The root of 𝒯 is (X,Y).
    
  *  No vertex of 𝒯 has more than p_0
    out-neighbours.
    
  *  The out-neighbourhood of each non-leaf (X',Y')
    of 𝒯 forms a (p,C,,β)-booster of (X',Y') for some
    p≤ p_0.
    
  *  If (X',Y') is a leaf of , then either
    G[X'] is C-degenerate, or there does not exist a
    (p,C,,β)-booster for (X',Y') for any p ≤ p_0.
  
  A vertex (X',Y') of 𝒯 is called degenerate if it is a
  leaf of 𝒯 and G[X'] is C-degenerate.

sentence:
The Kadanoff sand pile model with parameter p>0, KSPM(p), is defined by two sets:
  
    
  * configurations . Ultimately null non-negative integer sequences.
    
  * transition rules . We have a transition from a configuration b to a configuration b' on column i, and we note   b i→ b' when
    
    
      
  * b'_i-1=b_i-1 + p (for i ≠ 0)
      
  * b'_i = b_i - (p-1)
      
  * b'_i+p = b_i+p + 1
      
  * b'_j = b_j for j ∉{i-1, i, i+p }.

sentence:
Consider a cell complex K (not necessarily
of dimension d-1 or d) in M^d.
A k-stress (2≤ k≤ d+1) on K is
a real-valued function ω on the (k-1)-cells of K,
such that for each (k-2)-cell F of K,

    ∑_G∈ K^k-1,F⊂ Gω(G)u_ F,G=0,

where the sum is taken over all (k-1)-cells G of K
that contain F,
and u_ F,G is the inward unit normal to G at its facet F.
For k=1, a 1-stress is an affine dependence among the vertices
for the Euclidean case, or a linear dependence for the non-Euclidean case.

sentence:
An oriented matroid M=(E,) is a nonempty finite set E together with a collection  of signed subsets that satisfy the following axioms:


  * ≠∅.

  * If C∈, then -C∈.

  * For all C_1,C_2∈, if C_1⊆C_2, then either C_1=C_2 or -C_1=C_2.

  * For all C_1,C_2∈, e∈ C_1^+∩ C_2^-, and f∈ (C_1^+∖ C_2^-)∪ (C_1^-∖ C_2^+), there is a C_3∈ such that C_3^+⊂ (C_1^+∪ C_2^+)∖{e}, C_3^-⊂(C_1^-∪ C_2^-)∖{e}, and f∈C_3. [This condition is generally known as the strong circuit elimination axiom.]
