sentence:
An (associative[There are also non-associative algebras, in which only the second and third conditions hold. Often, some alternative property is imposed: Lie algebras, in which the Jacobi identity is enforced, have a structure theory analogous to what we discuss in this section.]) algebra over the field k is a vector space 𝒜 over k together with a binary operation (multiplication) which satisfies the following conditions:

    
  * Associativity: A(BC) = (AB)C for all A, B, C ∈𝒜.
    
  * Distributivity: A(B+C) = AB + AC and (A+B)C = AC + BC for all A, B, C ∈𝒜.
    
  * Scalar compatibility: (cA)(dB) = cdAB for all c, d ∈ k and all A, B ∈𝒜.

sentence:
Let F be a forest. For w ∈𝒲(F), we define the bottom-to-top maximum positions to be

    (F,w) =  { v : w(v)>w(u)  for all  u  <_F v}.
  For w ∈𝒲_B(F), we define the signed bottom-to-top maximum positions to be

    (F,w) =  { v : w(v)>0  and  w(v)>|w(u)|  for all  u  <_F v}.
  Finally, for w ∈𝒲_D(F), we define the even signed bottom-to-top maximum positions to be

    (F,w) =  { v : v  is not a leaf, w(v)>0  and  w(v)>|w(u)|  for all  u  <_F v}.

   Let Λ be a two dimensional lattice. A convex lattice polygon Γ is the convex hull of a finite non-empty set of lattice points in Λ. Polygons are considered equivalent when they are lattice equivalent.

(attributes of polygons) 
  Let Γ be a lattice polygon with lattice Λ. We call Γ a shoe polygon  if and only if  Γ=_l,m,n where  
    _l,m,n:=ConvexHull( (0,0),(0,l),(m,l),(m+n,0) )
 where l,m,n∈Z_≥ 0 (see Figure <ref>.a)).  

  
    < g r a p h i c s >
     
    < g r a p h i c s >
       
    < g r a p h i c s >
 

 a: _l,m,n           b: _2,0,2                 c: _1,0,>1 

 convex lattice polytopes corresponding to _l,m,n. 
 
 We call Γ a standard triangle  if and only if  Γ=_l,0,l with l>0 ( for example  Figure <ref>.b). We call Γ a thin triangle  if and only if  Γ=_1,0,l with l>1. ( for example  Figure <ref>.c). We call Γ minimal  if and only if

sentence:
(minimal toric degree and optimal toric family)  Let X be a complex embedded toric surface. 
 The minimal toric degree v(X) of X  is the smallest possible degree of a toric family on X (see Definition <ref>). The set of optimal toric families on X is defined as  
    S(X)= {  F∈Fam X   |   F  is a toric family  and  F = v(X)  }.

sentence:
(adjoint relation) 
  Let (X,D) be a mprs which is not minimal. An adjoint relation is a relation  (X,D) μ→ (X',D') where  
 (X,D) is a mprs which is not minimal, 
 (X',D') is a mprs, 
  is a birational morphism  which blows down all -1-curves C  such that  (D+K)C=0 and 
 D'=μ_*(D+K).

sentence:
(optimal and tight families and minimal degree) 
  Let (X,D) be a mprs.  Let K be the canonical divisor class on X.  Let F∈Fam(X). The degree of F  with respect to  (X,D) is given by DF. We call F a tight family  if and only if  FK=-2. The minimal rational degree  with respect to  (X,D) is defined as 
    v(X,D)=min{  DF   |   F∈Fam X  and  p_g(F)=0  }.
 The minimum exists since D is nef by definition.  We call F an optimal family  if and only if  F is a rational family and DF=v(X,D). The set of all optimal families on (X,D) is denoted by S(X,D).

	if G is f_X,k-choosable. For a real number
	0 ≤ϵ < 1,   G is called (k+ϵ)-choosable if every subgraph H of G has a k-sufficient subset X ⊆ V(H)   with |X| ≥ (1-ϵ)|V(H)|.

sentence:
(Coefficient Formula) Let f be a polynomial in 𝔽
[x_1,… ,x_n] and let f_α _1,… ,α _n denote
the coefficient of x_1^α _1⋯ x_n^α _n in f.
Suppose that (α _1,… ,α _n) is maximal in Supp
(f). Then for any sets A_1,… ,A_n in 𝔽 such that | A_i| =α _i+1 we have

    f_α _1,… ,α _n=∑_(a_1,… ,a_n)∈
    A_1×…× A_nf(a_1,… ,a_n)/N(a_1,…
    ,a_n).  *

sentence:
[Labelling of V(B)∩ V(Z)]
  A valid labelling L = L_B for B is a mapping L V(B)∩
  V(Z)→{{0},{1},{0,1}} obtained in the following way.

If V(B) ∖ V(Z) ≠∅ we pick a reference vertex v_B ∈ V(B) ∖
V(Z) for L. Then we fix a labelling parameter α_B ∈_2 for L.
Finally, for any u ∈ V(B)∩ V(Z) and for any proper walk ω with endpoints u
and v_B, the vertex u receives the
label α_B + λ(ω) ∈_2. Note that u may receive two labels after considering all such walks. On the other hand, each vertex of V(B) ∩ V(Z) obtains at least one label, which follows from the definition of bridges (Definition <ref>).

If V(B) ⊆ V(Z), then B comprises only of one edge e = uv
  connecting two vertices of V(Z). In such case, there are two valid
  labellings for B. We set L(u) = {α_B} and L(v) = {λ(e) +
  α_B} for a chosen labelling parameter α_B ∈_2.

sentence:
A collection ⊆ 2^[n] forms a d-dimensional Boolean algebra if there exist pairwise disjoint sets
X_0, X_1, …,X_d ⊆ [n], all non-empty with perhaps the exception of X_0, so that 

    ={X_0∪⋃_i∈ I X_i I⊆ [d]}.
  
We view all d-dimensional Boolean algebras as copies of a single structure _d.  Thus, a d-dimensional Boolean algebra forms a copy of _d , and a family ⊆ is _d-free if it does not contain a copy of _d.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let G be a graph and let X ⊂ V(G) satisfy |X| =k ≥ 2. We say G[X] is a chain of sausages of order k in G if G. (V(G)∖ X ) is a doubled cycle (of length k+1).  If G[X] is a chain of sausages of order at least 3 and x,x' ∈ X are adjacent, then the operation of identifying x and x' to a new vertex is called a sausage shortening .  If G' is obtained from G by repeatedly performing sausage shortenings until this operation is no longer possible, we call G' a sausage reduction of G.  We say that G is sausage reduced if it has no sausage of order at least 3 (so no sausage shortening is possible).

sentence: Let (P, ) be a poset (partially ordered set). A linear extension L of P is a total order which satisfies (x  y ∈ P)  (x  y ∈ L). A realiser of P is a set of linear extensions of P, say ℛ, which satisfy the following condition: for any two distinct elements x and y, x y ∈ P if and only if x  y ∈ L, ∀ L ∈ℛ.  The poset dimension of P, denoted by (P), is the minimum positive integer k such that there exists a realiser of P of cardinality k.

sentence:
Let ,d∈[0,1] and q,m≥1 be integers.


  * Let F be a graph on vertex set [q] and let U_1, …, U_q be disjoint sets of size m. We call a graph H on vertex set ⋃_i∈[q]U_i a (, m)-regular blow-up of F if whenever {i,j}∈ E(F), we have that (U_i, U_j) is a -regular pair.


  * If in addition to the above, d(U_i, U_j)≥ d for each edge {i,j} of Fm then we say that H has minimum density d. 


  * Suppose that F is a connected matching and H is a (, m)-regular blow-up of F with minimum density d. If for each matching edge {i,j} of F, the pair (U_i, U_j) is in fact (, d)-super-regular in H, then we say that H is a (, d, m)-super-regular blow-up of F.

sentence:
One execution of the outer repeat loop in is called an iteration .
For a sequence of non-empty sets = (I_1,…,I_t), we say that the algorithm follows
 if I_s is the set resampled in iteration s for 1 ≤ s < t, and I_t is a set of the
first m events resampled in iteration t for some m ≥ 1 (a prefix of the maximal independent set constructed in iteration t).

sentence:
A (k,ℓ)-Kneser coloring of a hypergraph H=(V,E) is a
function Δ E ⟶ [k] associating
a color with each hyperedge with the property that any two hyperedges
with the same color are ℓ-intersecting. A hypergraph admitting a (k,ℓ)-Kneser coloring is called (k,ℓ)-Kneser colorable ((k,ℓ)-colorable, for short), and the number of (k,ℓ)-Kneser colorings of a hypergraph H is denoted by κ(H,k,ℓ). Given positive integers n, r, k and ℓ, we define

    (n,r,k,ℓ)=max{κ(H,k,ℓ):H  is an
    r-uniform hypergraph on n vertices};

that is, (n,r,k,ℓ) is the maximum number of (k,ℓ)-Kneser colorings on an r-uniform hypergraph on n vertices.

[f-regularity]	
	For an ℓ-partite k-graph H with vertex classes (V_1,…,V_ℓ),
	we say that H is f-regular , where  f[0,1]→[0,1], if the following hold:
	
		
  * For every
		I ∈[ℓ]k, the induced subgraph H[⋃_i ∈ I V_i]
		
		is f(d(H))-regular,
		
  * If k ≥ 3, the (k-1)-graph (H) is f-regular.

sentence:
[⟨,,̱⟩̣-regularity]
	A bipartite graph of density d is ⟨,⟩̱-regular
	if it is (· d, )̱-regular.[That is, every S  Z, T  Z' with |S| ≥|̱Z|, |T| ≥|̱Z'| satisfy d(S,T)=(1 ±)d.]
	A vertex partition  is ⟨,,̱⟩̣-regular for a graph G if one can add/remove at most ·̣e(G) edges so that all pairs of  are ⟨,⟩̱-regular.

	
	Analogously, a 3-partite 3-graph of density d is ⟨,⟩̱-regular if it is (· d, )̱-regular.
	
	An (ℓ,t,_1,_2)-partition  is ⟨,,̱⟩̣-regular for a 3-graph H if one can add/remove at most ·̣e(H) hyperedges so that all triads of P are ⟨,⟩̱-regular.

sentence:
Let M be a combinatorial sphere and  f_1, f_2∈ M two of its facets that intersect in a ridge r = f_1∩ f_2. 
 Then the untriangulation of M with f_1 and f_2 is the set U(M), obtained from M by replacing f_1 and f_2 by their union:
 
    U(M){f_1∪ f_2}∪ M∖{f_1,f_2}.

sentence: A subgraph H of a bipartite graph G will be called an elementary subgraph if H contains every vertex of G, and every edge of H is used in some perfect matching of H. Equivalently, H is an elementary subgraph if it is the union of some set of perfect matchings of G.

sentence:
Let α,β be two H-colorings of G and let q be a vertex of G.
	Let Q∈π(H).
	We say Q is topologically valid for α,β,q
	if any of the following equivalent statements holds.
	
		
  * For every closed walk C from q to q we have
		β(C) = Q^-1·α(C)· Q.		
		
  * For every vertex w and any two walks W_1,W_2 from q to w in G we have

		α(W_1)^-1·  Q ·β(W_1) = α(W_2)^-1·  Q ·β(W_2).

order-isomorphic if they have the following property: For every two
integers i,j∈[  n], we have α(  i)
<α(  j) if and only if β(  i)
<β(  j).

sentence:
A labeled poset means a pair (  P,γ) consisting
of a finite poset P=(  X,≤) and an injective map
γ:X→ A for some totally ordered set A. The injective map
γ is called the labeling of the labeled poset (
P,γ). The poset P is called the ground poset of the
labeled poset (  P,γ).

[Threshold Partition]
  A partition λ is called a threshold partition if its Frobenius coordinates satisfy β_i=α_i+1 for i=1,…,d, where d is the Durfee rank of λ.

Let h_1 and h_2 be two hedra joined at a front f, hereafter said to be adjacent .
  Each other front of one of the hedra shares k-1 vertices with f; we say that two fronts f_1 of h_1 and f_2 of h_2 are mirror with respect to f if these shared vertices are the same, or equivalently if f_1∩ f = f_2∩ f.

A subset A ⊂ F is called K-mixing if 1_G∈ A and g h∈ F∖ K whenever g≠ h∈ A.

sentence:
Let A and B be finite sets.  
Let M:={ϕ:A→ B }  be a collection of set maps called homomorphisms.  
Let P(A,B) be the polyhedral cell complex ∏_i∈ AΔ_B, where Δ_B is the simplex with vertices labeled by elements of B.  
We record a face of P(A,B) by an |A|-tuple of the form X=(X_i)_i∈ A, with each ∅≠ X_i⊆ B.
The faces are partially ordered by X≤ Y if and only if X_i⊆ Y_i for all i∈ A.  
The homomorphism complex HOM_M(A,B) is the subcomplex of P(A,B) consisting of all cells labeled by (W_i)_i∈ A∈ P(A,B) such that if ψ:A→ B satisfies ψ(i)∈ W_i for all i∈ A then ψ∈ M.  
We call such a (W_i)_i∈ A∈ P(A,B) a multi-homomorphism , and we call A the test object and B the target object for the complex.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O

sentence:
Let H be a simplicial complex on vertex set [n]. 
We say that H is shifted if, for any face F ∈ H, any vertex i ∈ F, and any j < i such that j ∉ F, the set (F ∖{i})∪{j} is a face of H.

sentence:
A polyhedral cell complex X is a finite collection of convex polytopes in a real vector space V, called faces of X, satisfying the following two properties:


  * If τ is a polytope in X and η is a face of τ, then η is a polytope in X.

  * If τ and σ are both polytopes in X, then τ∩σ is a face of both τ and σ.

sentence:
Let H be a d-dimensional simplicial complex with totally ordered vertex set V(H). 
We inductively define H to be cointerval if either d =-1 or d ≥ 0 and


  * For each i ∈ V(H), _H(i) is cointerval.

  * For i, j ∈ V(H) and i < j, _H(j) is a subcomplex of _H(i).

sentence:
An n-ary operation Q:Σ^n→Σ,
where Σ is a nonempty set,
is called
an n-ary qua­si­group or n-qua­si­group
( of order |Σ| ) if 
in the equality z_0=Q(z_1, … , z_n) knowledge of any n elements
of z_0, z_1, …, z_n uniquely specifies the remaining one <cit.>.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
If we assign some fixed values to l∈{1,…,n} variables
in the predicate Q⟨ z_0, … , z_n⟩
then the (n-l+1)-ary predicate obtained corresponds to an (n-l)-qua­si­group.
Such a qua­si­group is called a retract or (n-l)-retract of Q.
If z_0 is not fixed, the retract is principal .

sentence:
The cost function c in (<ref>) is said to be
  concave if it is defined by
c(p, q) = g(|p - q|) with p, q ∈, where
g^+→∪{-∞} is a strictly concave non-decreasing 
  function such that g(0) := lim_x→ 0 g(x) ≥ -∞.

sentence:
[real-valued case]
  
  A chain is a sequence of elements of mass that has one of the
  forms
  
  
  * ((p_i_1, y), (q_j_1, y), …, (p_i_k, y), (q_j_k, y)) 
    with ℓ(p_i_1, y) = -∞, r(q_j_k, y) = ∞;
  
  * ((q_j_0, y), (p_i_1, y), …, (q_j_k - 1, y), (p_i_k, y))
    with ℓ(q_j_0, y) = -∞, r(p_i_k, y) = ∞;
  
  * ((p_i_1, y), (q_j_1, y), …, (q_j_k - 1, y),
    (p_i_k, y)) with ℓ(p_i_1, y) = -∞, r(p_i_k, y) =
    ∞.
  
  Here k≥ 1 and q_j_m - 1 = ℓ(p_i_m, y) > -∞,
  q_j_m = r(p_i_m, y) < ∞ for all m between 1 and k
  except the cases specified above.

sentence:
We define for each D∈(m,n) a monomial in the variables x_1,x_2,…: we set 
    x^D ∏_i=1^n x_l_i(D)
 where l_i(D) is the label of the i-th vertical step of D (the first being at the bottom). Notice that x_0 does not appear, which explains the word partially .

sentence: A square path ending east of size n is a lattice paths going from (0,0) to (n,n) consisting of east or north unit steps, always ending with an east step. The set of such paths is denoted by (n). We call base diagonal of a square path the diagonal y=x+k with the smallest value of k that is touched by the path (so that k≤ 0). The shift of the square path is the non-negative value -k. The breaking point of the square path is the lowest point in which the path touches the base diagonal (so for Dyck paths is (0,0)).

sentence:
For P ∈(p,n)^∗ℓ, ∘ d, and 1 ≤ i<j ≤ n+p, we say that the pair (i,j) is an inversion if 
	
		
  * either a_i(P) = a_j(P), i ∉(P), and j ∉(P) ( primary inversion ),
		
  * or a_i(P) = a_j(P) + 1, j ∉(P), and  i ∉(P) ( secondary inversion ).
	
	Then we define 
	
    (P)    #{ 0≤ i < j ≤ n+p | (i,j)  is an inversion}
          + #{0≤ i≤ n+p | a_i(D)<0 and  i ∉(P) }.
 
	This second term is referred to as bonus dinv .

sentence:
[Toroidal transversal structure labeling]
   

  Given a toroidal map G, a toroidal transversal structure labeling
  (or TTS-labeling for short) of G is a labeling of the
  half-edges of G with integers 0,1,2,3 (considered modulo 4)
  such that each edge is labeled with two integers that differ
  exactly by (2  4) and around each vertex the labeling form in
  counterclockwise order four non-empty intervals of 0, 1, 2,
  3.

sentence:
A tree is called a path if it has exactly two pendent
vertices.

sentence:
Let λ∈ L^∞(μ) be a T-invariant function  and ϕ∈ L^∞(μ). We say that ϕ is an eigenfunction with eigenvalue λ if


  * 
 |ϕ(x)| has value 0 or 1 for μ-a.e. x∈ X;

  * 
λ(x)=0 for μ-a.e. x∈ X such that ϕ(x)=0;

  * 
ϕ∘ T=λ·ϕ μ-a.e..

sentence:
Given the state vector x=(x(0),…,x(e)) of a liar game
with M elements,

the position vector u=u(x)=(u(1),u(2),…,u(M))

corresponding to x is defined by

    u(j):=min{k:∑_i=0^k x(i)≥ j}.

sentence:
A graph is Ore k-constructible if it is a complete graph K_k or if it can be constructed from K_k by successive applications of the following operation:


  * (Ore Merge) Suppose G_1 and G_2 are already-obtained disjoint graphs with respective edges (x_1,y_1) and (x_2,y_2). 
Let μ be a bijection from a subset of V(G_1) to V(G_2) so that x_1∉domain(μ) and x_2∉range(μ), and μ(y_1)≠ y_2.
Form the Hajós merge on G_1 and G_2 using the two edges, then identify the vertex pairs [x,μ(x)].
We abuse notation and denote the resulting graph (G_1,G_2).

Any construction of a graph using this process will be called an Ore construction .

Two ℒ^+_-formulas φ(x_1, …, x_d) and ψ(x_1, …, x_d) are logically equivalent just in case for every t ∈, the ℒ^+_Pres-formulas φ_t and ψ_t are logically equivalent; in other words, for every t ∈ and every (k_1, …, k_d) ∈^d, 
    φ_t(k_1, …, k_d) ⇔ψ_t(k_1, …, k_d).

sentence:
[(H,F)-regular graph]
	Let F  H be graphs on k vertices.
	A k-partite graph G is -(H,F)-regular if for every induced k-partite subgraph G' with n_F(G') ≥ n_F(G), we have HF(G') = HF(G) ±.

sentence:
Let 𝒦_1 and 𝒦_2 be two simplicial complexes.


  (1) Let v_i ∈ V(𝒦_i) be a distinguished vertex called base point, for i = 1,2. The wedge (product) of K_1 and K_2, (K_1,v_1)∨ (K_2,v_2), is a simplicial complex obtained by identifying v_1 and v_2. The homotopy type of the resulting simplicial complex is preserved under change of the base points v_1 and v_2 inside the connected components in the original complexes. In particular, for connected simplicial complexes the wedge is well defined up to homotopy equivalence without specifying base points.

  (2) The join of 𝒦_1 and 𝒦_2, 𝒦_1 * 𝒦_2, is a simplicial complex with vertex set V(𝒦_1*𝒦_2) = V(𝒦_1)⊔ V(𝒦_2) and simplexes s ∈ P(𝒦_1*𝒦_2), with s = s_1⊔ s_2 for s_i ∈ P(𝒦_i).

  (3) If V(𝒦_2) = v, then the join 𝒦_1 * v is called a cone with apex v and base 𝒦_1 (sometimes denoted by cone(v, 𝒦_1)).

  (4) If 𝒦_2 = S^0 (a complex whose topological realization consists of two isolated vertices), then 𝒦_1 * 𝒦_2 is called suspension of 𝒦_1 and denoted by Σ𝒦_1.

Let T be a border-strip tableau. The
sign of T is defined
by (T) = (-1)^h, where h is the sum of the 
heights of the border strips forming T.

sentence:
A degree sequence D = d_1, d_2, … d_n is a list of non-negative integers. A degree sequence is graphical if there exist a simple graph G whose degrees are exactly D. Such a graph is a realization of D. A degree sequence D is a tree degree sequence if each degree is positive and ∑_i =1^n d_i = 2n-2. 

A degree 1 vertex is called a leaf . A degree sequence is a path degree sequence if it has exactly two leaves. A realization of a tree degree sequence is called a caterpillar if its non-leaf vertices form a path. This path of non-leaf vertices is called the backbone .

sentence:
A stable n-labeled tree is a finite graph with n leaves {1, 2, ⋯,n} satisfying:


  * The underlying graph is a tree (i.e., there is no circuit).

  * Every (internal) vertex has at least 3 adjacent edges.

Let S(n) be the set of all stable n-labeled trees. Let S_k(n) ⊂ S(n) be the subset of stable n-labeled trees with precisely k vertices. It is straightforward to check that 

    S(n) = ⋃_k=1^n-2S_k(n).

sentence:
A MED decomposition of a 3-regular graph is a decomposition of it
into subgraphs G_1,G_2,G_3, where G_1 is a Matching, the components of
G_2 are Even cycles, and G_3 consists of independent Double-stars.  Given a
MED decomposition, let H be the graph formed from G_3 by deleting the
center edge from each component of G_3.

  We say that G is β-extremal if there exists a set B ⊂ V(G) such that
   |B| ≥ (1-δ/n-β)n and all but at most 4β n vertices v∈ B have |N(v) ∩ B| ≤β n.

sentence:
A t-array T=(t^(i)_j) ∈ℤ^n(n+1)/2 is called a GT pattern 
for GL_n if it satisfies the interlacing conditions:

    IC(1):     t_j^(i+1)≥ t_j^(i)
    IC(2):     t_j^(i)≥ t_j+1^(i+1)

for all i and j.

sentence:
Let (R,,k) be a Noetherian local ring, where k is infinite, and let I_1, …, I_n be a sequence of ideals of R, I := ∏_i=1^n I_i.  Suppose that d := ℓ(I) ≥ 1, and that {a_ij} and {b_ij} are complete reductions of I_1, …, I_n of type d.  Then for almost all matrices Z = {z_ij}∈ R^n × d (resp. vectors = {u_j}∈ R^d), we have that {a_ij^Z} (resp. {a_ij^}) is a complete reduction of I_1, …, I_n, where 
    a_ij^Z := 
    a_ij   if  j<d,
    ∑_h=1^d z_ih b_ih   if  j=d.
 (resp. 
    a_ij^ := 
    a_ij   if  j<d,
    ∑_h=1^d u_h b_ih   if  j=d.)

sentence:
(η-flexibility)
Given η > 0, we say that a square path P in a graph G is η-head-flexible if P is η-head-heavy and G[(P)^-_4] ≅ K_4.
We say that P is η-tail-flexible if P is η-tail-heavy and G[(P)^+_4] ≅ K_4.
If P is both η-head- and η-tail-flexible, we say that it is η-flexible .
We drop the prefix η- if it is clear from the context.

sentence:
(ℓ-triangle cycle Z_ℓ)
Write Z_ℓ for the graph with vertex set [ℓ] × [3] such that for all 1 ≤ i ≤ℓ and distinct 1 ≤ j,j' ≤ 3, we have (i,j)(i,j') ∈ E(Z_ℓ), and (i,j)(i+1,j') ∈ E(Z_ℓ), where addition is modulo ℓ. We call Z_ℓ an ℓ-triangle cycle.

Let T_ℓ be the spanning subgraph of Z_ℓ such that for all 1 ≤ i ≤ i' ≤ℓ and 1≤ j < j' ≤ 3, (i,j)(i',j') ∈ E(T_ℓ) whenever i=i'.
So T_ℓ is a collection of ℓ vertex-disjoint triangles.
word_labels: B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G be a claw-free graph. Then there is a well-defined graph
  cl(G) (called the closure of G) such that the following
  holds:
  
  
  * G is a spanning subgraph of cl(G),
  
  * cl(G) is the line graph of a triangle-free graph,
  
  * the length of a longest cycle in G is the same as in
    cl(G).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let Σ be a family of
pseudosegments and let S be a subset of Σ.  A point p of a
pseudosegment from S is a free point for S if
(F1) p is an endpoint of a pseudosegment in S, and
(F2) p is not interior to a pseudosegment in S, and
(F3) p is incident to the unbounded region of S, and
(F4) p is incident to the unbounded region of Σ or

          p is incident to a pseudosegment
that is not in S.

sentence:
[<cit.>] 
A chirotope is a function χ: E^r →{-1,0,1} such that:



  * it is not identically zero, i.e. χ≢0,

  * it is alternating, i.e. χ(σx)=  (σ) χ(x) for all σ∈𝔖_n,

  *  for all x_2, …, x_r and all y_0, …, y_r∈ E such that 

    χ(x_i) χ(y^i)≥ 0,

for all i>0, then we have

    χ(x_0) χ(y^0)≥ 0.

sentence:
For any pair of triangulations _P and _Q of point configurations P⊆^d and Q⊆^e, a web of stars in _Q with respect to _P is an order preserving map
  
    α : (_P^=d, ≼)
      →(__Q, ⊆).

  Two webs of stars α : _P^=d→__Q and β : _Q^=e→__P are compatible if
  
    σ∈β(τ) τ∉α(σ)
            for every σ∈_P^=d and τ∈_Q^=e.

sentence:
A source-terminal graph is a graph G with two distinct marked vertices s,t ∈ V(G). 

If G and H are two source-terminal graphs then we can define their parallel join as being the source-terminal graph G H, 
which is the disjoint union of G and H with the sources and terminals identified and with these two vertices forming the source and terminal of G H.  

If G and H are two source-terminal graphs then we can define their series join as being the source-terminal graph G  H which 
is the disjoint union of G and H with the source of H identified with the terminal of G, with the source of G becoming the source of G H, and the terminal of H becoming the terminal of G H.

sentence: An acyclic matching M of the face poset of a labeled cell complex is homogeneous if ℓ(σ)=ℓ(τ) for any σ,τ∈ M.

sentence:
Let (a_1,a_2) ∈^2_≥ 0, and 
𝒟 = 𝒟^a_1× a_2. 

Let s_1, s_2 be two integers such that 0≤ s_1≤ a_1, and 0≤ s_2≤ a_2. If S_1={u_1,…,u_s_1} is the set of the first s_1 horizontal edges in 𝒟, and S_2={v_a_2-s_2+1,…,v_a_2} is the set of the last s_2 vertical edges in 𝒟, then we call (S_1,S_2) the extremal pair (in 𝒟) of size (s_1; s_2).

sentence:
Let e,f be two x-monotone curves in 𝒞. 
We say that e,f are related if  e and f are non-crossing, there is a vertical line intersecting the relative interior of both e and f and furthermore for every vertical line intersecting the relative interior of both e and f the order of intersection is the same.

  The quasi-Schur function for α , denoted by QS_α, is given by
  
    QS_α(X) = ∑_T ∈(α) F_(T)(X),

  where F_β denotes the fundamental quasi-symmetric function.

sentence:
A spring-loaded push on a quasi-Yamanouchi Kohnert tableau is defined as follows. Let C denote the rightmost cell in some row i, and let j<i denote the highest nonempty row below row i, with D the leftmost cell in row j. Then
  
  
  * if the column of D is strictly left of the column of C and either the columns are nonadjacent or the label of D is less than the label of C, then move every cell below row i except D down one row and move cell C down to row j;
  
  * otherwise, if C and D lie in the same column and there is a cell, say E, immediately right of D, and the label of C is bigger than that of D,E, then move every cell below row i except D,E down one row and move cell C down to row j-1.
  
  Finally, apply the destandardization map to the result.

sentence:
Fix b ∈ℕ.   
The generalized greatest common divisor of r and s with respect to b is denoted _b and is defined as

    _b(r,s) := max{k ∈ℕ| k  divides  r  and  k^b  divides  s}.

sentence: A set of vertices x_1,…,x_l∈ H_1 is cyclic if for some permutation π∈𝒮_l, x_π(j) is in e(x_j) for every 1≤ i≤ a.

sentence:
A partition π∈_n is called universal , if π has exactly one block B with more than one element and the elements of B are circularly consecutive in P(π). 
		A chamber in |_n| is called universal , if every partition of the corresponding maximal chain in _n is universal. Compare <cit.>. An example for a universal chamber is shown in Figure <ref>.
		
		For a non-crossing partition π={B_1, …, B_k}∈_n  and a subset M ⊆{1, …, n}, the partition induced by M is defined as the partition π^M = {B_1 ∩ M, …, B_k∩ M}. Note that the induced partition is again non-crossing and can be identified with a partition in _#M. Induced chambers are defined analogously.

sentence:
Let 0< ν≤τ <1. Given any digraph G on n vertices and S ⊆ V(G), the ν-robust outneighbourhood RN_ν,G^+(S) of S is the set of all those vertices x ∈ V(G) which have at least ν n inneighbours in S. We define the ν-robust inneighbourhood RN_ν,G^-(S) of S is the set of all those vertices x ∈ V(G) which have at least ν n outneighbours in S.

G is called a robust (ν,τ)-outexpander if |RN_ν,G^+(S)| ≥ |S|+ν n for all S ⊆ V(G) with τ n < |S| < (1- τ)n. We define a robust (ν,τ)-inexpander similarly. If G is both a robust (ν,τ)-outexpander and a robust (ν,τ)-inexpander, we will say that G is a robust (ν,τ)-diexpander .

G is called a (ν,τ)-outexpander if |N^+(S)| ≥ |S|+ν n for all S ⊆ V(G) with τ n < |S| < (1- τ)n.

sentence:
Let G be a finite simple graph.  Define ∼ to be the equivalence relation of duplicates
    of G, and let [·]_∼ denote an equivalence class of this relation.  The
    de-duplicate graph of G is the graph G^⋆ with vertices given by the equivalence
    classes [v]_∼ for v ∈ V(G) and with an edge between [u]_∼ and [v]_∼ if and only if
    (u, v) ∈ E(G).

sentence:
Given a graph G, define the (Hadamard) critical exponents of G
to be

    CE_H(G) :=     min{α∈ : A ∈_G([0,∞)) ⇒
    A^∘β∈_G  for every β≥α},
    
    CE_H^ψ(G) :=     min{α∈ : A ∈_G() ⇒ψ_α[A] ∈_G  for every β≥α},
    
    CE_H^ϕ(G) :=     min{α∈ : A ∈_G() ⇒ϕ_α[A] ∈_G  for every β≥α}.

sentence:
Let T be a tree. We construct the outline graph of T as follows:
  first, all occurrences C^kF and C^ℓ L as rooted subtrees of T are replaced
  by special leaves “C^kF” and “C^ℓ L”,
  respectively (where replacement takes place by decreasing order of the
  replaced rooted subtree). In a second step, we consider all occurrences of subtrees C^kT'
  where T' has a unique branch T”. Every such subtree is replaced by
  the subtree T”, linked to the rest by a special edge “C^k_*”.

sentence:
Let T be a tree. We say that T fulfils the bipartition condition if the two classes
  in T's unique bipartition contain precisely the vertices of type A and B respectively.

sentence:
[ Sparse Regularity Lemma ]
For every ε>0, r≥ 1 and D≥ 1, there exist η>0 and T such that for every 0≤ p≤ 1, if G_1, G_2, …,G_r are (η,p,D)-upper-uniform graphs on the vertex set V, then there is an equipartition of V into s parts, where 1/ε≤ s≤ T, for which all but at most εs2 of the pairs induce an (,p)-regular pair in each G_i.

sentence: A q-design with parameters t-(v,k,λ_t)_q, or shorter a t-(v,k,λ_t)_q design, with v > k > 1, k ≥ t ≥ 1, λ_t ≥ 1, is a pair (, ) of the vector space =^v_q and a collection  of k-dimensional subspaces of  (called blocks), such that each t-dimensional subspace of  is contained in precisely λ_t blocks.

sentence:
Given a k-tuple ν=(ν^1,…,ν^k) of skew Young diagrams, we let SSYT(ν)=SSYT(ν^1)×⋯× SSYT(ν^k). Given T=(T^1,…,T^k)∈ SSYT(ν), let 𝐱^T denote the product 𝐱^T^1⋯𝐱^T^k. We say that T^i(u)<T^j(v) form an inversion if either
	
		
  * i<j and c(u)=c(v), or
		
  * i>j and c(u)=c(v)+1,
	 
	where c(u) is the content of u: if u has (row, column) coordinates (i,j), then c(u):=i-j. 
	
	We call (T) the total number of inversions occurring in T.

sentence:
[Assaf <cit.>]
A k-ribbon word is a pair (w,c) consisting of a word w and a weakly increasing sequence of integers c
of the same length such that if c_i=c_i+1, then there exist integers h and j such that
(h,i),(i+1,j)∈_k(w,c) and (i,j),(h,i+1)∉_k(w,c).
In other words, c_h=c_i-k and w_i<w_h≤ w_i+1 while c_j=c_i+k and w_i≤ w_j<w_i+1.

sentence:
An arithmetic matroid M = (E, , m) satisfies the strong gcd property if, for every subset X ⊆ E,
  
    m(X) = m(B) |B basis and |B ∩ X | = (X).

sentence: A finite collection 𝒫 = {𝒜_1 , 𝒜_2, ⋯, 𝒜_p } of subsets of ℝ/ℤ satisfying the five properties of Theorem <ref> is called a formal orbit portrait . The property (4) of Theorem <ref> implies that each 𝒜_j has a complementary arc of length greater than ( 1 - 1/d) (which we call the critical arc of  𝒜_j) that, under multiplication by -d covers exactly one complementary arc of 𝒜_j+1 d-times (which we call the critical value arc of 𝒜_j+1) and the others ( d - 1)-times.
